Professor Fredlund is a really wonderful professor. This is the first time this class was taught at UConn and she did a really fantastic job creating and teaching it. She really cares about her students and is very receptive to feedback. She is also so passionate about the subject which makes the class even more engaging.

Prof. Fredlund is great. Her lectures are interesting and everything that you have to do is laid out at the beginning of the semester. It's a lot of little things that make up your grade - I3's for attendance every lecture, participation in discussion section, a paper of sorts every week, and one group presentation. Great way to get a req done!
All the lectures were basically things from the textbook. All material was super clear and not complicated

I loved professor Fredlund! This is an easy class and I highly recommend taking it. I will say you shouldn't purchase the textbook as I never used it once so I feel that it's a waste of money, but overall 10/10 class.

Great intro course. Weekly tests (and the midterm/final) are open note, you have one 15 minute presentation for the whole semester but you work in a group. You don't have to read the textbook if you don't want to. I found the lectures quite interesting and honestly sometimes eye-opening. Plus it covers two gen ed requirements, I would recommend.
If you miss more than 3 classes you will be penalized (small assignment submitted at the end of every lecture to document attendance)

Professor Fredlund is one of those "If you pay attention, you'll do great. If you don't, you're screwed" situations. She's a solid professor who gives clear lectures, but you have to show up and actually put effort in to make it all count. Nothing's confusing or ridiculously hard, you just gotta do what's assigned and your grade is good.

Loved Professor Fredlund, this was a great class. She clearly loves her work very much. Her teaching is so clear and easy to understand, and the exams were also easy. If you need to fill a gen ed requirement, this is the perfect choice for an easy A.

Super sweet! I was actually in her sex and gender class but I can't seem to be able to add that course. Super sweet and caring and when I was too sick a few times this semester she told me to get better and not to worry. DON'T take advantage of her kindness because she doesn't deserve that but she will give you an extension or help if you need it.

Very easy class. Attendance is required because you have to submit 3 comments at the end of each lecture. Weekly online quizzes and a midterm and final exam, quizlet is your friend. One easy project for discussion and one short writing assignment weekly. Don't buy the textbook, everything is covered in lecture

This class was very light, and all exams were online with answers on Quizlet. Discussion participation is based off the TA. I skipped half the discussions and finished with a 95 attendance grade. The class is busy work, and you should be able to breeze by. The most work I did was reading an article and writing 3 questions about it each week.

Jessie is a great person and her class is super easy. You do have to show up to lectures for participation credit but the lectures are livestreamed via Kaltura. All her quizzes and exams are open-internet and are all on Quizlet. Easy grade

Prof. Fredlund was awesome. Her lectures were kinda boring because they go over the book chapters exactly, but you have to go to complete an I3 every class, which is basically for participation. Everything is super easy. Weekly open note quizzes, weekly reading/response. Midterm and final are both open note and online, just like the weekly quizzes

Great intro class for Freshman, or anyone who needs an easy A. Attendance is mandatory, but she livestreams the lectures so you don't have to go in person. Exam and Homework answers are on Quizlet. Minimal reading except for discussion which is mandatory to go to. Overall, a very easy class with interesting material.

Lectures are boring, all information is on slides. Weekly quizzes, participation questions every class and a short essay due every discussion. For discussion you only have to present a group presentation, be present and somewhat active. Very easy.

Her lectures are boring but you have to go because she has a code for the participation only shown in class, and it counts for a grade. Discussions aren't bad. 1 presentation for the whole semester worth 100 points. You have to participate in discussions. Course load wasn't bad at all, super easy. Open note everything. Midterm was super easy. 10/10

Easy stuff but annoying class. You can't skip discussion or lecture since participation is graded. Quizzes and exams don't have lockdown and it's on quizlet but not a big portion of your grade to be able to skimp on participating anyway. Kinda a bunch of busy work assignments due every week which is easy but just kinda annoying
Exams were online and there was always an assignment for attendance. There is also one project based off of readings

She requires the textbook, but you don't need it to pass the class. Can still get an A without it if you show up to every lecture. Lectures are mandatory because she does this attendance assignment every lecture. Lectures very straightforward and easy to follow. All exams and quizzes open notes. A lot of reading for discussion. Easy to get an A.
Her class was straightforward and easy. As long as you put in the bare minimum, you will succeed in this class.

One of the easiest classes I have ever taken. Lectures are pretty interesting, and exams are open book/internet. Only reason I didn't get an A is because I didn't show up to my discussion section half the time lol. Definitely recommend this class.

I genuinely loved this class. It was incredibly easy to get an A. Jessie is a little odd but she is super caring and understanding. Don't bother buying the textbook, I think I only read like the first few chapters. Really good gen-ed.

Professor Fredlund is probably one of the best professors I had thus far. Lectures are interesting and as long as you do weekly quizzes and show up and participate in discussions, it's an easy A. Midterm and final are based on lectures and quizzes, and are easy. Definitely recommend.
Nothing too extraordinary about Professor Fredlund. Easy A class if you have a good TA.

Easiest class I have ever taken and the best CA 2 class to take by far. Fredlund is a new professor, so she is still figuring out how to engage students in lecture, but she is very sweet and has done great this semester. The discussions are boring (like all of them), with one group project. Small participation assignments for each lecture.
I would highly recommend someone looking for an E course to take EVST1000E. Very light workload, exams only worth 20% of grade. don't buy the book, it is on z-libary for free :)

She's honestly one of the best professors at UConn. Her class was very informative and easy to handle. I enjoyed her class very much. She is very nice as well. My ta, Brady was the best too. She was super nice and funny. If you get her, you are lucky. This class deserves a 10/10.Thanks professor Fredlund

Very easy class, 2 exams and a group project in your discussion section. Participation matters in that section, but all the TAs I've met are nice and easy-going. The professor is very passionate, and very understanding as well. Homework isn't too bad, you have to submit something each lecture that proves you were paying attention, which isn't hard.

EXTREMELY easy course. Mandatory lectures, need to submit 3 comments each class. Boring lectures, don't waste time reading txtbook, prof talks about chapters in class. 3 thought questions (a paragraph each) due each week related to weekly article readings. 2 exams, VERY easy. Discussion = participation, 1 group presentation & mandatory attendance

Class was extremely easy. Just do your homework, and its an easy A. Fredlund and TAs are very nice as well, I had a couple emergencies and they were very understanding and easy to work with. Honors conversion was easy as well, just a couple extra assignments.

Professor Fredlund is a great professor! She is very passionate about the subject and about her work. Her lectures can be kind of repetitive and boring, but as long as you do the work and pay attention, it's an easy A. I definitely recommend this course for CA 4.

This class was very easy so if that's what you're looking for, this is perfect. One homework and quiz every week that are very simple. But, her lectures were unnecessarily boring. They were taken directly from the textbook and had way too much unnecessary information, making it hard to keep up. Very passionate professor, but not an enjoyable class.

The class was super organized and the material was really easy to understand. Most of what she covers in the lectures is also in the textbook so you can get by without reading it. There are supplemental readings too and an assignment based off of those as well, but I found those interesting.

ANTH 1000 with Professor Fredlund is an easy A. The class was somewhat interesting. It did have a tendency to teach opinions as if they are facts, but that's probably an issue with cultural anthropology in general, and not the professor.

Really great professor. Homework can get annoying and is a little hard to understand at first but you get used to it and its really easy. Quiz and Exams open notes and online and not difficult at all if you just go to class which you have to do for your grade anyway. Actually pretty interesting also. Enjoyed Jessie and the class

Fredlund was a great lecturer and understanding professor. There were two exams, both of which were online and not in a lockdown browser. I also took this class as an Honors class and the only additional work I had to do was to read an ethnography and write a 5 page paper on it. Fredlund clearly wants her students to do well.
Easy A as long as you show up to lectures because they are mandatory and 20% of your grade, both midterm and exam are open note very easy. Easy A for any elective or gen ed.

I think that Prof. Fredlund will be the best professor I have during my time at UConn. She is so incredibly organized, has real-life experiences that she relates back to the lectures, and her PowerPoints that she runs class off of are so well made. I don't think this woman ever missed a beat. Very respectable and a very good professor.

This class had quizzes and tests that were open notes and online. Super easy to breeze your way through. The I3s during class got super annoying and the presentations for the discussion section are anxiety inducing but otherwise the class itself is super easy. Jessie herself isn't a bad lecturer but it wasn't something I enjoyed having to sit thro

She's so nice and all her lectures are fairly interesting. You do have to attend lecture though because she requires you to pass in an "I3" for every lecture which is just 3 comments on the lecture. There is a quiz that's fairly easily due at the end of each week along with a small writing assignment. shes very organized and happy to help anyone!
An excellent professor and a great course!
I'm a senior POLS major and Dr. C is the best professor I've ever had at UConn POLS department! If you see his courses being offered, go for it!

I took POLS 1202 with Dr. Canbolat in the May 2024 term. Online courses are not my favorite, but I very much liked his classes. He is great at lecturing and answering students' questions. He was always accessible via email and genuinely cared about his students. Strongly recommended!
Fun course and an excellent professor!

Very fun professor to have! He explains the concepts in this class pretty well, even if you forgo the readings for that given week. Readings are simple, and you will end up needing them for the final and midterm for quotes, but for a week to week basis they are not needed. Midterm and final were short essays and not graded too harshly.
He is nice but takes attendance into consideration in grading as well as participation. You don't really need to pay attention to pass.

A good gen-ed class to take, I found it to be useful knowledge despite signing up for it just to fill a requirement. Professor Canbolat answered emails well and was very nice to talk to. Takes attendance at random times so beware.

BEST professor ever! He is very understanding and takes into account students feedback. Participation does matter, but I like how he made it optional if that was talking in front of the class or online via a discussion. For grading, it was two essays, and two online debates, all of which was easy.

Great class! He was very accessible outside of class. He was also very helpful! You can tell he cares about the students in the class and works to make sure everyone succeeds. The midterm and final were both take-home and for both, it was just answering two questions in essay form using any of the PowerPoints and any notes. Good gen-ed option!

Love him! You can tell he really cares about the course material and his students. I took this class as a gen-ed, but ended up really liking it. It is an easy class, with a few discussion board assignments and take-home essays for the midterm and final. Would definitely recommend taking this class with him!
Dr. Canbolat is a great professor, and despite this being a political science class, straight forward and unbaised. Great class for those in POLS and those not.

Easy class! Attendance is mandatory, he randomly checks. Weekly new sharing component which is easy, a midterm paper and a final paper. Two husky ct debates which were easy as well. I highly recommend this class for a gen ed.

This class was so easy! Really great professor with a good sense of humor. Had bi-weekly quizzes that were super easy if you just review notes from class. One midterm and one final. Both easy and consisted of two short answer questions. Drops lowest 2 quizzes. No textbook required.

POLS1202 with Dr. C was my favorite class in the Fall 2023 semester hands down! Unlike most professors, he really cares about his students and goes above and beyond to help them. Very approachable in and outside the class, too. If you have to take POLS1202 class, Dr. C is the prof. to go!

Class is alright, but the weekly quizzes can throw you off. Depending on your TA, there could be some issues but if you stay focused and take good notes you should be fine. Exams are 2 essay questions from the study guide in a blue book.

Although Dr. Sercan was a great professor, the classwork was pretty tedious. You read quite a bit, and the Midterm and Final are essay based but require you to cite sources through memory, which seems to be quite a lot if you are taking this course and are not a PoliSci major. Overall an easy course, just attend lecture and you will be fine.
Very cool professor. He knows his stuff and his interaction with students is amazing. I definitely recommend taking a class with Professor C!

Great professor and does his best to teach us all of the content over the semester. Discussion class can be a little tedious with quizzes almost every week. Overall not a crazy amount of reading just pay attention to lectures and be prepared for essay style midterm and finals.

Dr. C is the best! He is very knowledgeable in his area and he excels at teaching. More importantly, he cares about his students and is very accessible in and outside the classroom although it is a huge class (200 students!) Strongly recommended!!!

Lectures were really easy to understand and were also enjoyable. Professor Canbolat is one of the most charismatic people I've met and makes the class enjoyable even if you aren't a political science major. If you go to lectures the class is a pretty easy A. Definitely recommend

I would recommend taking this class, it was easy to understand the lectures because he engaged with the students. He has an accent but its not bad at all, he's pretty fair when it comes to grading exams and he gives out short easy quizzes every other week that would help your grade by the end of the course. I would his class take it again.
My favorite class and the professor this semester hands down. Professor Sercan was very engaging and friendly in and outside the class.

Professor Canbolat made us share news from around the world at the beginning of every class for credit, we had many readings for our discussion boards that we had every week so we got 1-2 questions to answer then we would respond to someone else's response. The Midterm and Final were papers with two questions with a minimum of 1,500 words.

Just show up, participate, and do your readings. I found the class a bit difficult at times but never unfairly; you get out exactly what you put in, and there's optional extra credit if you want to give yourself a bit of a buffer. Overall a great course, engaging, and the prof. facilitates interesting topical discussions.

It was an amazing class despite the pandemic circumstances. The professor did a wonderful job in getting us interested in the politics of other countries. Sharing news each week and watching movies related to our class are my faves - highly recommended!

prof has a lot of experience. very easy and great source for everything. you want an A. take him he will be very helpful. he does news sharing every week. I did my best to say anything important happened in the world and I received full credit. take him he 3 classes if you interested in pols take all his three.

Great teacher! He obviously truly cares about the material. When I needed an extension on an assignment, he was very accommodating, which is probably why I managed to maintain my grade... Also, we had an initial news-sharing component, which required knowledge of current events. Don't worry though, he's not looking for a dissertation or anything.

Overall good class with not lots of hw. Participation does matter and he does new sharing in each class. Also for my class, he gave us the Friday class off to focus on our weekly discussion board which was nice.

I highly recommend taking one of his classes. He works hard to connect with students and makes sure everyone does well and understands the material. He has a good balance of discussion,lectures,group/partner work and videos throughout the course.A dynamic from the beginning is set where students would respect and maximize what they learn from him.
Really cool and easy-going professor. His POLS 3426 class went seamless for me. Highly recommended!

Really enjoyed the Cinema class with Professor Canbolatt this semester. It is great to watch and analyze political movies. The course is well-structured and engaging. My favorite part was discussing important political news of the week at the beginning of each class.
He is absolutely amazing! Classes are easy, no classes on Friday's, we just did discussion boards. Never got bored in this class. He keeps it interesting, and no homework. He is just really good!
I enjoyed his classes very much. Professor Serjan is pretty chill and caring. Highly recommended!
Great guy. You have a weekly reading/discussion and 2 papers (one midterm and one final). Very easy grader but participation and attendance matters, and he gives Fridays off!!
Good professor, I definitely recommend taking him, we have weekly discussion boards, and two major papers plus extra credit opportunities.
Excellent POLS professor. Very friendly and caring. I got an A as the midterm grade in this class although I am not a POLS major. :) Strongly recommended!
One of my favorite classes this semester. I like the course format and Prof. Canbolat's welcoming attitude in the class and accessibility outside the classroom.
I am taking Cinema, Propaganda and Politics class with Professor Canbolat this semester. It has been going very well so far. I will come back again when the semester is over. :)
Very cool professor! His POLS 1202 is my favorite class this semester at UConn Stamford.

I am taking POLS 1402 with Professor Canbolat this semester. His class makes me like UConn-Stamford and International Relations. He is an easy grader, too! I am undecided at the time being, and I am considering to switch to the POLS major next semester.

He's an amazing professor! His class isn't too hard. His classes are amazing since there is a lot of in group discussion and participation opportunities. This allows his classes to engage with the topic more and gain a better understanding of the course. He is easy to communicate outside of class as well, so don't ever feel hesitate to reach out!

I am a big fan of Professor Canbolat's teaching style and his chummy attitude in the classroom. He treated us like a colleague and encouraged us to speak our mind freely about the course materials and world affairs through news-sharing at the beginning of each class.

Sercan Canbolat was my favorite professor at UConn Stamford in the Fall semester. He really knows his subject and does a great job in getting students participate in the lectures and discussions in person and online on HuskyCT.
He is a real gem. Professor Canbolat really cares about his students and goes the extra mile to help them succeed. One the best professors at UConn.
Sercan Canbolat is one of the best professors at UConn's Department of Political Science. Strongly recommended!
Very smart and nice professor. He is always accessible and very helpful both in and outside the class. I am taking his Cinema class next semester - I am already stoked about it!

I loved this class and the professor. It is both easy and fun to learn from Professor Canbolat. He treated us like colleagues and always welcomed student feedback on his teaching style and course materials. I learned a lot about Comparative Politics in this class. Specifically, I loved the news-sharing component of the class!

Professor Canbolat made the course very interesting and accessible to all students. He helped the students enjoy International Relations field. Thanks to his help and encouragement I am considering to change my major from Psychology to Political Science!

Sercan Canbolat is my favorite professor this semester. Very engaging and friendly! He truly cares about his students. I received extensive and instant feedback on my assignments and writing from Professor Canbolat. Strongly recommended!

Really nice Professor, makes sure the class is engaged, a couple of group projects but they are definitely manageable and also interesting. Great class to learn about certain aspects of our government.

Professor Sercan is an excellent professor. His lectures are extremely helpful, and he genuinely wants his students to learn and get good grades. He gives extra credit papers that help you get a better grade in class. He also responds to emails quickly.
He's an excellent professor! I enjoyed his class very much. He very lenient and he cares for his students. He's always very understanding and helpful to the students.

I loved this class and professor Canbolat's teaching style. He genuinely cares about his students and helps them succeed. He goes the extra mile to be accessible outside class and provides instant feedback. He always got back to my emails in a couple of hours and helped me make up for the assignments that I missed when I tested positive for COVID!
I took Professor Canbolat in the fall and he was great. I would 10/10 recommend him. The class is very straightforward as long as you show up and listen as well as participate.
He's a pretty flexible teacher. Although he has a way he likes to do things, he's receptive to feedback and makes clear changes depending on what the class wants.
Love this dude. He's got a nice sense of humor and lectures don't feel painfully long. Gives lots of EC opportunities. Participation does matter but it's easy to do so.

Sercan is an amazing professor! Although his lectures can be a bit boring if you're not interested in the topic, he makes sure to answer questions and to explain the topic well. He gives extra credit often which can really help boost your grade, although you probably won't need it because this class is fairly easy. Easy to reach by email!

He's an excellent professor. He gives extra credit papers that really boost your grade in the class. If you never need help on an assignment, send him an email and he will respond quickly with an answer for you. If I had the chance to take his class again I would. He is also a very good grader, as long as you follow his instructions you will exceed
Professor Sercan is a great teacher, not only I learned so much from him but I really enjoyed his class as well. I highly recommend him!
Amazing Professor, and an amazing class! Definitely take political science with him. You won't regret it!

Sercan is a real gem. He really knows his stuff and he cares about his students so much. He is personable and easy to reach, he always answers my e-mails right away. Although English is not his mother tongue (he is from Turkey), he speaks English very well and uses some words that I have never heard of. I respect him a ton! Strongly recommended!

I took the class online asynchronous over the summer, so I cannot speak much on how he is. However, the class was very easy, the material was interesting, and the papers were fun to do. The exams were a bit long, but they come directly from the material, so it's hard to do bad. Exams are all memorization, and the papers are more opinion-based.

Professor Spurling is one of my favorite ever instructors. He is so kind and very knowledgable, and he does a great job keeping everyone engaged. His lecture slides are not the clearest and a lot of the exam is what he says out loud, so it is wise to attend class.

I took this class 2 semester ago and I am still thinking about some of the contents the course taught me. Mark is an extremely exciting lecturer, he uses participation, and makes students interested in the topics he's teaching. Mark is one of the best professors UConn has to offer.

Take this class with him!! Lectures are easy to follow and kinda interesting too. As long as you take good notes and review them the exams aren't bad and the couple papers you have to write are not long as well. Not a stressful class, he explains everything very clearly.

Professor Spurling is one of my favorite professors at UConn. This class is very interesting and informative. I definitely recommend taking it. Although the tests are worth a large portion of your grade, they are very fair and you will do well if you study for them.

Probably the best professor I have taken a class with. The lectures are required, as almost all the material on the exams comes from the lecture, but the lectures are always entertaining and interesting. Extremely understanding and kind.

Such a great guy and amazing lecturer, definitely worth the hype. 4 Exams worth 80% and a couple papers worth 20% but the Exams are not difficult if you pay attention in lecture and getting an A is very doable. There is also an extra credit assignment that improves an exam score. Take this man!

Fantastic Professor! Material could be dry if you're not into it, but I loved it. He is very enthusiastic and makes the class interactive. attendance is strongly recommend as it helps to remember the material because he uses examples.

One of the best teachers in the business school by far. His lectures were engaging and he always relates the material to our lives. 2 discussion posts and 1 short paper for a few documentaries, and 4 MC tests that required studying. The information was always interesting and he posts all slides online. Easily the best choice for this course.

Zero homework, the entire class is based on the 4 exams (worth 20.05% each). Exams are worth 82% of your entire grade. Other things that make up your grade are a few papers & discussion boards. There are a few extra credit opp but only worth 1% of your grade. SO study hard for those exams. No final during finals week, class is done a bit early.
One of the best professors I've had at UConn. No homework and the class is very exciting.

Professor Spurling has really amazing lectures. They are very interactive and interesting, and directly pertain to the exams. He is a professor that truly cares about his students. Exams are very fair if you pay attention to lectures.10/10 recommend!

As a senior I can easily say Professor Spurling is the best professor I have ever had. His lectures are extremely interesting and hes just genuinely an awesome guy. Three exams that are very fair with a few discussion posts/papers that we had to do on assigned documentaries that were graded easily. TAKE HIM!!!

Favorite teacher at UConn!! He has amazing lectures that are so engaging and interesting. Tests and material are not difficult if you go to class every day and pay attention. Literally considering changing my major to BLAW after taking his class.

Best professor I've had at UConn so far. He made this class so interesting with real world examples and the material easy to learn. Uploads all the slides he uses in class so you can go back and look over them before class. Has videos lectures too to use. 4 test that make up 82% of your grade so study but they are straightforward.

Professor Spurling was one of the best professor's I've had at UConn. His style of teaching was benficial for so many different students. He used real life examples for much of the content. With the four exams (which were not hard if you paid attention), he assigned two discussion posts and one paper. This is how a class should be structured!

Seriously the best professor ever. Uses lecture time to find interactive examples with students, actually making this class interesting compared to other BLAW courses. Tests are about 20% each (4 of them). However, if you pay attention they're very fair. You learn worthwhile content from an incredible professor.

Professor Spurling was a pretty good professor. He knew the material well and provided a lot of real-life examples. His exams were not bad if you studied, but most of them were situational or hypothetical questions. He is also not the best at responding to emails.

Lectures are relatively informative, gives a lot of real world examples that help you understand the material. Posts lecture videos online most of the time which were helpful in preparation for exams. Exams were not the most difficult, but you definitely need to go to class to do well. 82% of the grade is four exams, so be sure to study.

Professor Spurling is a lawyer that ties his experience in the field to the curriculum that is learned. The content is interesting and he keeps you engaged with his case examples and personal experience. I only got a B because I was not able to go to many lectures and scanned the slides he posted. Easy A if you attend and take good notes.

Spurling gave clear lectures with real life applications and examples which made concepts easier to understand. There were 4 tests and 3 short writing assignments on movies/ documentaries. It was refreshing to be presented with material in an engaging way. For the first time ever I found the assignments interesting and enjoyable

I really enjoyed Professor Spurling's online course. We were only graded on exams and a couple of short papers, all of which were very easy as long as you watched the lectures and took minimal notes. The real world examples he gives (as he is a practicing attorney) are extremely interesting! I found myself telling my family about his lectures..

He is a great Professor! The class was incredibly interesting because he added his own experience as a lawyer and gave many examples for everything he was talking about. exams are easy as long as you take good notes and study the notes and slides. The hardest part for me was the court cases we had to go to because it was time consuming but easy.

Spurling is my favorite professor at UConn (but loves to cold-call so if that isn't your thing - good luck). Attendance isn't required, but you will miss a lot of exam content if you don't go, so go. Class is divided into 4 exams (21.5% each) and one paper worth 14%, but you can get up to 10 points in extra credit on your exam total. Great class.

Dr. Spurling is genuinely a great professor. He is incredible at breaking the material down, and explaining it in a fun and exciting way. There's 2 papers combined count for 25% of the grade, the rest are tests. The tests are fair, but if you don't study you won't do well. Also, the lectures are great, but you can learn from the PPTs and be fine.

Had Professor Spurling for the summer program. He is such a nice guy and his exams were really easy, all the material was directly from the lecture slides. We ended up getting credit for going to the court house for the day and then writing a review of our experience. He made the class super interesting and I would recommend taking it to anyone.

Spurling was a great professor. He is a lawyer so he often gives advice about the things he is teaching. Teaches heavily through made-up scenarios and follows powerpoints made by the book publisher. The book is not mandatory to buy as he wants the students to save money. Very caring and would recommend him!

Professor Spurling sucks. Exams are so difficult and he does nothing to help students during office hours. Also, he hates students. Exams have tricky wording and it is just so much material. Do not take Spurling's class. Also, he does not make blaw interesting. He lectures and all the material is too bland. I dislike him so much. Avoid at all costs

Spurling is a great professor. Just be aware you do have to do some after-class work: visiting a courtroom, watching a video/movie, and reading an article. Overall nothing too strenuous and the class is somewhat a review of high school civics. Just pay attention in lecture and copy down the Powerpoints and the exams (50q, MC) are an easy A

Genuinely interesting professor! He posts the slides to help you study, but I still recommend going to class to hear him explain things further (he does like cold calling, though). Exams are all multiple choice, and a large chunk of the grade. Don't bother with the textbook. Really nice guy, would have an adult libation with

Great guy, cares about you and how much you learn and how much you can apply to the real world. Writing assignments are very easy and are pretty much guaranteed 100s and gives a nice boost to your grade. Exams account for 80% of your grade but not too bad. Class isn't mandatory and slides alone cover 80-90% of exam. No reading needed.

Wow this class was tougher than expected. The material seems simple when it's presented but the exams are so tricky. The wording is put in such a twisted way that it's hard to understand. He is a good guy and keeps the class engaged but man, the exams were tough. Thought this would be an interesting and somewhat easy A, but I'll end up with a C :(

Prof. Spurling is awesome; I had him for 3175 and saw he was teaching this class so I took it as an elective. There are 3 exams and 2 movie responses, with an optional extra credit essay. Exams are trickier than 3175 but still managable if you read through & process each question. One of my favorite profs at UConn!

Professor Spurling is the BEST professor at UConn!! His lectures are amazingly interesting and his exams are extremely fair. Lecture is not mandatory but I dont see why you wouldnt want to go! The things you learn in class will help you in life in general outside of the class. TAKE HIM
Professor Spurling is the best BLAW professor at UCONN. His class is really interesting and enjoyable. He only test you on the topics that he talked in class, but his test can be tricky.

Professor Spurling is the best BLAW professor by far. His lectures are very clear and he only tests you on topics that he has taught in class. The book is good to have to help clarify topics, but it is not necessary. Spurling will answer any questions you have and definitely wants you to do well in his class. He is very passionate about BLAW.

Professor Spurling is a really cool guy who knows what he is talking about. He makes class interesting with real life cases and it is an interactive class. Cares about students and wants them to do well. Exams are pretty easy if you pay attention, he asks questions based on a lot of what he said in class instead of the PPT.

Spurling's class is relatively straightforward: you learn the material in class, study it, and recite it on exams. His lectures are very interactive, for he loves to choose on random students for law-related scenarios. Exams can be wordy so read closely, and know the concepts he stresses. I really enjoyed the class!
Good sense of humor. Test questions are tricky so be careful, some are worded just to trip you up. Made a boring class bearable.

Has a dry sense of humor that makes a boring subject matter pretty interesting. Uses a lot of real life examples to illustrate the topics. Actually makes you want to show up to class, which is good because some exam questions come directly from class videos and discussion

Amazing professor who makes a dry subject interesting. Lectures are really awesome he uses real-life examples and gets students involved in hypothetical situations. Posts powerpoint slides online, but you still need to take good notes. Exams are tricky and difficult, but he gives plenty of extra credit opportunities. Highly recommend!

Marks a good guy that makes a boring class bearable. Personally, i never showed up, he posts the slides on blackboard. Exams are straight from the slides and stuff he says in lecture. Exams are long and can be tricky

I took this class with Spurling because I had a good experience with him previously. He is really willing to help students and answer questions, and engage them in the material. This was a new course so we spent half the semester doing presentations that then got graded by the other students. Overall: simple, painless, and usually interesting.

One of the best professors at UCONN! His class was so interesting and really grabbed your attention. He used helpful real life examples to explain the material which made it a lot easier to grasp. He is highly knowledgeable and really enjoys what he does. I highly recommend him one of the best classes offered at UCONN.

NOT TO SOUND REPETITIVE FROM OTHER PEOPLE WHO RATED HIM, BUT: great guy! his lectures are interesting and useful. Exams are multiple choice and can be a little tricky (like most multiple choice exams are), but he offers extra credit in case you do bad on an exam. definitely recommend taking a class with him! I got an A
Awesome guy: easy-going and super helpful. Great lecturer,I actually wanted to go to class, haha. Helps that he's kinda hot too.

A lovely professor who enjoys his job and cares a lot about his students. His lessons were clear and very easy to follow-especially with his examples. Tests are slightly tricky, but fair. His one fault is that he's a bit oblivious. He tries to make shy people feel more comfortable, but comes across as a little creepy rather than reassuring.
He makes class SO interesting. I love going to listen to his stories & opinions.
awesome professor and a great guy! i would recommend him for any blaw class he teaches!

Awesome professor, I highly recommend him. He remembers who is in class even though he wont take attendance. Go to ALL of the lectures because his exams are an exat model of the lecture notes and examples in class. Don't bother buying the book. He will make class VERY interesting even if you have no interest in business law.
Awesome professor! Always try to help you. Well organized lectures. Exams are little bit hard, but as long you read the book, you should at least get a B+. Extra credit provided. Take him!!!

Aweeesome class!!! Gets you involved in all discussions and loves to just be casual with the students. You aren't going to want to skip this class because the lectures are really good and his examples are too. Take good notes; exams are a replica of his notes.
He's an awesome instructor. Very personable and understanding. Also, exams are pretty much a replica of the class examples so if you pay attn. in class, than you'll do great!
No Comments
Terrific guy, willing to help you, best lectures in school of business.
he's really nice and easy to talk to. has a good sense of humor and will help you if you need help on anything. supportive guy

Lecture attendance wasn't mandatory and all slides were posted. For TJ the TA, discussion attendance was mandatory. Weekly homework was slightly difficult and took about an hour. All exams had study guides exactly like the actual test with the answers posted. Lots of extra credit and low grades dropped. Easy class! Prof. cares about his students!

Professor Rossberg is definitely passionate about what he is teaching but lectures were slightly boring. From others I've talked to, this was an easier class than 1107, but that was mostly because of my TA, Amit. He was extremely helpful and always willing to meet with students. Definitely try to be in his section if you can.

The class is not an easy one, but the professor does care about his student and changed his teaching style mid course, just to try and help us. I will admit though, my TA (Amit), was a godsend; he is the greatest TA i've ever had and would go out of his way to help his students. It was thanks to him that I got an A.
He is very passionate about what he teaches which makes the lectures more enjoyable.

Worst class I took at UConn. Exams are so hard for no reason and nothing is taught in a clear way. Must self learn everything in this class. Answer keys for study guides don't even explain what to do half the time and doesn't provide any helpful assistance. Please don't take this class.

Not easy for a Gen Ed. Discussion sections are mandatory for participation credit. You can skip lectures but you're going to have to read the notes and practice on your own; the material is not easily comprehendible. There were only 3 exams though including the final. Homework weekly.

Such a confusing class for a beginner elective. Took this class as a senior because I needed an easy elective, but this class is far from easy. If you want an easy A, DO NOT take this class. Offers very little chances for redemption.

Lectures are online and very boring. Content is somewhat hard to understand. No attendance for online lecture but discussion is in person. Graded by somewhat weekly homework assignments which are all application. Two midterm exams and a final which are manageable if you study a lot. Answers to questions are very up in the air.
Horribly rude and condescending.

Marcus is awesome, super nice guy. Gives you the chance to redo almost anything (including exams) for a better grade. If you're stuck on anything too he will help even during exams. Just show you care and he will treat you well.

Professor Rossberg is a wonderful instructor. The material covered in 2211Q can be tough, but he really puts in effort explaining concepts during lectures. Very accessible outside of class and gives helpful feedback on homework and exams.

I liked Marcus a lot. This is a niche class so there is not a lot of help online but the textbook is extremely useful when in doubt the answer is probably in the textbook. Exams were online and not timed which decreased a lot of stress. You can redo weekly homework for a better grade. Difficult class but it's hard to fail.

Rossberg provided the lectures, but your grade is not defined by him. Utilizing the lectures, discussions, and homework, getting an A is possible. I failed the midterm, but my final exam grade replaced it and ensured my A. Participating in discussion is beneficial. Rossberg's lectures are super boring, so no need to really go; he also records them.

Lectures were online and recorded so you could go to class time or watch it later. Only in person aspect was discussion. 60% of your grade is the midterm + final, 30% are the weekly hw assignments, 10% is participation in discussion. Dropped lowest hw grade + replaced midterm grade w final grade if you did better on the final.

Professor Rossberg had good lectures and was a nice person. However, Phil 1102 to me was very hard. Content before midterm was hard to understand but got easier as the year progressed. Midterm was in person/pencil paper, but final was online/lockdown. Go to discussion sections and do MANY practice problems if you want to somewhat pass.

Lots of reading & hw every week. Practice midterm and final are exactly like the actual exams. Material was difficult the first half of class but got significantly easier. Go to discussions and practice a lot and you will be set. He does have an accent that can be difficult to understand

Lecture is not mandatory- he posts them online! Very understanding person. Weekly homework. Just read the textbook chapters he assigns and watch the lectures and you're good. You MUST participate in discussion, but if you do the work it's easy. Content is not that difficult to grasp if you put an ounce of effort in. He's very kind.

There is ONE midterm exam that over half of the class fails (including myself). Professor Rossberg assigns extremely difficult homework assignments and insanely long reading. The class is entirely self-taught. If you can help it, 100% TAKE A DIFFERENT PHILOSOPHY CLASS!
1102 was an extremely challenging class for something labeled as an introductory class. The homework assignments are confusing and so is the material. Not an easy class to understand by any means.

Professor Rossberg was okay for me. He seems really sweet, but isn't the best at explaining things. I did appreciate us being able to take home the midterm and the final, but he grades really tough. He also grades participation, which for me is hard because I have social anxiety and hate speaking up in class. He doesn't accept any late work either.

He is frankly not doing his job. He assigns insane amounts of reading and does a very poor job explaining anything or responding to questions. He actually just stopped grading any assignments halfway through the semester but expected us to improve based on feedback? He also literally made a bunch of essay prompt mistakes.

Professor Rossberg is not as terrible as people say. I found him very understanding and inclusive. Reading the textbook is a must to do well/understand and the homework is good practice. The practice midterm/final he provides are exactly like the actual exams. His exams also require exact definitions to get full credit, so know your definitions!

You can get away with never going to lecture, the slides explain themselves pretty much. Personally, I didn't even buy the textbook, I just relied on the free textbook guides you can find online and that he shared with us because the content is pretty easy to understand you just have to practice a lot to understand. And go to discussion.

Prof. Rossberg is the most unpleasant, disrespectful, rudest man I'ver ever encountered. He wants to prove that his class is the best and he is soooo smart. His emails make my blood boil just bc he so rude and unaccommodating, even during the pandemic. This is literally philosophy, its not supposed to be hard but he makes is so much harder.
Do not take this class!!!!!
One of the most unpleasant people I have met in my life.

I did not like this class at all. Professor Rossberg made lectures extremely boring to the point where I did not show up to class. I basically taught myself the material and went to discussions. The class material is very easy though, I just would not take it with this professor. Plus he's very rude.

Definitely would attribute my grade in the class to having an amazing T.A. who basically reviewed and re-taught all that was covered in lecture that week. Weekly quizzes and a midterm and final make up your grade, so doing the quizzes and good exam grades are essential. Put time into reading the textbook, review slides, and DO THE QUIZZES!!

In all honesty, I feel bad for this guy. In general, he doesn't care, he talks down to his students, and I don't blame him. If I was a teaching a class on Logic I'd loose it too. If you read the book, and do the homework you'll do fine, but don't expect him to help you.

He really isn't as bad as most people say he is. You have to do the readings on your own and go to the lectures, but if you study for the exams, you'll do well. Gave an extra credit question on the midterm and dropped the lowest homework grade. Only two exams (midterm and final), each worth 35% of your grade, but they are definitely doable.

Worst professor I have ever had. Talks down on students from a soap box and makes zero sense when he lectures. He missed a class once without even sending out an email too. Very hard grader on his papers

One of the worst teachers at UConn. Professor Rossberg does the bare minimum in teaching his students about aesthetics, instead he lets the class discuss among themselves for 50 minutes. EXTREMELY tough grader with a condescending attitude.

Took this class online over the summer. The subject matter is ridiculous, incredibly boring. The class itself was stupid, as the professor didn't do a single thing. The class is literally buy the textbook online then read it yourself and do HW, it's almost like we didn't have a professor. Both exams are very hard with way too much information.

Expects you to understand everything in each chapter, which there is A LOT to remember. If you receive a bad grade on a discussion, he doesn't comment why. Midterm and final were difficult. Only took this class as a gen-ed requirement but it hurt my overall GPA.

Worst professor at uconn. Don't believe the good reviews, he is trash. Our midterm average was a 67, did not curve it. No partial credit was given, if he did not like what u wrote he marked it all wrong. His lectures are boring and he never gives time for questions. I was told by my friends that this was easy and that its a guaranteed A. Not true.

Discussion and homework were easy. For most TAs, you get an A for discussion if you show up the majority of the time & I got a 95 on homework as it was fairly easy. Tests are horrible, not because of what is on it, but how they grade it. If you are not word for word you won't get more than 1/2 credit. Material is useless. Dont take take this class.

This class must have changed from this the previous years. I'm an honors premed student forced to take a PHIL class and I chose this one cause it had logic in the title. Material couldn't be any less useful if it tried. The blue book exams where you literally need to be word-for-word to get credit are insane. Stay away from this class at all costs.

After seeing how they graded the midterm, the criteria was absolutely ridiculous. If you don't give them a word for word definition of what they ask, you will not receive full credit. The answers you think are right or you can argue points back for will not receive credit either. Overall, probably my least favorite class at UConn.

If he does not like you it will be reflected in your grade! speaking in class is a must, it worth 30% of your grade. He also changed the whole content of the class, instead of being a philosophy class on aesthetics it was a class on art. I would have LOVED a class on aesthetics, but I got a horrible art class.

Honestly I would've been fine if I didn't go to lecture. The book spells out everything for 1102 perfectly. I would recommend reading the book though! It's very helpful and easy to follow. The class was really easy. Rosberg was a little hard to understand and kinda dull but I warmed up to him after awhile. He is also pretty helpful if you got him.

Pretty easy class. Two tests, and the rest of your grade is based off discussion + weekly online homework assignments. My TA planned on doing weekly quizzes but that never happened. I stopped going to lecture after the midterm. I just used the bookslides to study for the final and did well so lecture is unnecessary. Couldn't understand him anyway.

The class is very easy. I found the professor hard to understand and very inaccessible. I relied on the book for mostly all the information. The book is crucial to doing well in the class, but you do not have to go to lecture. Weekly quizzes that can be long and annoying at times. Only tests are the midterm and final, which were not difficult.

Rossberg, was pretty good and it was a well structured class. There is weekly homework which can take some time if you don't go to lecture. The tests weren't terrible, however, I did find the material to be strange. As for TA's, it really depends who you get. Mine was very helpful, but I heard others weren't very good.

LOTS of homework on online reading quizzes, usually over 30 questions each week and only one try per test. No extra credit and your grade relies on the reading quizzes, midtermfinal, and discussions. Midtermfinal aren't terribly difficult but sometimes the wording is confusing and the TA was confusing too. Powerpoints are posted online.
This class was fantastic. I would take it again if I could. Wish they still offered symbolic logic II. Rossberg is really knowledgeable and interesting, he's also a cool guy in general.
Great teacher, very clear, very helpful no matter what your philosophy/logic interest is. Knowledgeable and relatable. Highly recommend.

Good/easy class! Skimming the reading prior to lecture helps, but his lectures are straight from the book (sometimes boring). Homework assignments are an easy grade-booster as well as discussion "participation". Only 2 exams all semester but they aren't bad. You can tell that Rossberg loves what he teaches and actually cares about student success.

This class SUCKS. Rossberg is a bad teacher, rambles on and on. The lectures do not help; he literally reads off the slides he puts on-line. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I was more worried about passing this class than a calc class! wish i never took it.

The book is REQUIRED for this course. So is going to lecture; he explains everything in class really clearly and fully. He seems like a genuinely good guy, and he's passionate about his subject. Great beard and accent too.
Marcus is great. Goes over the readings in class so you don't have to do both. Homework is easy, straight from your book. As long as you somewhat study for exams you will be okay.

this was a pretty easy class. marcus is great, very willing to help. i barely went to class and discussion the last 2 months because all he does is go over the readings. if you're confused, go to him and they'll help. the tests aren't hard nor easy, if you study you'll do fine. no papers, no quizzes. just homework and exam grade.
Class is very dull. He always starts late and ends late. the class is very easy though
Awesome professor. Crystal clear and super helpful. I wish I could take more classes with him.
Fabulous professor, he teaches logically and cares a lot about his students. I looked forward to class. Funny guy, great beard.
I love this professor. Took him for Symbolic Logic too. He is just a great all around guy and does his absolute best at clarifying material when there is confusion. Fantastic professor!

This was an online class, but she seemed really passive aggressive. Overall if you do the course the way she wants, you end up spending 9+ hours on this class. If you take GEOG 1700, finesse the exams by studying like crazy before them, and find the hw answers in the PowerPoints. Take Dr.Thibeault if you have to but other profs are probs better.

This class was entirely online so I didn't have much interaction with her, but she was a little passive aggressive sometimes. Other than that the class was great, very organized set-up, clear guidelines. Weekly assignments, 3 exams, one semester project. Perfect gen-ed, doesn't require too much stress.

Lectures are boring but I don't think the professor should be getting as much hate as she does. Content itself is fine she will help you if needed. Just show up to class and submit weekly assignments which are easy. You can get B's on both exams and still end up with an A- or A in the class if you do everything else thoroughly. Not a tough class!

Dr. Thibeault is a sweet woman. Unfortunately, her lectures are very boring/disorganized and attendance is mandatory in a huge lecture hall. She gives out pop assignments weekly which are graded not based on completion, rather how well the response is. Though she is passionate about geography, the class is hard to sit through.

She is so extremely monotoned.The class may be interesting but I wouldn't know because her voice puts me to sleep. In 2320E she grades participation, one minute papers or short answer questions but you must be in class to take them. There is no set date on when these participations are, which is why you must go to class if you want the credit.

Dr. T is a very nice woman, but as a teacher she is VERY boring. Reads completely off slides that are available on HuskyCT. Attendance is mandatory because she gives random in-class participation assignments. 1 weekly assignment, but with SO much reading so plan accordingly. (Online) Book discussions every few weeks on a very boring book.

if theres another E course available, take that instead. class is sooo boring and waste of time, but sometimes she has random in-person assignments worth points and will affect your grade. she weirdly grades and will even take off points for "bad grammar". way too much work for an E course

This professor has single-handedly made me vow to never go to a climate rally again. I swear to god this class has to be a psyop to make me care as little as possible about climate change. It's like this class was designed specifically to torture me. This class has made me want to do everything in my power to make climate change worse. Avoid.

Dr. Thibeault is very boring and at times passive aggressive. However, the class itself is really not bad at all. There is a lot of content, but exams are pretty straightforward and she gives second chances on exams. I would say I spent a lot of time on homework, but it's fine. Don't let her awful impression deter you from taking this class.

Professor Thibeault is a very friendly woman but this class is truly awful. There is so much work given and she expects you to do an absurd amount of assignments in not enough time. For an E course full of non-GEOG majors there is no need for three exams, four book reports, weekly homeworks, and reading two textbooks. Do not take this class.

Information necessary for exams can be found in google slides, the textbook, or practice quizzes so attending the lectures isn't needed. There is weekly homework, 3 exams with 1 cheat sheet allowed, and a final project at the end. There is a lot of opportunity for extra credit and take the practice quizzes. I thought it was an interesting class.

I took this class as a gen ed requirement and it is too much work for a gen ed. There are three exams and while you get a cheat sheet, it's still hard. I also had a pretty long homework assignment each week. Final project was nice and boosted my grade. She responds to emails quickly and is nice, but the class isn't worth the stress and frustration.

If you're choosing this class because it is the only E with spots lefts, there is a reason; DON'T take it. She basically reads off a paper and slides the entire class, all of which is available to you. But class is made mandatory by surprise in class assignments worth a good portion of your grade. Tests are open notes and relatively easy.

She was one of the worst I have had at UConn. She didn't bring any energy to lectures and the information you were tested on was so obscure it was almost useless to even try and learn her material. Material was all over the place, incredibly boring, and again didn't care much about her students at all. If you can, take a different E course.

Don't take this class. Awful grading, terrible and boring lectures, professor isn't helpful nor interesting, horrible and specific tests, mandatory assignments during lectures, just don't take it. It's as if she wanted to make this class as unenjoyable as possible. One of the worst classes I've ever taken so far. Again, DON'T TAKE IT.

The content of this course was interesting, but the lectures were very very boring. All of the slides are posted online and she just reads from said slides the entire class. The class itself was not difficult if you keep up with notes, and weekly HW. Exams are also open note. There is a suggested textbook, but I never used it.

You can take one page of A4 size double-sided notes for the exam. There are homework every week, spot check attendance, other homework such as discussions and projects are not many (about 3 times a semester). There will be a curve in the exam.

Boring material made even more boring by a monotone lecture. Professor can also be very sarcastic and rude to students. Tests are nearly impossible to get an A on, even with a page of notes. There are completely redundant questions that have never been discussed on the tests for the seemingly sole purpose of preventing an A. Would not recommend.

Genuinely have not met a worse professor. Lectures cannot be followed, just goes over the slides and puts videos for the class. Even if you put effort into your answer for the weekly assignments she will take away points for the dumbest reasons possible. Super specific examples on exams. Really goes to show she does not care about teaching at all.

One word, bordem! You show up to class, she repeats the slides in a passive tone. 3 exams per year, pretty much makes up your whole grade. Tests cover around 70+ slides and 100s of pages in the textbook and asks for extremely specific stuff on the test like what treaty stopped the Bolivian war in a chapter which focused on weather.

She is the worst professor I've ever had. The way she teaches is so boring, she's passive aggressive, unhelpful, and rude. She will make comments and figure out ways to annoy her students on purpose. She sucks!

Weekly assignments weren't bad, but she started making class mandatory mid-semester because she was butt-hurt we wouldn't show up, even though she just read off the slides. Material is interesting, however her midterm exam was extremely difficult imo (the only exam for the class though). Not a bad professor really, but wouldn't take her again.
Terrible professor.

Took this for E credit, with very little interest, and it was actually relatively interesting material. Her lectures were awful though, she just read off powerpoint slides. Easy enough all semester, until the last few weeks she started doing in class assignments that didnt count toward grade. She clearly used these to subjectively grade final paper
bad.

Professor Thibeault is very passionate on what she lectures on. However, the lectures are very boring and monotone. The grade is based on weekly assignments which are not hard and a midterm exam which takes up a large portion of your grade and was pretty hard and a final paper 5-8 pages.

I expected this course to be much easier. It's not clear what to study for the exam. the study guide tells you to study everything in the textbook, lectures, quizzes, assignments. A lot of reading, gives extra credit. pearson subscription for the textbook and and the extra credit. she does show any excitement about the course. I don't recommend it.

She is an okay professor. Class was graded on weekly assignments (mc, fill in blanks, sometimes short answer submissions), one big midterm, and group project as final. She honestly made this class harder than it needed to be, as an E class. Midterm was on lockdown, had to take it in class, and had so many questions (but you could have paper notes).

This teacher is just very boring which makes it painful to attend lectures and hard to pay attention when you do. For a 1000-level gen ed it's wayy more work than I've had for comparable courses, and the exam is formatted as lockdown browser in class. 60 questions + an essay. If you want an easy gen ed, don't go with this. Choose comm or something

There is a lot of reading involved for this course, but she doesn't make geography better or worse. 1 semester project, weekly assignment and quiz, and some exams which were similar to the quizzes. Again emphasis on a lot of textbook reading but she does give the opportunity for some extra credit.
I took her class last semester and it was pretty easy. The test is straightforward if you studied.

For an online class, it was not too difficult. The work is straightforward. The only thing that will take time is probably the short assignments, but other than that, the work itself is organized. She's also accessible and responds to questions/emails relatively fast

Took this class completely asynchronous and was honestly one of the easiest, yet rewarding classes of the semester. She offers so many ways to improve your grade and although it was asynchronous, she was super accessible and regularly checked in with students. The material was interesting and the assignments weren't particularly difficult

i took this class online/asynchronous and prof always had organized materials/assignments. no lectures to watch, only things to read/watch and then one assignment and one quiz per week. open note. end of semester project instead of final, it's easy. perfect for gen ed requirement. you will use the book!
Class is not difficult. Two assignments per week and if you read the textbook and do the work, you will do very well.

Definitely not as bad as people are making her out to be... yeah maybe she doesn't make geography exciting, but doesn't make it more boring than it already is. The tests were open note but also weirdly difficult... as long as you make sure you do all the online quizzes and class participation, not THAT hard to get an A

Professor Thibeault is extremely caring and truly wants you to succeed. If you ever have any problems or concerns shes willing to help and is always accessible by email or after class. There are lots of grades and she even drops some to help improve your grade. There is a lot of material covered but as long as you do the work this class is great!
Took this class as a gened, it requires A LOT of reading. I literally spend more time on this class than some 3000 level engineering classes I'm taking alongside it.
I am a senior, and this is probably my least favorite class I have ever taken.

Taking her class in the spring semester of 2019 has been a terrible experience. I love geography and culture, this class does not do those studies justice. For a Dr. who knows many take this as a gen-ed, she assigns 2 week-long projects, 1 semester-long project, gives homework, ICAs, and makes you take weekly tests that are unjustly difficult.

Not easy. She's extremely unreasonably with the amount of hw you'll have. Weekly class work & chapter quizzes, 4 exams (not easy & not open notes), read a book, write a book review, & 3 projects (one you need to present). Lots of busy work. Takes time away from your actual important major classes, never have I had so much hw from just one class.

If you're considering taking this class, avoid it at all costs. I've never had to put in so much work for a 1000 level gen ed. Assigns way too many assignments for this class; 2 projects, 4 exams, a 3 pg paper, weekly online quizzes, and other weekly assignments. This class is not worth the time, find an easier class esp if you are in engineering.

She gives too many assignments that are unhelpful for the tests. I spend majority of my time doing her homework this semester. lectures are boring and everything is on the powerpoint and textbook. Test questions are extremely specific and really hard to study for, and she grades assignments strictly, hard to even get a B+, so annoyed for a gen-ed.

Literally the worst professor I've ever had. Her exams are impossible to do well on, even if you attend every single lecture because they are so specific. Extremely boring to listen to. would NOT recommend.

Expects us to have 4 different assignments done in the same week on top of other classes? I thought this would be a simple class to understand where countries are in the world but this is a more fact based class and more like history that explores the culture of different countries. I appreciate it, but I would've chosen another class if I could.
The course is taught well and is fair in terms of workload and expectations.

Worst teacher ever, material on tests is not even mentioned in class or the textbook, she gives zeros on assignments when her directions are extremely unclear. This class made up the majority of the homework and projects I had from all of my six classes
Not a very difficult class in terms of material difficulty, but she does assign a lot of work. It was my only class during the semester where I had something due every single week. She's alright.
Was not very helpful and not willing to work with you. Would not recommend taking her.

Very easy class, open notes exams, lectures aren't super interesting but can be sometimes. Weekly graded blackboard discussions and in-class assignments. Good extra credit opportunities, drops lowest exam, other classwork. Assignments weren't very difficult or time consuming

Jeanne is extremely nice and tries to get to know her students. She has a lot of outside that will help with your grade. Also, the tests are extremely easy since it's open book/notes. She also gives random extra credit points if you attend class on random days or if you participate in her lectures.

Jeanne is super nice and gives outside assignment to help boost your grade. Tests are kinda difficult but as long as you study and read the slides you should be good. Lectures are pretty boring and she's goes pretty quick through slides so bring a laptop!

I suggest only taking this class if you need it, or are interested in it. The lectures are boring but if you take good notes, read the slides and put effort in, you should do well. There are several take-home handouts and online quizzes that can help boost your grade if needed. I got C's on the exams but ended up with a B from the assignments.
Boring lectures and difficult exams. You have to go to class to get a decent grade due to participation questions she gives. Not a good class

You have to go to class, participations almost every class that count for point. It will bring your grade down a lot if you skip. Tests are pretty difficult but if you study a lot you tend to get in the 80s. Her homework assignments are long but she grades them pretty easily. Lectures are SO boring and I would not recommend this class as a gen-ed

Bontly was a great Phil professor. He only lost a point from me because of his day 1 lecture. He made a strong point about political neutrality in his lectures, but he did not follow through on this goal. Overall the class was easy and he made it simple to succeed, just pay attention to the instructions on exams and really try to have fun!

Bontly recently changed this course from his past years. All exams are in person, no notes. Midterm and final are on the harder side. There are many other phil 1104 professors who offer much easier courses so I would reccommend another professor. He is extremely unorganized and will not even make the exams until the night before.

Easy class, but Bontly is very disorganized. Homework and quiz schedule was unpredictable and things were announced last minute. Luckily things are graded by the TAs (mine extended deadlines by a week). Lots of readings that are necessary, but the concepts aren't too difficult. The grade is based on just a few assignments, which is very annoying.

Very disorganized which made this class stressful- slow grader, can't seem to stay on top of anything maybe partly bc he just became the EVST program director this year& neglects this class. Dis. sections are more helpful for those with a good TA; mine just made it more confusing- too bad bc I was actually excited about this subject but not anymore

Professor is a great person, but he contradicts himself a lot on his slides and lectures. Highly recommend going to the Friday discussions, they will discuss all the important things that will be on the exams. Going to lecture is not mandatory or necessary, I did not attend lecture often but I really paid attention in discussion section.

Lectures are not really mandatory at all but if you attend and pay attention you should know all of the material. Weekly quizzes/readings with study questions kind of suck. Not a lot of grades in the class and the midterm and final are a lot of the final grade. Lecture slides get posted after class and I recommend going to every discussion class

He was really unorganized, didn't finish making the tests until the morning of. Don't get me wrong, he's a great person and means well- but his teaching is not good. You have to attend lecture since the important information he says, isn't put on the slides. Only got a good grade because of my TA, but only Griffin, all the others sucked.

Terribly disorganized class. It's not difficult, but it felt like Prof Bontly was making everything up as he went. Homework will be mentioned in class on Tuesday but not posted until Thursday night/Friday morning, then due Monday night. Bontly's grading and assignments make this class more work than it is with other professors.

He is very unengaging with extremely boring lectures. Unnecessarily difficult for a required elective unrelated to our majors. has a midterm and a final only, and are very difficult. The other phil 1104 professors do not believe in grades whereas bontly does.

Bontly had very boring lectures, lot of words on the slides. Very disorganized. Changed the midterm and final multiple times. Midterm and final were closed book, closed note, written exams. Only graded on a few quizzes that were posted last minute, random homework posted 2 days before its due, midterm and final. Take another professor for 1104.

All of these positive reviews are from when Professor Bontly taught this course online. Now that it is in person, Thomas is very disorganized, very last minute, and very boring. Quizzes are online but very poorly worded and difficult. Exams are in person, closed-note, and also difficult. Find another professor.

This guy honestly isn't great. I was misled by his super positive reviews but this semester did not go well. As others have said he does not post the weekly schedule in a timely manner and often times you'll be left scrambling to finish a surprise assignment. His lectures might as well be a lullaby with the way he puts people to sleep.

Good lecturer, just horribly boring material. Puts together good study material for midterm and final. He posts readings to do, but as long as you take notes in lecture (slides and what he says/adds on) you don't have to do the readings. Discussion sections are a waste of time but required. Rarely posts homework and quizzes

Claims to have weekly schedule but doesn't post the homework on there half the time and they just appear a day or two before due. Beyond boring lectures but tbf he is a nice dude just no organization or clear train of thought. The internet will not help you with any part of his class. God I wish I could have back the hours I spent on this class

his 1104 tests are NO LONGER OPEN NOTE. I wish I knew that before taking this class. He is by far one of the most boring people I've ever heard speak. There are weekly readings, quizzes and 2 exams (midterm & final). the class is a gen ed so a lot of people teach it so TAKE SOMEONE ELSE

HATE this class. Lectures don't make sense, gives homework assignments very last minute. Also will mention homework in class, but won't post it on huskyct until the day before its due. This is a waste of my time and will tank my GPA.

He's the best. Super nice guy, a little unorganized BUT IT DOES NOT HURT YOU. It actually helps. The pace of the class is super relaxed and always discussion/lecture based. He explains the required readings for the week in class (& takes a few classes to do it). Take him if you want a relaxing complimentary course. I took PHIL of Science.

Prof. Bontly wasn't a bad teacher, but he also wasn't the greatest. He was sort of last minute with study guides or homework assignments, but, he was very lenient with due dates. The small quiz's weren't terrible since they were open note, but some were only 7 questions, which doesn't gave any room for error. His lectures were alright too.

This is probably the most boring class I have ever taken. But, you could not go to a single lecture and still get an A, as he posts all the slides online. There are lots of readings and online quizzes, but the exams were online, open note, and if you take notes they are very easy. He is caring and allows many opportunities to boost grade.

Prof Bontly is extremely easygoing and caring. Theres a lot to read and the readings are discussed in class. If you miss a few (or many) readings you can do well if you attend class and pay attention. He gives everyone an abundance of opportunities to get good grades and is very flexible with deadlines if you need it. Classes are discussion based.
Great lectures and really helps you engage in the content of the class.

Bontly is your typical run of the mill college prof. Listens to his students and takes their opinions into account. Lectures tell you everything you need to know for the exams. The readings aren't particularly hard and are kind of interesting, so it doesn't feel like too much work.
This class is the most boring class I have taken in my academic career. He gives tests in a philosophy class, which makes absolutely no sense. Effortless teaching

He is a very caring and understanding professor. He works with the students and gets their opinions on assignments and readings. He is very forgiving when it comes to personal life and hardships. However, his lectures are pretty boring and the class material itself is difficult (he does not do a good job of making it easier to understand).

Prof Bontly is kind & genuinely cares about his students' learning/mental health. He is forgiving with deadlines and takes student input seriously when deciding what content to teach during the semester. The class was discussion based and moved at the pace of the students, rather than having a strict schedule, which was nice but could be confusing.

Thomas Bontly is an amazing professor. He genuinely cares about his students and wants them to succeed. He gives people a window to take the midterm and final -usually three days - and dropped three out of the ten quizzes. If you think you may find philosophy boring, I highly recommend this class as it takes about relevant issues such as abortion.

I really liked Professor Bontly. He was super nice and caring toward students. He dropped 3/10 quizzes and gave us study guides that helped when doing the exams. Discussion sections were a bit dry. I stopped doing the readings halfway through, but the class/quizzes was still pretty easy. Not much essay writing either other than on exams.

Bontly is such a sweetheart and has tried to make this whole COVID thing very easy and understanding for us. There was only one quiz a week that was on one or two readings relevant to the lecture he gives. The exams focus on both these readings and the lectures, so I would try to go to the lectures when you can but you can miss a few and be fine.
