This is an interesting class and is a great class to take as a Gen Ed or otherwise as is pretty easy if you just pay attention in class and do the weekly readings. Prof Bontly speaks animatedly and clearly and connects well with students.

Prof Bontly is a great guy! He's very down to earth and despite our class being 200 students, there was a lot of discussion/participation from the class. He cares about the material and cracks a lot of jokes. He literally said "Ok, Boomer" when we were talking about climate change lol. Midterm and final were online so you already know that's a dub

Dr. Bontly is intelligent, well spoken, and helpful. He brings out the most interesting parts of philosophy. For exams he is very clear about expectations and he grades homework easily. I've had two philosophy classes with him (Philosophy and Social Ethics and Philosophy of Science) and both were the best ones I've taken. He even dresses well.

Bontly is a very nice guy but his lectures can be pretty dry at times. However, the material is presented well in class and it is basically an easy A if you show up and take notes. Readings are long but aren't mandatory in order to do well. Assignments and tests are fair. Would recommend taking his class to anyone.

Thomas is probably the most normal and down to earth of the PHIL professors. He assigns a lot of reading but explains all of them in class so you don't really have to do them. He is well respected and very knowledgable. He is a very fair grader. The tests are very fair and straight forward. If you attend class regularly, you will do well.

Great teacher - gives clear expectations and makes lecture very interesting. I don't care for philosophy at all as I find it very confusing, but Professor Bontly shows you a certain way of thinking and recognizing arguments that made it manageable for me
Lectures are mandatory because he puts his slides online but they are really interesting and he is a great public speaker and engages the lecture.

You can get away with skipping class and still doing well, he posts all the lecture slides online and reads off of them in class for the most part. Material is interesting and he knows his stuff well. He keeps it interesting and isn't too hard on the eyes.

He uses the lectures mostly. Interesting stuff. He knows his material well and he always offers to help. He holds review sessions before the exams and has given us opportunities to lift our grades. his powerpoints are organized and all uploaded online. theyre easy to go back to. good professor overall

I personally found that lectures were crucial to understanding the material. He claims that you need to read the assignments in order to pass exams, but he posts slides every week and they were detailed enough to understand the concepts well enough. Didn't really study and got an 80 on the midterm. He gives you the 8-9 essay questions in advance.

Philosophy is by no means an easy subject. Bontly made it a bit more enjoyable. It's clear he enjoys teaching, and he always posts slideshowshelpful handouts online. The discussion sections are really essential for understanding the class material better, and are usually pleasant enough to sit through. Would recommend for a gen-ed.
He knows what he's talking about and he's not boring. That being said he's not the best at directing discussions. Still, he's attractive. It all evens out. Take him!

Very easy class as long as you attend lecture (does not post information online very often). Studied for about an hour for the midterm and got a 95. Some days are a lot of thought-provoking discussion but some days are drawn out boring lectures.

Interesting topics, but boring lecture. Discussion was very helpful on recapping the information that I slept through in lecture. The articles and readings are useful when you're building your arguments during the exam. Exams are 40% multiple choice/short answer, 60% essay. If you study the example essay questions, you'll be good for the exams.

This class was rediculously hard for a non-major. I have never taken a philosophy course before and I found this to be terrible. Some of the material was interesting, but between the duel-professors (Bontley and Tabor) and the lack of a book, I found it pretty hard. Neither Bontley or Tabor succeed in teaching very effectively. Taught self material

Great teacher in discussion courses where its about 20-30 students, Had him for both Phil of Mind and PHIL 104 and Phil of Mind was so much better. The 20-30 student lecture was more of a discussion on the topic, in depth, interesting, great course. Would advise taking any of his courses.

I loved this teacher, but I never went to lecture. Sometimes he could be boring, but the discussion was always fun. He keeps the textbook use high to keep you interested in the class. GO TO HIS TEST REVIEWS!!!
really interesting class but the discuession section was pointless and actually just made me confused. i would definitely suggest going to class and doing the reading. the tests were all essays.

For any course he teaches, he is the easiest and best philosophy teacher UCONN has to offer. If you are a more serious philosophy student (meaning you want to have philosophy to be your career), you may benefit from another professor.
Easy enough class. He explains the subject matter very well. I found I didn't need to do the reading much if I took good enough notes. Recommended.
cool guy long winded

Don't go to lecture... i mean, it helps a little i guess, but all you have to do is spend some time on the essays he gives you. he tells you all the possible questions and you write them up then write them in class. a few of those, theres your grade. dont go to lecture...
Nice Guy, Easy to talk to, and he does the best with what he has...Phil 104 is a pretty boring class.
Detailed outlines on all readings make material so much easier to understand. Lectures aren't that great, but what lectures are.
Very smart, articulate, easy on the eyes
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

For a W this was a great class to take, for me, it was a break from all the STEM classes I take. Dr. Shemer makes it doable to succeed, as there are only 3 five page papers throughout the whole semester. TA is the one who does the grading, and Sevgi was amazing for me. Not terrible, essays can be a little time-consuming but it's a pretty doable W.

Prof. Shemer is a very interesting and engaging lecturer and the course material is very well laid out and easy to know what you're supposed to be doing. If you have an interest in human culture and development I would recommend taking this course even if you don't need the gen-ed requirement.

Professor Shemer is definitely a very smart, good professor. Three 5 Page papers plus some quizzes and reflections all In-class (attendance key). The TA however is slightly different, I was promised help with comments, feedback (even a google meet) on my papers, never received it at all, and then grilled me when graded, oh I wonder why it was bad?

This course was doable. All of the daily assignments were easy to complete and not time-consuming. We needed to read four books, but she posted slideshows with everything we needed to look for so the readings weren't too difficult. Professor Shemer was very nice and paced the class well. She no longer has open-note exams but they weren't very hard.

Nice professor, however there is a lot of homework and reading. There Is a paper due before every class and exams make up most of the grade. I took the class because reviews said the exams were online, but she switched them to in person and they are difficult. I would not recommend this class unless you really want to learn about Anthropology.
Awesome professor who cares about her students. No exams, easy quizzes, three 5 page papers. I would recommend taking this course with her for the W requirement.

Dr. Shemer is a very good professor who cares about her students. The class is good choice for the W requirement since there are only three 5-page essays and the quizzes are easy. You have to attend lecture for the 1-minute papers and go to discussion but for the requirements you satisfy I would say it is a good option. I wouldn't buy anything tho.

Prof. Shemer is by far the best professor I have had here at UCONN. While her class is reading and writing heavy, if you are genuinely interested in the topics she discusses the work feels easy-- just time consuming (its all just papers). Very helpful when it comes to feedback, has accommodations if needed, and is very understanding of extensions.

Very kind and tries to make lecture material engaging. Content is not too difficult and the W component (15 pages of writing) is split between 3 essays to make it slightly more manageable. Essays are 50% of the final grade, lecture attendance is 10%, and there is textbook reading w/ MC quizzes but you can just Ctrl+F through them. No exams.

My easiest class of the last semester. A course that commands basic recitation of the material & the most minuscule level of critical thinking to pass. I would warn that this class presupposes a certain worldview on social issues & anything contra that makes passing borderline impossible, but so long as you accept or feign those values, you're fine

Boring class (to me) but easy A. You do the most work in discussion which is just 3 5-page papers. Attendance does matter, you get a "one-minute" paper almost every class but it's only worth a small percentage of your grade. You can miss up to a couple without penalty. Nice class if you need an easy W

Easily one of the best professors I have had at UConn so far. Her course on race, ethnicity, and nationalism was so interesting and enlightening. I wish my friends here could have taken her class because I genuinely enjoyed it. Homework and quizzes were very manageable. Overall, she was a very fair grader.

Professor Shemer's class was not the most interesting, but it was an easy A. Quizzes were online and you could take them whenever you wanted, using notes. Papers were outlined with grading criteria and explanations were given if any points were taken off. Be sure to attend class because attendance counts in both lecture and discussion sections.

Professor Shemer always love to provide helps to her student and will not deduct you points with no reason. She followed the rubric to give you a clear understanding on how you did on your homework and why you get the grade. The course content is way more interesting than other course I've have. Really love it!

Prof. Shemer made a summer course somewhat enjoyable with the requirements being both simple to fulfill yet allowing for actually deepening my understanding of anthropology! ANTH 1000W summer course is very easy and would recommend for anyone willing to pay for it!

This course was way more interesting than I expected. Professor Shemer is an amazing lecturer and if you show up to class you will do well. Most of the essays are on class material or personal experience and quizzes are also easy. Extra credit is offered but you probably won't need it.

Great course, easy W. Do not even bother buying any of the textbooks, no need. Anything that is needed is given to you in discussion, including chapters from one of the mandatory textbooks. Plenty of extra credit opportunities, but you probably won't need them as long as you try on the papers. No exams, just group collaborative reviews.

Overall, she was a really sweet teacher. She has a lot of fieldwork and is genuinely interested in what she teaches. She does have a lot of reading required, but truthfully as long as you just go to class and take notes you can get away without reading any of the 4 books. It wasnt my favorite class personally, but I did well in it and it was easy.

I looked at the syllabus before every class and it was very clear what was due. I thought the papers were difficult to write from an anthropological perspective. However, by putting in the time and effort, you should be able to do well in this course. Besides the papers and textbook readings there is no outside work.

it's a w class, so 15 revised pages are required. the content was uninteresting and the readings were not necessary. her lectures and slides were bad, but that didn't matter bc the quizzes were easy. super boring, but easy a

One of the best lectures I have ever had. You do not need to show up to lectures, but she made the topics interesting. There are no midterms or finals, just online quizzes and chapter reviews you can do with others. The TAs were more focused on writing and helping with essays that were easy to bang out. Not a stressful class at all, easy A.

Professor Shemar is WONDERFUL I have never had a professor who was so kind, respectful, and so excellent at giving lectures. She does do a lot of group work which i loved in this class. The dialouge she nurtured was great. The readings can be tough but she did a great job of taking really difficult concepts and making them digestable. She's great

Professor Shemer is one of the best professors in the Anthropology Department. Endlessly encouraging and with a very clear grading criteria and clear assignments, it's a fantastic, super interesting class. She also has collaborative class notes which can be a total lifesaver during exams. Any class with her is a class worth taking.

I personally hate writing but the setup of this class definitely made it more bearable (rough drafts due a week before the finals to force you to not wait til last minute). She's very caring, understanding, accommodating, and gives engaging lectures.

Kind of boring to listen to, not really intriguing in her lectures. I stopped going like a month and a half in and only went to discussions since the major part was the writing part. Not the best but not the worst. Great TA.

I never attended lectures. All you have to do is go to the collab reviews (which if you show up you get a 100%), write discussion posts, and do the chapter quizzes(which are all on Quizlet) for the lecture portion. I did take the W course, which means you do have to attend discussion sections and write papers, but even those were reasonable.

Absolutely amazing professor. There are two tests throughout the semester but both are very easy if you show up to class and have a basic idea of what's going on. Your grade is also based on two essays which are really easy since she is a light grader. I actually really enjoyed the content of this course and it has opened my eyes in many new ways

The class was online/remote so I never saw her. Lectures were slides with some notes, then a MC quiz for each chapter. The essays weren't too hard, but make sure you follow the deadlines. You submit a rough draft first, then only the final draft is graded. Having a good TA is helpful for feedback.

Material is honestly not that interesting but Noga is a really nice professor and does her best to keep it engaging. Have to write one thing you learned and one thing you struggled with at the end of every class and it makes up a large portion of your grade. Two easy book reviews. Open note exams and curves.
This class is great for a gen ed and W credit. The papers are pretty easy, all things considered. The class requires a lot of reading the textbook, but it's not dense material.

If you need an easy W class, definitely take this. There's so little work outside of the 2 papers and even those aren't hard (works cited counts towards page requirement). If you're looking to save money, I don't really think the books are necessary unless you want to learn about the concepts in-depth. Super glad I took this.

Such a sweetheart! She gave excellent lectures and really cared for the students! Probably my most favorite anthropology professor by far... Great supplemental reading, discussions, and fun activities. I thought the exams were very fair and majority open ended which made it easier to prepare for. Very accessible in office hours and by email.

Super reasonable, online there were really not "lectures" (gave her a 4 because I literally never interacted with her all semester, only my TA who was awesome). Content was given in 2 week blocks so you could easily get ahead or just move along slowly. Learned a lot with not a lot of work. Only two papers, quizzes, and discussion posts.

My favorite professor at UConn. The lectures were so interesting and inspirational, really make you think! She is straightforward and even if you haven't understood the readings properly, she is very good at summarizing them in a way that make sense. Read a lot for sure, but worth it because engaging with the course will make it 10x better.

This is my second time taking anthro (needed it for the W). I absolutely loved her lectures. She made learning anthro easy. In addition, she breaks up the essays in a way that makes it very manageable for a W course. Take this class with her, you won't regret it. Just make sure you show up to discussion and lecture b/c there is participation points

Professor Shemer is awesome! Her exams are more than fair, and she is an excellent lecturer. She really cares about her students. Even when the class is being disruptive, she is incredibly patient and never looses her temper.

Her lectures are awesome! She really understands that most kids who take this class are not ANTH majors and really caters to that. She makes the coursework manageable and it is an easy class if you stay on top of everything.

She is so nice! The class was easy and interesting and we did not just sit and listen for 50 minutes. The class was interactive and we watched several interesting case studies. The exam review is very helpful, doesn't leave anything out, and the essays are not hard either. Overall a very interesting and nice class!

Professor Shemer is great! She makes her class very accessible to people of all majors and clarifies that at the very beginning of the class. Am a Stem major but I still felt that the content of the class was interesting and not really difficult as long as you go to class. 3 papers, weekly 1-2 pg "papers", going to class, and two tests.

Noga is such a great professor and lecturer!! She's passionate about the topics. Kind of a lot of work, but its to be expected because its a W course. Slides are vague, but she made the material interesting. I honestly thought this class was going to be so hard but if you do your work you'll be fine. I will say I didn't always read the book.
Interesting class, relatable lectures, and straightforward exams. She really makes the content interesting, while the exams are straight from homeworks and the textbook definitions.

Easily my favorite professor at UConn. The lectures are clear and super interesting/deep. I've had two classes with her and I honestly think about things she's said even after the semester ends. It sounds corny but her classes have shifted my worldview.
Lots of reading but they are good books with a lot of information, easy to understand what the professor needs and wants as far as class work. Wonderful and Kind.

Professor Shemer is easily one of the best professors I've had at UConn thus far. I have learned so much in this class, and I would say that it was pretty easy for a W course. You have a lot of opportunities to get good grades since there are 3 papers, weekly fieldwork assignments, and 2 exams. If you need an easy W course, take it with her!

Dr. Shemer is a wonderful professor who seems to really care about teaching. She is always very well prepared and clear. The was she teaches enables students to comprehend everything is a well throughout and clear way.
Just show up and pay attention. Fieldwork assignments aren't that bad but do get annoying at times. Exams weren't that bad. Very nice lady.
Professor Shemer is a wonderful woman. She gives a lot of great feedback and clearly cares about the topic. 10/10 rec! As long as you try and pay attention, you will do well!

There are a lot of readings assigned, but I have not read once for the class and I have done well on all my assignments. She reads right off the slides and posts them, so if you take the time to go over the slides you really do not need to go to class.
Professor Shemer was very clear and concise with her lectures and assignments. There were a lot of readings but most were very interesting and she helps you work through the texts during lecture.

The class is straightforward enough - it's basic introductory anthro, but with a research paper worth 40% of your grade (hence the W), two exams, and a journal. Really easy material, and Noga was a really nice lady willing to help you through every aspect of the writing process. The only work outside of class should be for the paper

Shemer is a great lecturer if you're interested in the subject. I really enjoyed taking this class, but there's a lot of reading material so if you don't like reading then don't take it. All in all, interesting class, easy short quizzes, and presentation at the end of the semester.
at UCONN she was decent but harsh with emails
Holy guacamole, what a great class!

The absolute worst professor I have ever had during my three years at UCONN. She is extremely rude in emails and refused to provide any extra help. I knew the course wasn't going to be easy. That was not the issue. It was the blatant refusal to clarify material or answer questions. Horrible experience.

Landin is one of the most cold-hearted people I have ever met. She genuinely does not give a damn about a student's success She will make the student feel bad and make them sound ungrateful by mentioning many times that she put a lot of helpers in the course You are solely graded on exams and if you ask for extra credit she will turn into Godzilla.

Don't plan on taking this class if you want to succeed, the majority of your grade is determined through the heavily dense exams and you aren't able to use scrap paper! When reaching out for help all she has to avail is rudeness and lack of empathy for students who don't grasp the material right away. Do not take

Class was an absolute nightmare, beyond disorganized, and unfair. She is a very cold person and rude in her emails. It was so bad that I no longer felt comfortable asking for help. She never planned any lessons, no SI, no TA, no office hours. Exams were poor for students not allowed paper. The lab is A LOT OF WORK. Class is a major disappointment.

Rude, has an attitude when you email her about clarifying something sometimes. She is well aware this class is difficult but instead of wanting to see her students succeed, she puts more obstacles. She didnt have much of clear grading scale. Worse professor I ever had.

Dr. Landin poorly lays out her expectations, offers no help to students and gives nasty remarks to anyone asking for clarification or help. she suspects every student of being a cheater and treats her students as such. Dr. Landin will make your life hell and not give a damn if you have something to say about it. Avoid if you can.

She is not clear what her grading scale is and is very rude to students over email. She called classmates of mine "Stupid" and never offered to help us learn. She also has no sympathy and lab is a joke depending on your TA. This is the first time she is teaching MCB 2000 and she really disappointed the students. CURVE

Challenging but fair for MCB 2000. Very dense lectures and exams that require lots of memorization, but are overall straightforward. Class is well organized and she emphasizes what she wants you to know. Lab is time-consuming with reports due every week but TA's grade easily. Overall solid choice.

It's been a while, but it still holds. Prof. Landin is, well, mediocre. The lab part was nice and did fairly well there but the Taq writeup was brutal and the rest of the class was very hard. This is coming from the CDC's notetaker, so I wrote all of my notes twice. She's okay, but certainly not a miracle-worker like some of the other ratings say.

Great Class, interesting, overall a great experience. Do not, under any circumstances, take this class for an A. She averages the three exam grades and is weighted 75 percent of your final grade and 25 percent is the lab grade. Even if you get all 90, you still end up with an A-. And trust me you will not get all 90.

The class is tough. You really need to work for a good grade, and Landin will tell you EXACTLY how to do that. The lectures are dense, but they're essential to the exams so go to class! Go to office hours if you need help - she's open to helping students learn when not pressed for time. Memorize the pathways early on and never forget them!
Really fun class we learned about cells in it it was very good the tests weren't bad either
Class is cake. Some people struggle because they don't try hard enough, but you barely have to try at all. Just go to class occasionally and you'll pass...

Don't listen to the naysayers, Professor Landin is one of UCONN's shining stars. I've been over the moon in her class the entire semester. She knows when to be hands on, but will also give you space if that's what you need. Professor Landin even brought in Milky Ways before exams!

Agree with the fake ratings. I look her course a few years ago. Dr. Landin's lectures were not helpful in preparing for exams, and I found that looking at and memorizing her slides were more beneficial than actually learning the material. Her exams reinforce memorization rather than application and knowledge, which was not helpful in my career.

This is the only course I've taken at UConn where I felt it was impossible to earn an A or B even with significant studying (20+ hours / week). The material is not difficult, but the pacing is very difficult to keep up with. Dr. Landin does not teach well, and the exams are written survey questions of minor details in the slides. Take with Bruno.

Listen up, all the reviews on here are very very fake. Exam 1 average 78%, Exam 2 average 56%, exam 3 average 60%. The exams are extremely difficult and will leave you traumatized. There is NO CURVE. All these people here who got As, no way. There are only 2 people with As in her class of 110+. No way difficulty is rated 1 too. Take with Bruno.
Nicest lady. helped me do good
I took class many moons ago. Judith teach me to be good man. To be best biochemist I can be. Thank you Judith for sharing your wisdom with me. Very humbling. Thank you.

Great professor. takes the time to get to know here students by their names! Get to know her and ask herself. Exams are easy per se, but ton of material! be prepared to know all the details. Funny, and there is review at the beginning of every single class. Use this to your advantage. Exams are open-ended. A lot of work required. Rewarding class!
nice!

There's a reason that it's 5 credits. Professor Landin really cares about her students and the material. Exams are all open ended and she's very nit picky about word choice when grading. Lab is also detail oriented but doesn't provide you with a lot of guidance unless you specifically ask your TA what's expected in the lab report.
Reads off the slides. Laughs a lot and grimaces

Advanced Biochem lab was like learning to do real research. Dr. Landin is such an amazing professor (I had her for 3010 too). She is always willing to go the extra mile to help her students succeed, and she is truly a gem in the MCB dept. Structured labs followed by an independent project with a formal research paper and poster. Loved it.
Often shows episodes of The Magic School Bus and relates it to the stuff we're doing in class. What a great lady!
Incredible! Making Uconn Great Again!
So good. great lady. Very high energy. Wants to make UCONN great again
sometimes the tests that she would give to the class were very tough but it's easy to do well if you study and she's so nice and helpful that you will have no problem!
Good class, gooder professor
She's a nice lady who loves to see you succeed her class is so nice i really like it and i really had so much fun with it and her and all my classmates!
Honestly, Biochem is pretty easy already, but Professor Landin makes it even easier. Highly recommend for an interesting and easy A!
Really great teacher! Sometimes, if she's teaching on the first floor, she'll come into the classroom though the window!!! Hahaha she always knows how to make her students laugh!

She's absolutely fantastic! She makes biochemistry so interesting, and she really cares about her students. If she doesn't know the answer to a question, she'll take the time to look up the answer and get back to you. Awesome professor!

Material can be tricky, but she's a nice lady and is the mother of an awful lot of memes. I heard once that she had over 100,000 comment karma on le Reddit which is quite an accomplishment. Highly recommend. P.S. Be sure to ask "When does the narwhal bacon?" on the first day. She'll love it.

Dr. Landin is an inspirational professor who cares for her students and really goes above and beyond to make sure everyone understands the content. Biochemistry is a dense topic, but Judith makes the course very manageable. Her exams are all written out (which is to your advantage) and they were all very fair and graded fairly. Best prof at UConn!
Taught me how to do Biochem but more importantly how to be a good person.

Wow is all I can say. Dr. Landin is by far the best professor I have had at UConn. Biochemistry is a VERY dense course and she teaches it extremely well. If you're looking to learn biochemistry, Dr. Landin is the way to go. Lab portion of the course can be difficult but is not impossible. Would definitely take again.
Tough but fair. what a great lady

tbh talks way too much. can be really intimidating because she laughs at everything (even questions). good teacher though. cares a lot about students. nice person. the class is a lot of work, but i would take it again in a heartbeat. i really like dr. landin. she just took some getting used to.
what an epic memer

When I first signed up for biochem, I was concerned that this class would be one of the most difficult at uconn. Gee whiz I was wrong... Judith is like the mother that I never had and does her best to help you understand the material. If you pay attention and try to participate, this class should be an easy A. She even brought in cookies once!!

Like sometimes I'd go to class and it was good, but sometimes it was jut great. Kind of hard and there were a bunch of lectures but she told a lot of pretty okay jokes which made the lectures fly by. Not a lot of homework and it was pretty easy when there was. Tests were okay if you put the work in. Judith believes in A quality work, so work hard.
Pretty good
Judith is a fox
Great professor and more importantly a great person. Thank you for the opportunity to take your class Judith Landin.

I liked this class way more than I expected to. i learned so much and it was all important stuff going on in the world instead of boring book knowledge. landin was so into the material too, she was great and if you follow her directions closely, youll do good.

Judith is a real gem. Not the easiest material but she tries her hardest to make it fun and exciting. I took this class for fun (as an English major), so I was a little behind the rest of the students, but with a bit of hard work I managed to pull off an A!

Landin-Good teacher, willing to help Exams-Difficult but doable. Open response. Know the details for processespathways Lab-Not bad but sometimes tedious. Read lab prior, do the reports, you should be good. Tips-Focus on slides when studying, and attend lectures. She asksanswers questions that keep you on track. Know the details for each topic.

Oh my god she is LITERALLY the best professor I ever had. Never had I thought I would enjoy biochem this much. Judith is truly a delight. She's there for you whenever you need her and she makes the class a breeze to pass. Would recommend as a GPA booster if you're interested in biochem at all.

Wonderful professor with a great personality. There are weekly readings that she walks you through in class, nothing too bad. Class is graded on 3 essays (500 words max) and a digital research project and there is the opportunity for extra credit for doing discussion posts. Incredibly caring and understanding if you can't meet a deadline.

Asynchronous (at least during COVID-19). Lectures analyze and discuss books for their contribution to science. Six 100-200pg books, 3 Essays total for the semester, 1 digital research project. Uses Facebook to host research projects. No Final Exam. If something comes up, let her know asap. Try to read/skim the material and/or know the main pts.

Sweet and hilarious. Gives an exam for the study guide that if you follow, youre all good to go. Response exercises are essentially pop quizzes to check youre up-to-date with the latest reading, drops your lowest grade. My one thing is shes somewhat hard on the essays she assigns. Very helpful during office hours.

Lots of reading, obviously. She gives the class schedule, so you know what you'll need to read, and when you need to read it. Lectures are just her reading the poems or novels, and explaining them along the way. You don't really need to go to class if you keep up with the readings. Exams are simple, essays are simple. Good class

Loved Professor Rumbo! She was so kind and funny, and her exams/essays are really easy as long as you read the plays and come to class to get the notes. She's really understanding if you can't reach a deadline or need some help as well. I really appreciate how sweet and intelligent she was, and I hope to take more classes from her in future years!

Proffesor Rumbo is a solid choice for British Lit courses 1 and 2. I enjoyed all of her classes because she made the material so accessible to me! She was funny, understanding, and very knowledgeable in this field. The homework is very manageable, and each quiz/test has the same format each time so you know what to expect. Prof Rumbo is great!

Rumbo is extremely boring, just reads passages out loud and listens to herself speak. She gives zero feedback on essays and is extremely unapproachable. Quizzes and exams are the same format, but can be difficult with very specific questions. She uses the same test format every time, which is nice once you get used to it.

I sincerely enjoyed this class so much! Rumbo is a witty teacher who is very knowledgable in this field. You enter class and she has classical music playing! She reads each passage assigned with you and explains what's happening (it's SUPER helpful). There is a midterm, a final, about 7ish quizzes total, and one/two 2 page essay about every month.
A lot of reading but nothing difficult. Professor Rumbo is a good teacher and a really nice professor. Always adds a couple jokes and videos into class to make lectures more interesting

She is such a nice lady, this class is interesting at times but there is a lot of reading. You're graded on like two essays, a presentation, and midterm/final, but the essays/presentation are done at your discretion and time availability. Lectures are sometimes boring, but it's a good Gen Ed class.

As long as you actually read the plays and do some minimal studying this class isn't very difficult. She is extremely friendly, accessible and flexible when you talk to her. As long as you keep her informed she is usually willing to accommodate you. She is also absolutely hysterical, so there's a plus.

Class is tough. Lots of reading to stay on top of. Four response papers to the plays, which she grades really rigorously. One essay that's also graded harsh. The exams aren't overly hard but the quotes killed me. They're very specific so you really need to grasp the plays. Talked to her in office hours and she isn't very friendly but still helpful.

Really loved this class. She's so passionate it makes you enjoy coming at learning about Chaucer, etc. She explains the readings and the tests are straight forward. Easy A if you attend, participation not required. Starts classes with historical music.

Overall, I like Rebecca but the class is more difficult than I expected. On exams, you need to define quotes and they are very specific so you need to really grasp the plays you read. The multiple choice and fill in the blank parts are easy. Very tough grader on papers but she's willing to help. Not a bad professor, just put in the work needed.

She is such a nice lady, honestly. When you meet with her, she asks about your life and actually takes interest. She goes over details of the books being read in depth during class so it's easy to stay on track. She's not the easiest essay grader but she's not terrible & gives good feedback so if you actually try a bit, you can get at least an A-

Dr. Rumbo is very sweet and kind! She is a tough grader when it comes to papers, but she allows you to rewrite one of the two papers she assigns. She helped me a great deal when it came to writing, since I am a science major and writing was never my strongest subject. Her exams are very easy. Just remember the terms and look over your notes!

This woman is amazing! You don't have to participate (unless you choose to do so, then it's extra credit), the one paper you write is only 4 pages, and she really makes herself available to help you with it. The tests and quizzes are E A S Y I got a 99 on the final and I studied the night before. She's truly interested in the material too.
Great prof, Brit Lit was a breeze. Exams were not very hard at all. You just have to go over her study guide. She does take attendance but I would skip occasionally and she didn't really care.

I loved her! I barely went to class, but when I did she would always catch me up (if i asked). She gives extra credit and you can tell she wants the best for her students. She actually teaches too! Theres a lot of reading for the class but it's not boring. Extra points for participating but its as easy as speaking once and handing in a notecard.

Prof Rumbo is great! There is reading for drama but you just have to read background and the plays themselves. She offers extra credit and all you need to study for the exam is the one page study guide of terms and ideas she makes. she shows a lot of videos so its pretty entertaining. Shes funny too

This lady can really teach. There's so much pointless baloney in classes nowadays. Between clickers, expensive ass books, online homework, and ridiculous reading assignments; questioning your purpose in life, is a daily occurrence for the average college student. This class is an exception. It's interesting, direct, and entertaining. Take it.

I liked Mrs. Rumbo. Easy to understand, all class consists of is her talking about the readings, and the occasional in-class writing just analyzing a reading. The readings are all short passages, no annoying novels or anything. Gives fair tests and you have the opportunity to succeed in the class. She takes attendance so go to class.

Rebecca is great. She has a great sense of humor and is passionate on Dramatic Arts. It can get a little boring because she talks most of the time but she is VERY helpful. Especially when it comes to writing. I recommend this class!
Hilarious and straightforward. Do the readings and go to class and you'll do well. Fair grader and offers extra credit

Lectures were boring, not many opportunities for class participation at all. She's very nice and will gladly help clarify exam material during office hours. The study guides she gives are extremely helpful; memorize them and you'll get an A. The three out of six papers you have to do are also easy. The readings aren't long at all.

Sweet woman, exams are cake just make sure you memorize the study guide. Three exams, and two papers for the semester and she lets you rewrite if you receive a low grade. Has some in class writing responses on works assigned for class. Relatively easy, definitely GPA booster
Probably one of the worst english professors i have had. Very harsh grader on papers.
Awful. She gives paper prompts and then gives you a D for not responding to the prompt... even if you follow the directions exactly. Hard grader, extremely boring, and mouthy to boot. STAY AWAY!
Pretty straight forward. If you can sit through her lectures and take notes, the exams are simple. She's a very tough grader on papers, so if you want a definite A, go to the writing center.

Professor Rumbo is so clear and makes this class fun, enjoyable and easy. I truly looked forward to attending her class :) If you need to fulfill a literature requirement definitely take a class with her, she rocks!

rumbo is so nice! shes a really good teacher. we had to meet with her after every rough draft of each paper so she could talk to us about how to fix them, it was really helpful. she's like the best honors english teacher, definitely take her if you're going to take ENGL 3800!
Had her for short story. Easy professor who clarified work. Short papers to write, but she lets you rewrite if you get C or lower. Easy class if you do the readings and go to class! She's amazing.

Quizzes and exams were the exact same format-- same length and eveything. she can be confusing in that there have been times when my classmates and I have put word for word what she said in class on exams and she said it was "going too far" and marked it wrong... doesnt interact with class either. just talks at you. boring.
Grades fairly. Easy. Doing the assignments=good grade. Offered extra credit.

One of the easiest professors I've had. The exams were fair and easy, and the papers we had to write were graded based on if you handed them in or not. I emailed her with a couple of questions and she was really nice. In class, she showed scenes from movies on the plays. I definitely recommend her! Easy gen ed.

Fantastic professor! Picks some really cool stories and has interesting discussions about them. Very easy exams, some easy short papers. Class is relaxed and she has a good sense of humor. This is an enjoyable English class!

I've had Rumbo for two classes and they have both been great. Very fair and easy grader, decent amount of reading but not too much work. She is one of the most helpful profs I've ever had, really cares about students. She tells a lot of jokes in class and they're pretty funny if your paying attention

She was SUPER easy. I never got lower than a 95 on one of her exams. Her 2-page max response papers were graded just on whether or not you turned it in. Maybe it was because it was an intro class, though. She was really nice & you could tell that she loved the subj. She showed a bunch of movie clips from the Shakespeare plays, which was a change.
very easy class. offers plenty of opportunities for extra credit. do hw assignments. i recommend taking the course with a friend so you won't be too bored

She is a really good teacher and she made me slightly more interested in literature. She does tutorials for every essay you write where you hand in a rough draft and she tells you what you did wrong and how you can improve your writing. She is also very helpful with letting freshman know about different resources on campus.

Great class for a gen ed, actually fairly interesting too. I would recommend going, because although I know it seems simple she puts everything you're going to need to know on overheads etc. Read the plays once over, and take notes during class. Make note cards or something, study the night before, get an A.
Very boring class but easy.

Very easy class if you just attend a majority of the classes and take notes...she tells exactly what is on the quizzes and tests...really just pay attention to what she says...awesome teacher and makes the material interesting.

Barely went to 1/2 the classes and still passed with a C. The theater is so dark, and the seats are so comfy, and the topic is so boring, I just kept passing out. Either that or I'd read the paper. Too easy to cheat on tests. Too far to walk at 8am.

I enjoyed this class, especially the frequent video clips that really illustrated her points. Read the assigned readings, spend a little time studying, attend the lectures and you'll do ok on the multiple choice tests. Fair, helpful and accomodating.
No Comments
No Comments
lectures get boring, often find myself dozing off
The class on the most part sucked....the tests were fairly simple but the class and the attitude of the teacher was lukewarm...not really positive or negative.
You want to find the ultimate way to punish 400 students? Stick them in Drama 101 with Dr.Rumbo.

professors.name: Therese Smith
professors.department: computer science and electrical engineering department

reviews.review: Although an absolutely caring and kind person, this professor is not a good teacher. The resources for the class are extremely unorganized, confusing and hard to find. Assignment objectives unclear. Her lectures are often ineffective and not engaging, leading many students to stop attending them. Struggles to effectively teach necessary concepts.
Well first off she barely teaches you about the material she gives out. Her lectures are difficult to follow. I wouldn't recommend taking her unless you have programming background.
She is very caring, study the review tests you can get a good grade. Always meet her for extra credit opportunities.

I had Therese at CCSU. She does not take attendance and I skipped about half the classes and still passed with an A. If your good with computers and can teach yourself coding, it's pretty easy, but learning from her is difficult. She knows what she's doing, but you will not be able to learn from her. The hardest part is making your own website.

She always made herself available to answer questions outside of class. She offered extra credit to students that felt they should have done better on the exam. Her lectures are a little dry, but that's because no one asked questions and she was reading/interacting with the slides. A solid B+ professor who I think will improve over time.

Therese genuinely cares about students. Sometimes office hours are a hit or miss. At times, I felt like the grades were pulled out of a hat. The grading breakdown for the class changed verbally several times, so no one knew the breakdown. YOU NEED THE BOOK TO SURVIVE. She's a nice person and very smart, but she really needs to work on teaching.

Therese is one of the smartest professors I've had, she was able to answer any question I ever had, and at any time of the day. Her office hours are invaluable. CSE 2102 is hard because it's hard to teach students who have never dealt with big projects, big data, or software engineering roles. She wants you to learn from personal experiences.

Tries to be helpful and cares about her students. She is also learning and was teaching some tough subjects with not enough teaching experience so it did not well. Gave good grades to students that never came to class and that did no work. Some only took the final exam and got an A. 75% of her reviews are in a 5 day span? Seems a tad fishy.

She was a decent professor. It was a summer course so things were more relaxed. I found her method of teaching helpful since she tried to focus on each student individually. In the end, you were able to do a project on whatever you were interested in as long as it met certain criteria. This approach probably wouldn't work during the year.

People on here being kinda hard, shes pretty new to being a full time professor but getting better with every class. I can honestly say she cares about you and your grading unlike some other cse professor. She is extremely busy but always makes time if you need it. In my experience i have got As-B+ and that she is easy then other cse professors
Fairest grader ever

Therese cares immensely about your success in her class, and she's a very intelligent professor. If you're ever confused about something, make sure you ask about it because she'll be willing to help, but otherwise she'll just keep on going and you'll definitely be lost.

Probably the worst professor I've had the pleasure of dealing with at UConn. I strongly advise against having her as a professor. Her handling of my CSE 2100 class was appalling and the department head actually had to intervene.

Had as a TA for my CSE1729 lab. Very willing to help walk you through code to make sure you understand WHY programs output what they do, yet never does your code outright. Committed to making sure you understand the fundamental problem-solving skills that are needed for programming.
Terrible. Couldn't control the class. Everyone was talking over her. She couldn't decide on what to do. Grading is arbitrary.

Therese is super nice. This class was the easiest thing in the world and you still walk out of it learning a lot. She uses personal experience to better convey lectures and you just have to participate a bit. If you don't, she'll even ask you to say a tad bit so you get your participation credit. Borderline no homework. Quick final presentation.

I was emailed by Therese to leave a rating on RateMyProfessor (what professor has ever done this before?) So I will give my honest rating. Therese is not a good professor at all. She is a petty person that doesn't know how to properly teach Computer Science. I didn't attend 2100 more than 3 times (including exams) and still received an A. Terrible.
She is great. Not too strict and doesn't go exactly by the book. She really just cares that her students learn. If they learn, they get nice grades. :)
Don't you find it strange that there is a sudden traffic on 6/29 for good rating for Therese... Months after school let out... she's not a good student... My parents taught me to never tell a lie
A great course. I really enjoy it. The instructor allowed us to have opportunities to earn points back on exams. Contents require you to put efforts into it.

I am not the brightest bulb in the box. 2500 with Therese was not easy at all. However, Therese was extremely helpful and accessible. Her lectures were difficult, but she made many fun analogies that still makes me laugh when I think about them (horse proofs, anyone??). Hands down, sweetest, kindest, most caring CS prof in the entire department!

Therese was one of the better people in UConn's engineering department. Some professors don't care whether or not you understand the material, but Therese will spend hours outside of class with you until you understand it. She came in on Saturday morning to help me 1-on-1 more than once, and she has study sessions outside of the lecture hours.
She teaches in a way where you are expected to have read and learned material on your own. She's extremely accessible to students, and spends a great deal of time helping them.

Therese Smith was one of my favorite teachers, she managed to solicit interest and passion in her students while keeping the coursework challenging in a healthy way. As long as you have a drive to do well in her class and she can see that, she will always give you a chance to put in work and redeem yourself.

I had Therese for Into to Software Engineering. She didn't teach the main lecture, she was the professor for our main coding project, which we worked on throughout the semester. She is very enthusiastic about what she does, and you can tell she cares about her students. She was very helpful, and I remember that she graded pretty nicely. Recommended

For Data Structures and Algorithms, the key to passing is actually reading the book ahead of class. This class is naturally difficult because it introduces a way of programming most students have never encountered before, and probably won't get unless they read the code in the book. Once you get it, it's pretty easy to pass with a good grade.

Class was pretty easy. Show up for participation points and had to give a long presentation at the end. Ethics is a dry topic but each group had to cover a different event or topic regarding the field so it was at least varied. Therese is a very understanding professor and didn't try to make the 1 credit course more than it should be.

Therese cares very much about her students. Slides were verbose. Lecture was good but the material is confusing and using the book is recommended (its very short). Tests were a bit long but the questions and grading were both fair.

I had taken a summer class with Professor Smith quite some time ago, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I learned a lot and the final project was one of my favorites! We were given creative freedom so I chose to make a game. Though I didn't get to finish it by the end of the course, I put a lot of effort into it and got a final grade of an A.
She cares a lot about students, but is sub-par at best at teaching.

Here's the gist: Therese cares about her students, and wants you to succeed I had her for the lab section of 2102. She spent every minute of lab helping someone. I learned significantly more in her lab section than I did in the lecture part of the course. She's prompt and clear with email replies, and makes herself available to students.

Therese pushes her students to learn to the best of their ability. Expect a lot of learning to be done on your own outside of class, but expect to come out of the class knowing much more than you did before and feeling challenged. If you work hard, you will receive a good grade and learn a lot, Therese really knows her stuff and is very helpful!!
She is bad!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! dont take her class!!!!!!!!!!!!!! all the stuff that she taught in the class has nothing to do with EXAM!!!!!!!!!

Therese did her best to both inspire interest in the subject matter and to provide a venue to discuss and organize projects with the students. I came out of the course with a small but very honest image of software engineering and the related fields, and had an overall very positive experience, though I didn't perform to my usual standard.

Professor Smith led our lab section well, and although she was sometimes hard to reach in class, this was no fault of her own, as she tended to dedicate the most time to the students who needed it the most.

Therese really cares about her students. She puts a lot of effort into her course, and tries to design it to be accessible and give room for students to excel. Though her lectures may leave something to be desired, she's very accessible in her office hours, and willing to entertain any form of question about the coursework and beyond.

Therese was very passionate about what she was teaching and provided many examples. She assumed a high level understanding of the material and taught the difficult intricacies of it during lectures. Make sure to come prepared to class with a basic understanding of what will be taught and you will be able to easily follow along.
I thought this professor was very knowledgeable on the subject and she also had on the job and real life knowledge of the material.
Really cares about her students and does EVERYTHING she can to help them pass.
Was always willing to help out with your code, regardless of the issue.

Theresa did an amazing job on this class. Its a real difficult course to teach. Its very dry and it makes it hard time to focus. Given that she communicated and delivered the material effectively. One of the better professors I'll had. The course was difficult as it will be with any professor.
Expect to get destroyed on exams. And if you go to her Office Hours, you might be treated rudely. The Curve is the only savior in this course.

Wants her students to do well, and does almost all she can to help. The most valuable resources you have in the class are, her office hours, textbook, and class time. Where if you have a question about what's being taught at the moment, please ask it, and bring your A-game to lecture (stay focused). It'll save you pain later.
Grading makes no sense
Comprehending material in this course was very difficult as there was so much disorganization. Exams are very difficult and questions don't make sense. Avoid if possible.
She is really nice person and really helpful.

Therese wants to give everyone an A. But this DOES NOT mean that you can not do the work and study and still get an A. She is there 100% for students who need extra help. She also provides ample opportunity for extra credit. These classes are challenging, but take advantage of her office hours, read the text, and ASK QUESTIONS and you will do well!
Good luck.

Grading is very unclear and inconsistent. There was no semblance of a syllabus for the class I took, and students' final grades were somehow still being adjusted arbitrarily even into January. Would not recommend. I had her for data structures, which I understand is a very crucial fundamental CS class, and I do not believe I comprehend it at all

If you can avoid taking her classes, do so. Her assignments and lectures are both very vague. The questions on the exams were very confusing. The only thing that really mattered in the class were her practice exams. The one plus about the class is that it's open book and notes on all her exams.

Was a great TA! Took her class because I thought she'd be a good professor. I was wrong. The pace of the class is so fast, faster than the other class of the same subject. Its ridiculous. Extremely confusing, and grading is not clear. Despite all this, I can tell she really wants her students to learn. But unfortunately, just read the textbook.

Atrocious. No guidance on assignments, spews professionally written code at you and expects complete mastery. No gap between 1102 and 2100, trying to comprehend her lectures is as useless as being thrown into a pit of lava with an ice cube. Zero grading criteria, avoid at all costs.
She is the worst. Nothing is clear, she is ambiguous, verbose, and convoluted. She expects us to be java prodigies and is one of those people who craves feedback and then doesn't utilize it.

I'm not sure how to accurately rate the professor to be honest. Easy A, I guess(?) The lectures seriously feel like they were slapped together on his drive to campus, they are WILD, all over the place, too long, and way off topic most of the time. This class will be fine if you don't mind doing all the work yourself in your own time. Easy tests.

Deepak is a great professor and he's pretty funny. The class is challenging but not impossible, my advice would be to make sure you always complete the online homework. Also, the exams could be a bit difficult but I recommend re-doing the iclickers and doing the practice exam he posts. Plus he gives a bunch of partial credit on the exams

Super cool guy. Exams were fairly easy. Final was actually kind of hard. He try's his best to keep everyone engaged in the subject and is pretty funny. Labs were easy and graded fairly. Overall, I love this guy. Sad to see him not teach Physics II

Deepak's class isn't bad, the tests can be a little challenging but going through his iClicker questions and the practice exam will prepare you for it. He does not record his lectures, and there is iClicker that counts towards your participation. The lab is pretty chill, but it is long. Not a bad class, he lets you make your notesheet for the exam.

My experience with Dr. Sainju was poor. I'm a 3.7-3.8 GPA student and ended with an A in the class. His teaching style is awful, HW/lab questions seemed out of the blue, and the whole class felt like it was put together in about 5 minutes. If you're planning on taking the MCAT, I would recommend another professor who actually teaches the material.

He kept lectures interesting even if you don't like physics. The homework was online each week and wasn't too terrible, but it is poorly organized; missed one and he let me make it up but wasn't very understanding. Overall, he is a good professor for physics and gave study guides for exams and the exams weren't too bad; you can bring a note sheet.

He was a really good professor, he understood that we had lives out of class. Was very lenient and accessible. Tests are hard but the study guide helps a lot. Lab was great and definitely helped my grade. I would take his class again tbh.

Deepak truly cares about his students. He explains things a little too fast sometimes but his slides are super helpful. Average for exams was an 89. Go to class to get easy participation points. Tutorial problems were tough but lab was a nice grade booster. Do not skip class and do not fall behind.

If you want an easy A in physics take it with Deepak. If you can't solve a single problem but you write the formula and your thoughts you'll get a lot of partial credit. Expected a 30 on the first exam, got an 85. Homework once a week that is graded by accuracy but it gives you multiple tries.

Deepak's class is very hard especially if you have no background in physics but he is a great guy. His lectures are engaging and he always highlights the most important equations. His exams are very difficult but he gives you so many points just for trying. Very hard class taught by a great guy, highly recommend

He's so passionate and he always reviews the most important concepts. His analogies always gets a chuckle from the class. Attendance not mandatory, but definitely go because there's a lot of clicker questions and tutorial questions.

Genuinely never expected to enjoy Physics, but he is so funny and entertaining! He gives so much partial credit and the exams are HARD but it helps. He wants us to succeed. Only downside (and a pretty big one) is that he doesn't record lectures - the concepts are very difficult and sometimes I feel like I need to rewatch the lecture but I can't.

Sometimes this class was really hard to follow but I really liked how he would rewrite/go over main ideas. He is a really sweet professor and cares a lot about teaching well and reexplaining concepts. Definitely go to class because the slides are not super helpful and the clicker questions are big.

deepak is a very sweet professor and it's not hard to do well in his class but lab really matters and the hw does too it counts same % as an exam. The hw sometimes grades weird so aim for the high 90's. I got the grade I got because the syllabus was a bit confusing with the clicker points. Attendance is mandatory and it's done through clicker.
Overall this was a great class. Lectures were clear and the tests were fair. Professor Sainju does a great job of explaining the material and answering any questions.

Easy grader who actually cares about his students. The lectures can be confusing sometimes, but he makes sure to clarify and note the number of resources available online. Solid professor and would take his course again.

Deepak is one of the most genuine professors ever. Physics is not easy but he made the lectures followable. Would take it again with Deepak. Got to class to get easy clicker and tutorial points. Exam questions are problems you've seen before in class or homework.

Physics is a difficult subject, but Deepak made it manageable. His lectures were great and he would write on the board so you knew exactly what part of the powerpoint was important. He also provided lots of example problems. Exams were fair and you got to make your own formula/notes sheet to use while taking them. His humor made lectures engaging.

Deepak is the man. If you're taking physics 1 I recommend taking it with this stud. He always comes to class full of energy and jokes. The class only consists of 3 exams and homework, but you get to make an equation sheet and the exams are similar to clicker questions during lecture.

Professor Sainju made a tough 8 am harder by hard to follow lectures. I am not sure who is making the slides for this class, but they are awful and have way too much information per page. He seems like a nice guy outside of class though.

As someone that hates physics, I anticipated this being my hardest class( for reference I had to take three other lab sciences) but Deepak made this class a breeze for me. A very kind man who wants his students to pass. He can be a bit hard to follow along but as long as you put in work outside class you'll be fine. The lab was also very easy.

Deepak is a legend. Never thought I would enjoy going to an 8am lecture but he always made them fun and entertaining. He's hard to follow sometimes but the exams are fair as long as you know how to do the problems on the practice exams.

Professor Sainju is awesome, lectures were really fun, and he seemed to love teaching physics to the students in the class, and the class had a direct and simple grading syllabus. Though physics was hard for me, Professor Sainju made the class really interesting & manageable, and would often connect physics with real-life instances.

I have always hated physics with a passion but I grew to actually enjoy it this past semester. He always writes down important concepts and equations on the board which makes it easy to follow along. Exams weren't too bad either. He is also such a nice guy and wants everyone to do well. Definitely take physics with him if you get the chance!

Horrible professor. Fell behind and his lectures are all over the place. Had to basically teach myself. His exams were so fragmented from his material. Only bright side was his curves were great and he had a balanced syllabus grading wise. Easy grade but felt like it was borderline a waste of time, energy, and effort.

Deepak wasn't a bad professor but taught his material really slow. We were behind other classes so labs were confusing at times. Class was super boring and I never felt like I learned from class. Exams were hard but graded with ease.
v understanding prof, lets you bring 2 sided cheat sheets to exams and the final, easy labs and hw

Professor Sainju is a solid professor. He throws in jokes to make class interesting and often explains topics pretty well. Class is based off clicker participation, 3 exams (the final was a partner final and you get a handmade cheat sheet for all exams), homework, lab portion (which is so boring and I didn't have the best TA). Don't fall behind.

This class is very hard in general, but he made it manageable. If you are a visual learner he is a great professor for you. Class goes quick and tests are hard, luckily tests dont make up a huge portion of your grade. He cares about his students and wants all of us to succeed. He is one of the few professors who made me engaged and want to learn.

Honestly, I hated physics with a passion. This class is my least favorite class this semester, but Prof. Sainju explained the concepts pretty well. He does have a thick accent, but still pretty understandable. He can be pretty funny sometimes. Although I wished he would do more practice problems to help us prepare for the exams. Solid choice!

Professor Sainju moves around a lot and it can be difficult to follow him sometimes, especially for the difficulty of the class (the topics are already pretty difficult to understand on their own). Despite this I found him to be enjoyable, but wouldn't take him again.

Rushes through a pretty boring lecture, hard to stay focused on. He misses a-lot of class which can put you behind in the lab portion. Nothing graded on time, tests are fairly easy just study. Allows a cheat sheet for formulas only so take advantage of this opportunity.

Best professor I've had so far. He is so kind and understanding and extremely accommodating. Homework, quizzes, and exams were all on mastering physics. Quizzes and exams were open note and really straightforward. I wish I could take 1202 with him.

Sainju is extremely nice & a great choice for those who arent a fan of physics. His tests are very fair. Mastering Physics homework was sometimes a pain. You will have to learn the material yourself. Lab was ABSOLUTELY PAINFUL online especially with a bad TA

Does clicker questions during lecture, 4 exams, 5 quizzes and the lowest grade is dropped, and homework all mastering physics. His exams are very simple and not designed to trick you. Deepak is a really nice guy and wants his students to do well. He does his best to make lecture thorough and interesting, and likes to crack jokes!

The best professor I have had so far. This was an online sync class this semester. Mastering Physics site was used for homework, quizzes, and exams. Was an easy class but I really learned so much. Professor Sainju breaks down problems during class and never puts questions on exams that are far off from classwork/homework. 10/10 recommend
Sainju is a very caring and understanding professor especially during online classes. He gives out clicker questions and uses mastering physics for homework and exams. Overall great professor

This guy is average at best. He has a lot of energy and you can see that he likes the material, but he doesn't communicate these hard topics very well. He moves really fast during lectures, so you have to pay close attention, and he doesn't give you enough time to copy his notes down. He also takes a really long time to return grades. Lots of HW.

I would not recommend Deepak for studio physics 1502. I know he has great reviews for previous classes but this past semester he was not a good teacher at all. Don't get me wrong, he's a great guy but he does not know how to lecture physics in a way that is easily comprehended. I definitely started learning more after I start teaching myself.

Really nice guy. Wants everyone to pass his class. His exams are a little weird. They usually have two open eneded questions and then 5 multiple choice. The multiple choice is strictly right or wrong, no partial credit so if you bomb those then your exam grade will suffer. He allows cheat sheets which really help. Read the book and use the formulas

Deepak is a great guy and an even better professor. Most people taking 1502Q struggle a lot, but he made it clear from the beginning he just wanted us to learn the material. Fair grader, fair content, and very accessible outside of class. Exams were fair and the group project was fun too. Want to pass 1502? Take it with Deepak. He's the man.

The issue of this class isn't Deepak, its flipitphysics. That software is the worst for student learning, and the physics professor force it on students. Deepak himself is great lecturer and very funny. His exams are conceptually a little strange, but the calculations behind them when you figure it out aren't too hard. Lab helps your grade a ton.

It's exactly how you would expect physics to be but I personally thought my high school physics class was MUCH harder. Also, he literally teaches everything that you need to know for the exam and the lab is SO EASY to get an A but it is just VERY boring. There is one group exam which will help you out with the other bad grades you might get.

Tests are fair and he allows a cheat sheet for equations and concepts. If you don't want to read the powerpoints/book, go to lecture and he'll go over everything and write the important equations on the board for you to copy down. Does clicker questions, and will always go over them afterward to make sure everyone understands.

You are probably better off teaching the subject to yourself. His accent makes some things more confusing. His exam are generally straightforward though and as long as you sweat some hours on the online HW you should be fine. Also, a 89.5% is a B+

I loved Professor Sainju. He is super nice and accommodating. He let us bring in a cheat sheet for our exams and the exams themselves weren't that bad either. There was an extra credit project that was worth a decent chunk of our final grade too. Just show up to class, do the clicker questions and you should be fine. Lab was a joke.

Yo Deepak is THE MAN. He does have a thick accent, but he does make his long lectures funny. His office hours are useful if you do struggle with physics (it helped me a lot). Overall, I would have loved to take 1202 with this man because he was that good of a professor.

the reason I rated him kinda difficult is because I find physics itself hard, so if you are like me; im not only considering the professor (whom is very nice and will make sure you understand) but content of the class in my level of difficulty. He will push off homework if you let him know in advance you will be busy. Group project at end& iclicker

Awesome guy. He does not try to trick you with exam questions, gives a group project, and one group exam. He cracks jokes during lecture and tries to make it interesting. Clear slide notes that are posted regularly. Also, he allows a formula sheet for exams. Yeah, take Deepak.

Pretty simple class. You get a cheat sheet for every exam and the second exam is a partner exam. There's a lot of extra credit on the exams and you can get over 100%. The only reason I didn't get an A in the class is because the online homework is super annoying and I had the worst TA who was a super nite picky grader compared to the other TAs.
Easy class, simple test and Great professor, take this class if you are a BA student and try to finish the CA 3,.

There's a good amount of group work: a project and a test you take with a partner, but they really help your grade more than hurt it. The exams are really straight forward and follow the homework questions or lecture notes exactly. Lectures definitely important to go to even though it's a little boring, but overall an easy A.

This is probably one of the easiest general physics courses you can take. Our first exam average was a 95%, he allowed you to bring in an equations cheat sheet for every exam, and one of our exams he let us take in pairs. His lectures weren't the most exciting but he's a nice guy and it was a fairly enjoyable class.

I enjoyed being in this professors class. He uses PowerPoints for lecture with clicker questions that are for credit. However, he writes a lot on the board and gives lots of examples. I used the PowerPoint if I didnt go to class or to get equations for homework/exams. We were allowed cheat sheets for each of the 3 exams (double sided).

Professor Magley was a really caring professor who knew how to lecture to students. This course is more like a business course through a psychological lens, so if you're not interested in business then maybe this isn't the course for you. Despite the fact that all of her exams were open note, you had to look up most of the answers online.

Lectures are boring, stopped attending them midway through the semester, but probably could have stopped earlier since the lecture material rarely lined up with the tests/hw anyway. The professor herself is very caring and knowledgable, it's just the material that is uninteresting (imo). Overall, easy class to pass, not all that engaging though.

Always going on personal rants and trying to inspire us when all we want is to understand the material so we can pass. Quizzes never seem to line up with what was covered in lecture and are fairly difficult even though they are open note. You have to attend lecture because she doesn't upload her lecture notes online.
All she does is go on tangents and then the tests never match up with the minimal material that is actually covered in class. Her grading is not consistent or clear.

I honestly really only went to this class like 2 times the whole semester. She gives a total of 5 homework and 6 quizzes. The lowest 2 grades get dropped and the quizzes are all online and open note. The final is also like the quizzes.

She goes on so many tangents that the class could probably be done in half the time if she didn't. The tests are confusing and had material she didn't cover in class. The TA did a better job teaching the one time she was away and I actually had way more notes than usual. She doesn't post slides so if you miss class you have no idea what happened.

One of the worst classes i've ever taken. The exams are completely different than the lecture slides, and even if you go to lectures, you wont be able to apply anything learned to the actual exams. She rambles on and on and goes on tangents that have nothing to do with the material. Also never responds to emails.

do not take her. she does not upload slides, and she just rambles the whole class. the topic is already not interesting for most, and they way she teaches is the least engaging i've experienced. tests are actually difficult and homeworks are much more difficult than needed. im sure shes nice but this class is horrid.

DO NOT TAKE HER CLASS!!! Doesn't upload any slides so have to go to class. Tests are harder than needed and not all correct answers are straightforward. Not all answers are in the slides or textbook as well so it was a guessing game at times. Doesn't reply to emails and no accommodation for covid. Feared for my grade all semester.

Does not accommodate students with COVID and refuses to share slides or even give information about missed lectures. Does not reply to emails either, only to tell you that she's sorry you have COVID, but she doesn't share her slides.

The course itself is interesting but DO NOT TAKE with Professor Magley. Tests are difficult even though she drops the lowest 2. She will not answer your emails, will not provide notes, lecture recordings, or any assistance at all if you miss a class or are struggling with the material. AVOID!!

Seems like a nice lady, but not that engaging of a professor. The lectures were usually a snooze-fest and she would sometimes go off on random tangents that nobody cared about. The tests were pretty difficult despite being open note and open book as well. The only positive was her dropping the lowest homework and test grades.

I actually found this class very interesting, and found myself not wanting lecture to end. The quizzes aren't awful they're open note/book they just have a short time limit. Homework is easy as long as you take notes. Get to drop 2 lowest quiz and homework grades. Not accessible out of class. Go to class and take notes and you're good.

This professor is not accommodating to students at all, does not reply to emails for weeks. Do not take this course unless you want to be met with an unsupportive professor who clearly does not care about you at all.
If you need help she wont respond or attempt to accommodate you. Not the type of professor that sympathizes or even understands personal matters.

Professor Magley is an excellent professor who cares about her students and wants them to succeed. The exams were not too bad as long as you study for them. Her office hours hep you understand concepts and ask good questions. She also offers extra credit to help you boost your grade. This class was interesting so we can apply concepts to our life.

Considering the class topic, I feel that Prof. Magley could've handled the content better. There was def a need for stronger trigger warnings, &she was somewhat insensitive in her personal comments. The textbook was outdated/included some offensive terminology. Online lectures took forever to get thru w her personal comments &were posted days late.

She is a good person, very nice and understanding. I feel her class would be good if it was in person. She was very unorganized. For Tuesday's class, she sometimes doesn't post the lecture till 2 am Wednesday morning. The test dates on the syllabus aren't the actual test dates she announces the exams two days before. But it is an easy A tho

Easy class- 6 online tests (you drop your 2 lowest) and 5 easy homework assignments. You have to go to class since she doesn't post her slides online. She was very flexible and understanding when everything went online because of covid-19.

Didn't want to take this class, but had to bc it was the only PSYC course that fit into my schedule.
