Stay away from this class unless you are a Poli Sci major and can't avoid taking it - it is a GPA buster. You are expect to have hundreds of pages of text memorized for exams you are given next to no information about. I spent more time studying for the midterm in this class than all my other ones combined and it was still my lowest grade.
For a 1000 level political science class, this is hard. Coming from a second year STEM major, toughest gen ed taken. Hands down. Pop quizzes on very minute details, lots of reading.

Reading is an absolute must. Acing the class is virtually impossible unless you ace all of his extremely arbitrary pop quizzes on information that is randomly selected to be quizzed on, and if you have the time to read 40 page chapters of a generic textbook before every class
Does not prepare you for the exams. No study guide for tests that require you to know lots of information. His lectures are bad and pop quizzes are often on the reading.
SOOOO boring. Drones on and on for lectures. WAY too many pop quizzes that MURDERED my grade--even though I did the readings!! Hands down the WORST class I've EVER taken.

I had the pleasure of having Paul Harrison for Intro to American Politics. I found his lectures to cover the stuff that was on the exams only, which saved myself a bunch of unnecessary BS with studying. Make friends with your neighbor in the class and visit Paul during office hours and you'll do just fine. Him and his TA's were very approachable.
His lectures do not cover what will be on the exams. Avoid if you can!

Professor Herrnson is a very nice guy with a great heart, but his lectures are vague and typically not important for the tests. The tests are mostly based on the chapters of reading so as long as you keep up with the readings, an A is not too hard. Discussion is helpful as well

If you are interested in going into the book publishing industry, this would be a worthwhile class to take. Other than that, I'd avoid it. . The professor can be harsh and sometimes flat out rude in feedback sessions, and often brings up uncomfortable and unrelated topics in class. Don't take this class unless you have a thick skin with writing.

HORRIBLE! He is both rude and condescending, will not give helpful feedback while also refusing to acknowledge other perspectives. Way too much work for a 3 credit class, and he grades tough. He'll talk about inappropriate topics carelessly, often starting things like "How can I say this without getting fired?". Avoid at ALL COSTS.
Way more than 3 credit or even W class workload!!! Professor has a habit of tangents and is difficult to speak to. Course content is pretty mind numbing as well. Nothing redeemable.

Professor Grossman is a frustrating educator with a limited scope of students' capabilities or interests. He will forcibly include group projects (even in asynchronous format, so good luck) - provides 0 help when students (understandably) refuse to do this. His feedback is rude, and even with an A in his class, I would never take him again.
This professor was horrible. 10 discussion board posts a week, and there was a lot of reading. Lots and lots of reading. Plus, his suggestions, and advice on assignments were not helpful.
10+ hours a week of readings outside of class on top of other assignments. too much for a 3 credit class

Very dismissive when you tell him you have a problem. I took AMST 2276W and it was a nightmare. Reading heavy and class is just him putting his own words to what you said then agreeing with himself. I tried emailing for help and the harder life got the less he would answer. I had a death in the family and he didn't answer and still hasn't

Assigned readings are incredibly heavy, often find I have to dedicate way more time than this class should require. Gives poor feedback on papers, leaves very few comments and random question marks. Very dismissive to student comments during class.

Don't not take this professor or class if you are looking for a manageable A. This professor was rude and didn't provide helpful feedback on the essays. Doesn't update grade book. 10 discussion post must be due within 2 days and an 8-10 paper within 1 week. Not open minded to student ideas. Save yourself 1 extra life by not taking this class.

Leigh is a caring professor but his courses are difficult. You will probably spent 4-5 hours a week reading in this class and he doesn't use huskyct. You wont really know your course grade till the middle of the semester and the very end. He is considerate about covid and being sick but other excuses for missing class not so much.

Professor Grossman, while very knowledgeable, doesn't explain what he means when he references your wrongdoings, he more so just comes across as rude. He has a tendency to not listen to anyone's ideas other than his own. I'll admit he taught me a lot, he was just very difficult to deal with as a teacher.

9 novels. Graded primarily on 2 papers- 1 analysis, 1 creative. Prof. Grossman gives some of the best feedback, but I didn't realize going into it that the course would be so focused on developing one's own creative writing style. Not the best W course for a non-author, or someone who doesn't love genre fiction. Visits from authors were cool.

I would never take a class with this professor again. He was unbelievably pretentious, rude, and ignorant of student ideas. He leaves the grade book empty so you have no clue how you're doing. Assigns superfluous readings. I do not feel I have learned anything from this course. I dreaded this class and having to interact with him. Does not listen.

The worst professor I've ever had, told him I was struggling with the subject and required extra help and he said "its not that hard... I dont get why". We had a new book to read every week usually upwards of 200 pages. He even expected us to read 700 page book in one week, and then be able to write an 8 page paper about it by the next week

Lots of reading. Pretentious and name dropping. Willing to help out with projects/essays though. Group project was very unclear and hard to figure out what he actually wanted; it took about 3 office hours trips per group to get something "workable." Definitely not an easy class but you will see improvement in your writing if you put effort in.

Incredibly pretentious. Will go on and on during lectures about his interpretations of the story when it's your class time. Does not give good feed back on your paper. Get ready to not receive your papers back for weeks. Would not recommend if you're looking for an easy Gen Ed.

This class was a lot of work, but it was 100% worth it. Grossman gave very detailed feedback, and was always happy to linger after class or to sit down with you outside of class to go more in depth. This class is definitely geared towards aspiring authors. Grossman definitely expects a lot, but if you put in the time he will always meet halfway.

He allows for you to revise your essays and gives extensive feedback. His lectures are very interesting and he picks out readings that are far from boring. However, if you are shy like I was or have a propensity to skip class, your grade will definitely suffer. Heavily participation based. Overall, a good experience and a well-balanced class.

Not to be dramatic, but I would rather be hit by a bus every day for the rest of my life than take this professor again. He is pretentious, not interested in helping you learn or excel, not open to any opinion other than his own, and a HUGE name-dropper. Comments on papers are often just, "really?" and other completely unhelpful sentences. Just no.
Dear God, please save yourself. Don't ever, and I mean EVER take this class unless you want to be reading all day in and all day out.

Professor Grossman's class can be very boring. The information in his publishing course comes from his glory days and is out dated. If you are looking for help publishing your work join a student org on campus instead. Grossman's course is very easy to pass so don't be tricked into thinking the course is difficult.

The great thing about this course is being able to network with other students who want to work in the publishing industry. Class is very boring. Very difficult to ask Professor questions. The Key to passing this class is going online and doing all of the work by yourself.

if you are looking for a minimal work gen ed, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. This class was extremely time consuming and he is a really tough grader. He does care about his students but this class is a lot of work for a content area 1 class. Spare yourself the effort if you are looking for an easy gen ed class.

If you read the readings, participate in class, and put effort into the essays you will pass easily. He gives good feedback and really cares about the students. Wants everyone to succeed in everything they're doing regardless of whether they're english majors or not.

He is very thoughtful and considerate of student's needs, and even spent countless hours talking with me during his office hours. Very helpful - cannot stress enough. He expects participation and good work, but he will work with you to get it there if you care enough - really only take a course with him if you genuinely care about the subject.

Such a nice person, cares about his students. He's tough on your work because he wants to see you do well. Other students in the class critique your work as well. It can be a challenge to sit back and listen to all the negative/positive things about your work, but it's good feedback. A great preparation course for future writers.

He loves publishing and he wants everyone to too, but he wants to show the reality of it. He has speakers which show the variety of jobs and personalities in publishing. He is v willing to meet to talk about the projects, go over resumes and help apply for jobs. You have to be selfish, ask questions, make appointments, go to class, BE INTERESTED.
Very Easy Online Class if you like to read

He assigned more reading than I could keep up with, but I managed to get an A without doing all of it.... The class is hard - I was one of two A's - but if you actually like sci-fi, do some of the work, and show up to class you'll do okay. I like sci-fi, but even I was a little put off by how overly dorky some of the class was...

Grossman's class was enjoyable. Really lectured based, w. 1 slideshow project and a proposal assignment you wrote multiple drafts of. He does tend to repeat himself concerning his experiences in the publishing industry. Hosted interesting guest speakers. Grades fairly. Just show up on time, don't skip, and ask questions.

Very interested in his own status within the larger writing community and a perpetual name-dropper. With that said, he knows what he's talking about when he's not off on a winding tangent. Don't take it if you don't like to read. Show up to class and say what he wants to hear and you'll get an A and learn something about writing.
Do not take if you dont like to read or write. Very intensive. name drops- suprisingly doesnt assign his own novels.

Pompous, a name dropper. I wanted to learn about publishing, not become a published writer, he heard this and has skewered me on every assignment since. He tells everyone how terrible they are, and gradually gives them higher grades to make him feel like a better instructor. Worst professor ever.

He is an awful teacher, I have learned nothing in his class. He goes off on tangents and never focuses on the topic planned for class. He thinks everyone wants to be a writer so makes you do work as if your being published. Name drops. Never thinks he is wrong, so dont eve try to argue.

Took Publishing with him, and LOVED the course. He really knows what he's talking about, and he's really helpful in trying to give students the tools/info they need to actually GET publishing jobs. His grading was very fair and generous too; he let us hand in ungraded drafts of everything and gave helpful comments for revision. Would take again!
No Comments

He's very arrogant and doesn't really care about the lives of students outside of the classroom. He is very unclear on what he wants and tries to hold students to the same level of accomplished writers

He admits that he picks favorites, and if you're unlucky enough not to be one (for whatever reason) you might as well drop the course, because no amount of work on your part will change it. Grades rather harshly, and is the most arrogant professor I have ever met. He loves to talk about himself more than the course material.

despite what everyone here has already said: this guy is smart. he knows what he's talking about and is a great teacher. compare him to ann charters and you'll realize this guy is EXCELLENT teacher and knows what he's talking about (not saying charaters doesn't but she's not a good instructor)

the discussions are completely worthless and irrelevant, you don't actually learn anything in them; if you do the reading you could never go to discussion and still get the same grade. He also rants and namedrops authors he knows and basically just sucks as far as a teacher.

just avoid this class. Unless you are really interested in the subject you will be bored as all hell and pissed at your grades. He is a tough grader and when he explains to you why you got your grade he never gives you any advice that could help in the future. He says himself that he rarely gives out A's. His personality sucks too.

I took his class because it was offered online in the summer. I had taken a previous class of his for only 1 day before dropping because was so pompous. Thought I'd try again - BIG MISTAKE. Only talks about himself, assigns a ridiculous amount of reading (and I'm an ENGLISH major!), doesn't help you understand material and favors certain students.

Biast teacher picks favorites and grades refect it, asks completely unclear questions, reading load is 12 books from 100-900 pages each, ****ed choice of books, costantantly talks about his writing career or something that you can learn in another class he teaches but doesn't want to get into it.
I took two of his classes and got A's both times... and I'm an accounting major.

Stay away if you want a good grade. This person only believes in giving an 'A' grade if you are better than he is, which at this level how many college students are? Poor teaching is rivaled only by his biased grading. Don't take.

Very easy gen ed while also interesting. I took it as a summer online course; there is no midterm or final. Do the readings and take notes, and the quizzes will be easy. She also grades easily; as long as you do the assignments, you should get an A. Accepts late work and gives full credit. She gives good feedback and wants all her students to pass.

Prof Smith is awesome, super easy if you get her. Lectures are not required and are recorded so you don't have to go, and she posts the lecture slides. The quizzes right now are either you can take in class or take at home online until midnight on that day. Very easy, in the notes and do the readings. No midterm or final. 10/10 gen ed.

She posts all her slides so going to lecture isn't necessary but discussion is. Exams & quizzes are online, no lockdown. They aren't on quizlet but if you take notes on the slides you're fine. Other than that, you'll have assignments for every module but most of the time if you go to discussion, u finish it there in small groups so it's easy.

I choose this class for the gen-ed, but it convinced me to double major in Anthro. She's SO nice. Seriously. Radiates good energy. All tests are open-book. Some short assignments in discussion, but graded easily. All lectures were recorded.

This semester, I had Professor Smith for ANTH 3706, and ANTH 1500. She was easily my favorite professor, and truly cared about her students and work. Prof. Smith prompted me to double major in Anthropology, something I would be hesitant to pursue on my own. Additionally, her understanding was amazing, and she helped me get through a difficult time.

Alexia is a great professor and genuinely loves her students. Shes super caring and sweet, and is always willing to explain lecture material or anything you might not understand. I loved the class I took with her.

Professor Smith oozes enthusiasm in the material she teaches. Her lectures are livestreamed and posted online, although her lectures are a joy to sit through. Quizzes are open note and open book. The assignments are simple and straightforward. Easy class to do well in.

I absolutely loved this class!! Lectures are live streamed, quizzes are open book and open note, and there isn't a lot of assignments. The only downside is you have to show up to your discussion section or you get a zero for that day. The discussion sections are really interesting though so I didn't want to miss them. I 100% recommend this course!!

This professor is so kind, caring and overall AMAZING! She is super helpful if you have any confusion. Lectures can be a lot, but also interesting. Labs for this class also helped, and assignments were relatively easy, but time consuming. 2 papers, a exam, and participation in labs are main grade factors. She's helpful and provides good feedback.

I really loved Dr. Smith. The class itself is not difficult, but it remains incredibly interesting because she is such a good lecturer. To do well, just show up to the lectures, take good enough notes to refer back to them, skim through the readings, and take the open note quizzes with those materials in mind. Would recommend this class!
Great teacher, no midterms, no final (final was a open notes/google quiz on a unit). All quizzes/tests are open notes/google

One of the best profs I've had, despite never even seeing her face. Her class was super easy--all of the quizzes were multiple choice and open note, and we had weekly discussion posts that only required a few sentences response. The material was incredibly interesting and covered a wide range. Some modules were a bit heavy but still manageable :)
Clearly very passionate about the material, lots of easy assignments, no final, its a really easy class to do well in.

Honestly, I though this class was kind of hard for a gen ed. Normally big lectures have multiple choice tests but her tests have a short/long answer section that asks really specific questions. And, the weekly quizzes are short answer too which required a lot of memorization. Her study guides are too broad. She is nice tho and wants you to do good.

Dr. Smith is an extremely kind and caring professor! Weekly quizzes in discussion make up 30% of the grade but they are very easy and she tells you exactly what is going to be on them. Tests cover a lot of material and are pretty specific so they require a lot of memorization but if you study EVERYTHING on the study guide you should be fine!!

Alexia Smith cares a lot about her students and wants them all to succeed. The class material can be very boring at times, but as long as you study the lecture slides (which are all posted online), then you will do well on exams and quizzes. There is no textbook which is a huge plus.

Alexia was a great prof but as someone who struggles with memorization based exams, I had to study a lot just to do decently on them. Class could be interesting at times, boring at others. The weekly quizzes make up a higher percentage of the grade then the exams and are pretty easy, so if you keep up on studying for them you will do fine.

Alexia is very caring. She has weekly quizes held on fridays during discussion which are peice of cake because she tells you exactly what's going to be in the quizes. Her grading is fair. The tests can be easy if you have great memorization skills. There are lot of names, dates, and location and can be tricky but after all she is amazing.

Alexia cares about her students and truly wants everyone to do well. It is made very clear what will be on the weekly quizzes and the exams. Study guides and lecture outlines are posted. Basically, do the work and you will do fine. Very interesting class.

I never went to class. She puts the lecture slides and a recorded version on her page if you were interested. The weekly Friday quizzes are either cake or awful and they count for 30% of your grade. If you study the quiz topics every Wednesday, for the Friday quiz. You're pretty set. The tests were straight forward. LOTS of MEMORIZATION

This class will bore you right to sleep. Alexia's lectures are long and boring. There are only 3 tests that your overall grade depends on along with 30% of your quiz average. Quizzes tend to be very easy, but tests are tricky and a pain. She gives horrible study guides. Rather than telling you what is on the exam she wants you to study EVERYTHING.

Among the worst possible teacher here at UConn. Grading is unfair. Quizzes are easy, but the exams are impossible. You only have 3 tests worth 65% of your grade. Quizzes were 30%. You must go to class and memorize the little details not in lecture outlines and the study guides are not helpful at all. Overall, very boring class and hard grader.

Alexia sets up the course in a way that is almost impossible to fail. The 3 exams are not cumulative, weekly quizzes are 30% of your grade and she practically gives you the questions in class, she records her lectures and puts them online with audio, as well as posts an outline of each lecture in document form. No textbook and exams are super easy.

Dr. Smith is an amazing woman. Incredibly kind, and very willing to talk with her students. Lectures are straight forward, but cover a lot of material. Make sure you do the weekly readings. Weekly quizzes are very easy, and a good grade booster. Exams are also very easy. Overall wonderful class, and a wonderful woman. Highly recommend!
She posts outlines online so showing up to class is optional. Tests are a breeze if you study from the study guide she posts. It's an easy class.

She is very knowledgeable. There is a lot of material to cover so lecture and time periods move very fast. The information is interesting. She tells you extactly what is on the 3 exams. There are easy weekly quizzes in discussion that count as 30% of the grade. Just look over notes. I definitely recommend taking this class with Alexia.

I took her class fall semester and I got an A. I think she means well but head this warning: her tests can be challenging. The quizzes which are thirty percent are cake but follow the study guides and study hard for the tests because the first test surprised me with the expectation of knowledge for a gen ed course.

Very nice and well spoken professor. Doesnt make class harder than it needs to be. But there is a lot of memorization. To get an A you need to go to class, type all the notes on her slides and anything else she says in particular & study those notes. She doesn't post her notes. Discussion quizzes are easy. Study notes from past 2 or 3 lectures.

Very kind and caring person, genuinely wants her students to do well. This course is basically all memorization, which was my downfall as I am not good at it, book was rarely used, as she posts lecture outlines online. Weekly quizzes can help and are fairly easy, topics given the class beforehand. Would recommend this as a CA 4int gen ed course.

Best professor by far. She truly does care about her students and it's an easy class. I didn't buy the book and I didn't need to. If you just study the class notes, and outlines on HuskyCt you'll pass no problem. The material is pretty cool too.
It was a very easy class and as long as you study the notes she puts online for the quizzes and tests you will do fine. She wants to see everyone do well and tries to help anyone who is struggling.

Alexia is the sweetest woman who genuinely cares about her students. She provides weekly outlines that covers material discussed in class. Weekly quizzes can help make or break your grade but they are super easy. There is a lot of memorization involved, be prepared for that. She provided study guides for exams LEARN THESE. Overal great professor.

She's genuinely nice and friendly, and her TAs are usually just as nice and helpful. The course is one of the most interesting geneds at UConn. Memorization and good quiz grades are the key to success. I had (literally) perfect test grades, but a 70 Quiz average- giving me a B+in the class unfortunately. That part was a bit frustrating.

Requires a bit more memorization than a typical gen ed, but it is still possible to get a good grade. Don't waste your money on the textbook, it's not necessary. Most lecture material is posted on the weekly outline. Professor is a truly nice woman.
Great teacher, not a very hard class. She will post notes online and all you have to do is study those to ace the quizes.

She is pretty good. She has a good heart. Exams are very easy if you just study lecture notes, but attend lecture because she tells you what you need to know for each week's quiz, which are usually fairly simple. She uses the textbook a little bit for exams, so when she specifically mentions to read something, read it and take very basic notes.

Truly nice woman, she really wants you to do well. Is honest when she is unsure of something, and will look up the correct answer for you. If you attend lecture and read the lecture outlines/textbook, the tests are extremely easy. Great class, great professor, loved it!

Very nice lady who is passionate about her field of study. The quizzes and exams are mostly off the notes, you don't really have to read much of the book. However, make sure you go to class and get the notes.

So so class, she's ok and really likes what she does, but could do so much more to make the stuff interesting but tends to dull it down abit. Weekly quizzes in discussion are pointless, they are based on the lecture yet when i went to lecture I would average abt. 4 out of 10, and when I didn't I averaged a 9.

Very unfair. Worst grading system I have ever heard of. The quizzes each week in discussion were worth more than the exams and the quizzes were graded EXTREMELY unfairly. My TA was awful and even though I averaged an A on the exams I got a B in the class because of discussion.

Fantastic teacher who really knows what she's talking about. The exams are pretty easy as long as you know people, dates, artifacts, time periods and basic facts. Not too bad. At the very least it was very interesting.
She has very fair tests which consists of averages in the 80s. Discussion doesn't do much for me, but her lecture is very good. A very fair professor.
No Comments

Handled the class very well for a huge lecture mostly comprised of freshmen -- recommended lots of resources and generally seemed to care (i.e. an online textbook site I've used ever since). Exams weren't hard, and she only tested on what was covered in lecture. Sometimes talked too fast for notes to be taken, and the book was a bit pricey.

Was told by our TAs that showing up to the lectures was required for the discussions, but they weren't on topic. As passionate as he was, for a philosophy class I wasn't going to take notes on ancient Mesopotamian words and why the Dark Knight was such a good film. Even the TAs were often clueless as well as to how his course was at all related.
He's fine

Easy class. Only based on some papers which are p/f (40%), participation (10%), and a midterm and final paper (50% combined). Lectures are a complete waste of time bc he just yaps for 50 minutes. There is also some extra credit that adds a lot of points to ur grade, so I would take him for an easy A.

Dr. Gordon is a funny and passionate lecturer, but his lectures rarely relate to the topic. He gets sidetracked super easily and spends 2/3 of the class talking about something unrelated. His grading is easy though-completion of four 1 page papers, 1 group presentation/essay, and final. It's an easy class but not very informative.

Pretty interesting course. Gordon is a nice professor who cares about the subject. Lectures were interesting but not mandatory to attend. Discussions have a participation grade so make an effort to attend those. 4 P/F papers, any completed after that was extra credit. Group paper for the midterm, and the final was a paper.

The class was based on 4 P/F papers, a group project, a final paper, and participation in the discussion section. Everything is graded by the TA. Papers and the group project are easy if you attend the lectures. Gordon was always inspirational, and the lectures and discussion sections were enjoyable (though he would sometimes drag on).

(PHIL 1109) This class is easy to do well in because he wants his students to learn. Discussion is mandatory, and your TA does all the grading. There were 4 P/F papers (more for extra credit), a group presentation/paper midterm, and a paper for the final. Going to lecture made papers a lot easier to write and his lectures were always inspiring.

(PHIL 1109) Super easy, I went to lecture two times all semester. Go to discussion, complete 4 P/F 1 page papers on readings of your choice, more for extra credit, a group presentation and essay midterm, and a paper for the final. TA does all the grading. Overall easy A, just put in a little work for the papers and skim a few of the readings.

(Actually PHIL 1109) Go to discussions, pay attention to Microsoft teams (instead of HuskyCT) and you will be fine without lecture. Group paper/presentation for a midterm then take home essay for a final with 4 required reflection papers on any reading throughout the entire semester of your choice with plenty of extra credit. Super easy, low stress
this professor is inappropriate with students. he should not be trusted with a classroom

Very easy class. You don't need to go to lecture but every time I went I felt inspired tbh. 4 written homework assignments and 1 group presentation/essay are the only assignments besides the final essay.

I was very confused throughout this whole class. Nothing gets graded till the very end, so I am not sure about my grade. The TA does all the grading and he is not very accessible outside of class. Attendance for the discussion is mandatory and the class meets 3 times a week.

Listening to Professor Gordon speak was hard. He has only worked in academia his entire career, so frankly his view of the world is extremely skewed. The good thing about this course is that it is easy. The grade is essentially based off of a presentation in your discussion sections, a paper, and four weekly reading responses that are pass/fail.

Easy A four one page papers which are pass/fail, one group project in discussion, and then a 1500 word paper. Don't need to go to lecture, when I did go though it wasn't great he would sidetrack a lot and get political for literally no reason.

Loved Professor Gordon. Very candid and chill in lectures, clearly passionate about philosophy but never too pretentious. Grading was super light, as long as you do the assignments it's a very easy A. Content is sometimes difficult to understand, but very interesting and Prof always helps interpret them.

Overall easy, graded on 4 one page reading reflections (usually opinions or summaries), group midterm project, and a final paper. TA does all the grading. Not required to go to lecture but discussion attendance is required.

Assignments for the semester: 4 one-page reflections on readings (take 20 minutes to write, read a summary of the reading), group project for midterm, final paper. Show up for discussion section (attendance recorded for discussion). I went to lecture all of 3 times. Your TA is who ends up grading everything

lots of reading but not too bad. 4 one-page assignments to complete over the semester, one group presentation in discussion for your midterm, and a final paper. dont worry about missing lecture because he just talks about the readings. the prompts for the final are very specific so read at least some of the readings. DONT BUY HIS BOOKS
One of the smartest people I have ever met and an amazing lecturer. He is very opinionated but informed enough to defend his position well. Just do the reading and show up to the discussion sections

He was a nice professor and class was easy. He made the readings understandable and told engaging stories. He does get political often, which is both uncomfortable and ironic. 4 P/F papers on readings, 1 group midterm essay, and a final take-home essay. Depending on your TA you'll do well. Participation was also graded during discussion.

Class format was Mon Wed 1 hour lecture from Gordon with 300 students and then individual small 20 person group discussions once a week. only assignments were 4 individual one page papers for whole semester pass fail. And a group paper and then final take home paper. Lectures are completely skiable very easy A.
He is a nice professor. Fun person. This class is easy and fun. Take it. You will not regret.

I took his class online and it was very easy. Only four papers you needed to hand in all semester and this was pass/fail. Then a group project that turned into your midterm and then a final paper. His lectures are fun as he makes them engaging, but I didn't really pay attention but they were interesting.

Professor Gordon is nice and his lectures are quite funny. Pretty easy A (4 pass/fail 1 page papers, participation, midterm, final). However, I was extremely irritated in this class because he attempts to push his radical political views on us any chance he could get, even though most of the material has absolutely nothing to do with politics.

Profesor Gordon is absolutely amazing! Truly cares about his students, and tells funny stories to keep the class engaged. For a serious class about deeper understanding, he still finds a way to make it light-hearted and relatable. The discussion section was mandatory, but class is pretty much optional. Not much work, but the midterm paper was long

This was a very easy class. Both exams are take home essays. If you're decent at writing and attend a couple of lectures you'll get an A. The reason I didn't rate him higher is in lectures he gets off track very often and gets political for NO reason which is super annoying (Take the class and you'll know what I'm talking about).

Prof. Gordon is very knowledgeable about topics in his field, and gives great lectures on the subject material. I skipped his lectures <5 times, and I was able to get a 92 on the midterm, take-home essay. The final and the midterm are both take home essays, and the reflections are pass/fail on whether or not you submit them. Easy A.

This class was . . . interesting. Lectures were all over the place and filled with stories to make the content relatable, but not a lot of the actual content itself. I didn't feel prepared going into the exam essays. Emailed him a couple times and he never wrote back. Grading seemed arbitrary, but it all depends on whether you have a good TA.

Professor Gordon is a really nice guy and very respected philosopher but he's kind of unclear in his lectures. Most people don't go and get As, I went and really wish I would have skipped more. The grade is only a midterm and final take home essay and 5 pass/fail 1 page papers so it's very easy as long as you have a good TA

Professor Gordon is one of a kind he is unlike any professor you've ever had class with before. Incredibly funny, charismatic and has the craziest stories to share. He is very intellectual and very knowledgeable about the topics he teaches. Also a firm believer that grades do not reflect who we are, and thus he is not a tough grader. Loved him!

Possibly the nicest professor I've ever taken. For this class specifically there is a large workload involved for reading so that you can be engaged with what he teaches in the class, but the content was fascinating and well taught. Extremely supportive of your success, and easy to get a hold of.

1106 with Gordon was probably the easiest class I've ever taken. But, I probably learned the most in this class. A few simple essays (homework is 50% of grade) and discussion makes up the grade. As long as you show up and think a little Gordon helps you out. He designed his class to be easy to encourage more genuine thinking. Highly recommend.

Highly recommend taking philosophy with him if you need a philosophy course! I rarely went to lecture (although this lectures are really funny and engaging, they are not necessary)and rarely went to discussion and still finished with an A-. No exams, just 2 papers and 5 one-page reflections that are pass/fail.
Easiest class. You do not have to go to lecture or discussion. Two 5 pg. papers that are 50% of grade. Five 1 pg. reflections that are 40%, 10% participation.

Prof. Gordon is NOT disorganized. If you've been doing the reading like you are supposed to notes would not be a problem. There is no clear formula when it comes to philosophy and students don't get that. This class is primarily based on understanding. Go to office hours as he is always more than willing to help you. He is so kind hearted.

Professor Gordon was a great professor. Take Phil 1106 with him if you can! 50% of the grade is based on 1 pg relfections you do from readings each week, the rest is two final papers each 20%. He is a great speaker, the way he teaches is kind of like storytelling in a way. Go to class if you want to keep on track but it isn't mandatory.

Easy class overall. Midterm and final is a 1500-2000 word take home paper. His lectures are disorganized. He will write very broad notes on the board so write down whatever comes out of his mouth as well. Notes will be very important when writing your paper. Makes really weird, and sometimes uncomfortable comments during lecture. Gets off topic

A great professor but his lectures aren't powerpoints, they're on the spot, so don't miss class! His lectures are a little disorganized, which was difficult for me, but he was really interesting and a great speaker. He's also pretty well known in the philosophy community, which is really cool. Just an overall great guy!

Professor Gordon is super easy. He only has a midterm and a final, which are take home and count for 50% of your grade, but they're not even hard. Attendance isn't mandatory and you don't miss anything by not going. The rest is reflection journals that are less than 1 page and participation in discussion. Super easy, if you can take it, do it!!

This professor is Uconn's Greatest asset! He is so inspiring, so knowledgeable, and truly wants educate his students. He discusses the most interesting and mind boggling philosophical concepts in a way that is easy for undergrads to understand. He is very humble, understanding, and open for discussion at any time. Truly one of a kind.

Love this man!! Extremely knowledgeable in all kinds of philosophy, and really enthusiastic. He is a dynamic lecturer, and he's great at spicing his lectures up with fun stories and analogies. He recognizes that his duty is to teach us so we really learn, and only gives a very reasonable and manageable amount of work and reading. Take a class!!
Fantastic inspiring professor. really easy class. Best storyteller I've heard which makes class go by relatively quickly. Just a few papers, doesn't grade too harshly and no tests.

He is not really organized and it feels like he doesn't prepare for his lectures at all. But he sometimes makes the lectures interesting and makes jokes. He gives a weekly reflection assignemnt and a midterm and final paper. Not a a tough class, but the papers are hard and the lectures can be very boring.
She's great! Funny, entertaining, and very helpful. If you have any questions, she takes her time to help you out. Exams are not easy, but not impossible. It is a fun class.

The slides are VERY visual. I found it easiest to print them out and write on them during lecture. The exam questions are kind of confusing so I recommend looking over the practice exam to see WHY each answer is right or wrong. She's very nice and enjoys lecturing.

I loved taking this class with Carello. She was interesting and energetic. Honestly it really was not that hard if you showed up to class. I did very minimal outside work (did not read textbooks or study much) and the lowest grade I got on an exam was a 96. The questions can be a little confusing but if you read them carefully you'll be alright.

She is just an awful teacher. I suggest you take an extra semester to graduate than be forced to take her class. Her test questions are way to complicated. I don't know if she knows its a 1000 level class.
Not appropriate for an entry level course.
If you attend lecture OR read the textbook the class shouldn't be too hard. Definitely do at least one though.

She was a great professor in her lab class. It was actually pretty fun doing all kinds of distance perception experiments every week. The grading scheme there involved a final paper and a comprehensive lab journal, and I appreciated that. Definitely take her if you have an interest in science or come from a scientific background. She's VERY nice.

The class was pretty easy, and the professor covered everything on the tests, however her lectures were unbelievably boring. I had trouble staying awake. However, do go to lecture because stuff that she says, that isn't in the book, is on the test.

unless you have the attention span and patience of a chess player then youll be alright. i had 3 tests all semester but each were either so vague or so specific that its very difficult to get a good grade in that class. nice women but she should not be teaching

she means well but is a horrible teacher. her lectures are very visual and hard to understand and the tests only ask detail questions. i had a very hard time with this class and do not recomend taking it with her
so hot

She is really nice and is extremely intelligent, but overall not a very good professor. The slides are so hard to understand, even if you go to class every time. The tests are kind of hard to understand as well.

she's nice, but an awful teacher. i brought in ap psych credit and it did not help me in her class. her lecture notes are SO confusing, you have to reread everything like 100 times over to take anything in

She knows her subject well, but isn't great at teaching it to students who have no prior content knowledge.I had to teach myself most of the material because her powerpoints are mainly just pictures with no information. Lecture is hard to follow and pay attention to. Exams are very difficult. She's sweet and means well, but not an easy professor!

She was a very good teacher, other students give her bad reviews because they're bad students. If you go to lectures and put in some hard work and effort, you'll get back a good grade. You have to go to class to do well and actually study, but shouldn't you have to for every class?

Her lecture is just a silly cartoon-y powerpoint and is nothing like the tests. All I've learned is anatomy, physics and Stats, nothing on psych. I've never gotten below a C+ in my life and I currently have a D. This class is so hard. Either don't take it at all or take it with another professor.

She seemed like a very nice person but her tests were SO HARD and her lectures could be boring and confusing. I'm not sure if it was the subject matter or the way she taught it, but it was kind of dry and hard to understand.

The exams we're as difficult as everyone says especially because practice exams are very similar. They do require a lot of studying and paying attention to the way SHE explains things rather than the book however.

I took this class and practically failed with her as a teacher and re-took it and got an A with another professor. Her classes were boring and the materials were harder than necessary for an introductory class

Very easy class ! Highly recommend. Tests and notes are a little difficult, but if you go to every class and pay attention you'll do fine. She also awards up to 7 extra credit pts on final grade for doing experiments! I got an A in this class and didnt put much effort in...

I took AP Psych prior to this class so I knew a lot of the material. If you study enough you'll do fine on her exams; the material is a little difficult. Her power points are extremely helpful and she explains things very well. She's happy to help you, and is very nice. Her slides are more helpful than the textbook.

Uses visual aids, including powerpoint slides and physical gestures. Reading the book is helpful, but the exams tend to follow the slides more than they follow the book. I would recommend a science background for her lecture as her exams require some logic, and most of her course deals with the physics of psychology.

I went into the class at 2, wide awake, and came out ready to fall asleep. Tests are hard. A lot of studying is needed to pass them because a lot of it is little detail material. I liked the guest speaker she had teach for two classes rather than her.

She's a pretty nice lady, but not clear. She posts all of her slides and dictations on her Husky CT page, which is nice if you don't want to go to class, but her tests are pretty difficult, all multiple choice, but they're on fairly obscure things she taught. Book reading is assigned, but not necessary. The lab had NOTHING to do with the lecture.

She puts all her slides online which is helpful, almost don't need to go to class. she uses confusing language i would recommend reading the textbook and looking at the slides, that it is more helpful than her lectures. she makes her tests unnecessarily difficult you need to study a lot for but overall it's not that bad.. go to the review sessions

I liked her. She put her slides online which is really helpful and helps with taking notes during class. Little reading (not really necessary either - she goes over everything). Study sessions help a lot. The lab is completely different than the lecture, so it's a bit confusing. Good teacher, makes class interesting.

She is a bore rather, but the class info is neatly printed on slides for your understanding. If you study the slides and got to exam review, you are guaranteed at least a B. I missed half the classes and got a B+

Carello was completely useless. The information she gave in the lecture was very different to what was on the tests. The discussion and lecture had nothing to do with each other. She read off of her slides every class and did not add anything new to the. Awful experience over all

A nice lady.. but a horrible teacher! All of her tests are extremely difficult. It is pretty easy to get a C by doing really well in lab, but almost impossible to do any better than that. Avoid her, if possible!
Nice lady but tests can be confusing since she likes to use confusing vocab

Different from other teachers, you have to put everything you learn towards the real world...practice questions, and essay summary of chapters she puts online are VERY HELPFULL....dont even need the textbook...

Requires a different way of thinking. Even if you study, you have to be able to put the knowledge together for the exams. Her exams are tough, but if you study, you should get at least a B. Not much reading, maybe about 2-3 pages per lecture. Has a lab portion to her class also.

Many people say that Professor Carello is hard and boring, while I do not find this to be the case at all. She assigns very little reading and the slides she provides are helpful. Her multiple choice tests are okay. I have an A so far, just by going to class and studying a moderate amount. Study sessions and practice exams are key.

exams are very hard. She give one multi chioce exam which isn't too bad and 2 essay exams. she gives you the questions ahead of time but most of the questions arevery complex,and she uses a very big vocab whihc can make class and essay question difficult to understand. If you are not good at writing i would not take this class.
Her test are pretty difficult, but if you ask for help and go see her you'll do fine.
hard,tests are difficult,not too helpful,uses words like stuff&chewy quite often making it very difficult to comprehend what she is talking about.
No Comments
very nice lady, teachers material well: tests are very hard
No Comments
She's clear and does her best to explain complex concepts
No Comments
Powerpoint is VERY helpful, emphasizes the general rather than specific points

Prof. Jaramillo is a great professor. Her lectures are incredibly easy to follow and she posts all her notes online. In addition, all her lectures are recorded so there are no issues if you miss class. She provides study guides for exams on which the exams are based. Highly recommend for any course she teaches.

Posts lecture videos online so you can go back to them, or if you don't go to class you can always watch them. Her tests are fair and aren't meant to trick you. The weekly worksheet really helps with exams. If you know how to do them then you should be good for them exams.

Maree is honestly the best math instructor I've ever had. She is very thorough in her lectures and uploads extensive notes online and lecture recordings. She asks if anyone has questions very often and is accommodating to people who need a slower-paced class. Work-load is very reasonable assuming you don't let it pile up.

Very sweet professor and is always available for office hours. However, her lectures are very fast-paced and can be difficult to keep up with. Homework is due on Wednesday with an additional worksheet usually due the day before the lecture. Very test-heavy but she allows test corrections to make up points.

Maree is one of the best professors I've ever had. People are giving her bad reviews because the class is hard but that's literally because this is calculus, what were they expecting? Maree does her best and she clearly cares about her students, if you seek help she will give it. Pay attention and go to class, you get what you put in.

Though the professor is nice. She usually goes really fast through the chapters and talks a lot. She also has worksheets and homework each week. If you really like math you should take her. Just be ready to be flash through the lectures.
Maree Jaramillo is a real gem at UConn Hartford. She is a great calc professor who cares about her students and loves math.

she is a good person but other than that there's not much to it. she doesn't really teach the class just goes over a few a problems for the topic and moves on, you can't pass just by attending lecture. if u know u can't keep up with fast paced classes don't take it cuz there's a lot of material. exams are on paper and she looks around alot.

Maree was an amazing professor. She claims she does not give extra credit but towards the end of the semester she gives lots of extra credit throughout class and grades VERY leniently on exams! She cares a lot about her students and explains everything super well.

I took her for 1131Q and 1132Q fully online because of COVID, but shes so nice! She genuinely cares about her students and made sure to give lots of partial credit even when your final answer was wrong. Although the material itself was very challenging at times, Maree tried her best in making sure everyone understood. 10/10 would recommend her!

Maree is very nice and teaches with passion. Her class is very hard, you need to do weekly worksheet and 1-2 WebAssign hws. There are 2 exams 20% of your grade each. She gives lots of credit even if you get the final answer wrong. Final is also 25% of your grade. Math is hard in general but she is the best at teaching. I would recommend her.
She's always optimistic and encouraging. Even though calc is a super hard course, she made it entertaining. Always gives amazing feedback and really wants you to pass.

Prof Jaramillo is the sweetest woman out there. She genuinely cares about you and wants your wellbeing. She gives a lot of followers credit so if you get an answer wrong on an exam you can still get a lot of points for it. Theres a crap ton of homework in the class but helps in the longrun

Shes very very veryyy nice, and a genuine queen . Her personality and class notes *chefs kiss*. But her class has changed ever since online started. It was very difficult for me to keep up with her as her lectures are long... but I didnt set myself up with the 2hr block, so my fault. But no notecards and lockdown for every quiz/exam!!
Great professor super helpful lectures are great
Nice professor, cannot adapt to an online setting
Very nice professor, but the class is extremely challenging. Her lectures are not helpful, and if you don't do well on even one exam, the class will not go well for you.
Great Professor really cares about her students and making sure they do well.

Maree is GREAT! You cant find a better Math Prof at UConn. But, this course is T-O-U-G-H! Dont be fooled because its "Pre" Calc. Requires a LOT of effort. Lots of HW (which is good is a way, because it forces you to learn the material, so you don't fail the exams.) The final being cumulative is HARD! Use the Qcenter. She does curve and give EC.

Professor Jaramillo is amazing! Truly cares about the wellbeing of her students and makes sure they understand the material! Not many tests, but mandatory graded homework for each week of material. Takes some time but really helps to perfect understanding the material. She is awesome and so so nice! Love her!

Professor Jaramillo is one of the BEST math professors UCONN has. She gives you many opportunities to improve your grade and makes sure you understand the content. She definitely makes calculus less painful. Id recommend anyone to take her. Switch your schedule if you can, you wont regret it!

So far taken Professor Jaramillo for Pre-Calc and Calc. She is absolutely amazing if you care about your grade. Attendance isn't mandatory but advised obviously ( I skipped a couple lectures). Really study and do the exam reviews! You will do well. Curves exams if overall isnt good. Got a 88 and 86 one two different exams received 98 and 95 final

One of the best professors Ive ever had. She really cares about you, and really wants you to succeed. I took pre calc and calc 1 with her I will truly miss her!! Made me love math. Not only did I learn so much I also enjoyed learning it ï¿½ï¿½ NO OTHER PROFESSOR COMPARES TO HER !!!
Shes an amazing teacher. Gives LOTS of examples. Quizzes every week but they prepare you for the exams. She gives you many chances for extra credit point.

One of the nicest professor you might ever met, but one of the most boring classes you might have ever been in. She does a great job with posting notes online and she does a great job during her office hours; but if you do not utilize them it is difficult to do well. Also, there is lotsss of homework every week. Her exams are a little difficult.

This Professor is the absolute best! There is a lot of homework, but plenty of extra credit opportunities for quizzes. My opinion is she makes this subject so much easier than I predicted. Easy A, just keep up with the work. Being that i missed a lot of school due to being in the military she worked with me a lot. Can't wait for to take her again

nice woman, boring lectures. had to teach myself the material. did round up my grade a bit which was super nice. uploads the material online but decently helpful to go to class. material is really difficult and goes through it quickly. study a lot for the quizzes and especially the exam.

Maree is the best Calc professor in the school. Extremely nice person and teacher, will help with any problems you have. Explains everything nicely but Calc is a hard subject to teach. You have to put multiple hours studying outside of class to get an A. All the Homework is online and easy to do.

She is the best professor I had in this University, she really cares for her students. She is just like mom. For exams just be prepared on the review packet she gives you and seek help during her office hours and schedule with her she is always willing to help also lets you use flash cards for exams, make sure to do the web assigns those help!
She is a mother that I never had. She is the best math teacher I ever!!! And would take it again in a heart beat.

Honestly, a great professor who cares about her students. Takes the time to make packets which we can print out and use as notes packets. Allows flashcards during exams. And gives many opportunites to raise your grade. A fantastic teacher!!!

Maree is the best math prof i have had at UCONN. Very enthusiastic and dumbs down the math to make it easy (which is what i need to understand) give extra credit all the time and lots of take home quizzes. only negative- you HAVE to buy the book for webassign hw. very thorough teacher, cares about all her students. would definitely take her again!

Maree is a phenomenal professor, willing to give help when it is asked for and needed. Her exams are a little challenging, but manageable if you attend every lecture. Don't miss lecture. She is straightforward and is optimistic about teaching. I would take multi with her again!

Maree is a good professor b/c she's enthusiastic. However, if you want an A, don't take it with her unless you're very good at math. The other sections are typically easier. I was disappointed w/my final grade b/c I did all of the homework, and participated a lot in class, but only got a passable grade. The final exam was very hard.

Maree is the best professor that I've had so far. Lectures are long but the material and notes are important. She explains things very well and if you're remotely confused she will clarify until you understand it. She's super nice and very enthusiastic which is refreshing, and actually bothers to learn students' names. Tests are hard but fair.

Maree is one of the nicest professors you will ever have and she is very approachable. I would email her all the time and she would respond and help with my questions. There are weekly quizzes and webassign so you have to constantly review the material. She gives practice exams and allows a notecard for formulas which is unheard of.

I had Prof. Jaramillo in her first semester of teaching in UConn (Fall 2014). As a college freshman, I must say she did a good job. She utilizes iClickers for a participation grade, which is a nice little booster right there. She also frequently adjusted her office hours for us. Overall, she is a very good professor, and I'd recommend her to all.
She is very clear on her lectures and the assignments are very straightforward. If you have her, just take good notes and read the book, especially when she recommends you to.

Good teacher i think i was the first class she had out of school so at first she wasnt that easy to understand but she got better over the semester. Very nice and helpful in class and office hours you just have to have a specific question she wont go over a whole topic. very hit or miss with grading sometimes she gives alot of points sometimes not

Dr. J. is a really good prof. who knows how to teach! Her notes are very thorough, so you could probably get by without the book. Quizzes every Monday. Spend time doing the homework and you will ace them. She provides a lot of material and resources for students to learn, and communicates really well, so it's really your fault if you don't succeed.

Ok teacher in general. A little difficult to understand her lessons. Definitely have to spend time alone re-learning the lesson. She's nice and very sweet. Not intimidating. Tests not extremely difficult. Definitely not the easiest class to get an A in but she's not a bad recommendation.
The only bad thing I can say is that sometimes she rushes through slides.

Basically this class was done through Pearson where you take chapter quizzes. You have 3 tries out of 4 possible answers to get the right answer. The textbook was online and very easy to read. There were 2 papers which were 2-3 pages each. Dr. Brown gives very clear instructions on what to write for those papers. Quick 250 word max discussion posts

HDFS 2001 was online and asynchronous. There were 4 total modules to complete over the course of the semester, each with a due date. Basically read the lecture notes/textbook, take the quiz. In addition, there were 3 projects that were the heaviest graded assignments in the class. Those will take more effort and time, so just prepare in advance.

Not a lot of assignments and they're spread out across the whole semester. The deadlines were never stressful and there's a lot of leeway in the final project. There's only 4 quizzes. I loved learning about diversity issues. The layout of the class really worked well for me. She's great!

You could do weeks worth of work in a day before the discussion board posts and quizzes were due. There was a semester long project that was split into three parts that wasn't only interesting but made me learn a lot! Very informative, easy class.

Honestly, this class was an easy A. As long as you took notes while reading the textbook the quizzes were very easy, and so were the discussion board posts. The only other things you had to do was two paper based on the textbook and ted talks assigned, and those were easy as well. Highly recommend!

There were module notes provided and four quizzes throughout the semester. One project is divided into three different parts. Essay, media portfolio, and a plan of action. Super fun course and stress-free! She responded to my emails quickly. I would definitely take another course with Dr. Brown.

Although I never met Dr. Brown, this class was so interesting and easy. It was an online class, so the textbook was required. We had a quiz and discussion post every week and two short (1-2 pages) papers throughout the semester. Such a low-stress course and the content was super interesting; loved this class!

I took this class as an online class It is really easy that you are graded by Quizzes which are really easy to take and their are nine of them of the course of the semester. Their are nine discussion board over the course of the semester which are related to course material. Their are also two 2-3 page paper which are easy to complete.

Professor Brown is not caring at all. I left her a note on a late assignment explaining it was late because my grandmother had been very sick and passed a couple days ago. She still gave me credit, but deducted a lot of points for being late and wished my grandmother to get better, proving she did not read the entire note.

This prof is so sweet and caring! I took this class online and didn't need to put in much work, but she was always very accessible especially during office hours and shows that she really cares for her students mental well being and grades.

This course was fully online but easy to follow. Lectures are all posted with added videos to help grasp a better understanding of topic. If you put in the work you will receive an "A". Grades are mostly based on quizzes, 3 projects and discussion work. Overall Dr. Brown is amazing and I am excited to take another course with her!.

Super easy class, module notes are provided that you read. Module quizzes are easy and don't require lockdown browser. The projects are easy, too as long as you follow the instructions which are super clear. I liked the material of the class, and I wish I got to take it in person. I didn't interact with the professor once, only my TA.

This class was pretty easy and there is very little interaction with the professor. You read the notes to yourself (there are no video lectures). There are a few module quizzes, some discussions, and 3 projects. It is not a hard class, you just have to do the work. You have to teach yourself but most of it is common sense.

Asynchronous. Each module lasts 1-4 weeks with a 5-10 question quiz at the end. Routine assignments are group discussion post and replies, journaling, and module assignments (e.g. building bridges, media portfolia, plan of action). No tests. Late policy is unclear. Great class overall.

Don't buy the book all the info is on the slides that she posts on HuskyCT. Exams are very easy and you can get extra credit during the in-class review. She does a few worksheets in class. Homework is just working on sections of your final paper and worksheets for discussion. Overall, if you follow the rubrics and review the info you'll do great.
Took this over the winter session with absolutely no complaints. Very responsive and understanding in emails. Very clear expectations.

For a W course, she makes it easy. She provides a lot of help and feedback with developing your research idea and writing the paper. All exam info is on the slides, slides are on HuskyCT, and there are review sessions for exams. Dr. Brown is very caring and willing to work with students to have them learn well and get the best grade that they can.

Loved this class and definitely recommend taking it! Such an amazing woman who made lectures fun and getting good grades very achievable. Grades are based on in-class and discussion activities (go to class), three exams, and three projects.
Very easy class if you show up and pay attention.
Professor Brown is great! super chill and lectures were very interesting! Would recommend.
Very good professor and super easy class. Smart and knows what shes doing

Very easy material and the lectures were usually laid-back and enjoyable. There is a discussion section, but the TA's for this class are usually also pretty laid-back. There are 2 multiple choice exams, and also a "Building Bridges" project that spans over the whole semester. The project requires a lot of writing. Overall interesting class.
Shes really genuine and the course load is not bad, definetely an easy a
Kind of a throw-away class but not hard at all.

Edna is a very laid back professor, with the only heavy expectation of her students being to PARTICIPATE in lecture. She gets pissed when people don't. Grading is SO easy and work is even easier. She just wants you interested. Exams have random q's from lecture so you have to go. Easy class but the busy work kinda sucks.

Lectures rarely take up the whole class time. You need to show up to class for the guest speakers but they are very interesting. Go to discussion for participation points. There is a semester long project that takes up a lot of time but is easy to do. You need the textbook for some assigned readings because there are some exam questions about them
Professor Brown is great. Interesting and easy class.
Easy class if you stay on top of the work. Don't bother to get the textbook. Have to go to class as she puts up her power points but leaves out the key definitionspoints
Very easy class. Only 2 exams and 3 assignments that are easy A's. Journals are hard to stay on top of and remember. They are worth a lot, so don't miss them!
TAKE HER. it's a smart decision
found the class very interesting

Easy A. Material is easy, exams are easy, and not worth much. There's a semester long project that consists of two short essays and one portfolio. Project can be kind of a pain, but it's really not that bad. Prof. Brown is funny and extremely nice. Definitely recommend for a CA-4 class.
Definitely an Easy A class. The material is pretty interesting and Dr. Brown is an overall entertaining lecturer. Take this class!
Easy A class. Just go to class. My only issue is that I never missed a class but found the exams to cover pointless information which was tricky. Other than that very enjoyable!

edna is awesome. She explains everything you need to know. The tests are easy if you study briefly. If you pay attention in class, take notes and go to lecture you will get a definite A. 3 tests, including the non cumulative final are worth 20% in total. The rest are journals, easy papers and projects. The movies and guest speakers are amazing!

SO easy. Never studied once for any exam, totally common sense topics and terms. Intelligently BS'ed the projects. Literally got an A+ with zero effort. Go to lecture and discussion and just listen. Every other lecture is a speaker or movie that you can give as much or little attention you want. TAKE THIS CLASS NOW. Great GPA boost!!

This class is very easy if you attend lecture but you have to focus on the little details to study for the exam. Although she posts lectures online, you have to attend class to fill in the blanks. Half of the whole semester, the TA's would give lectures and not the teacher herself. Topics are general and mostly common sense.

HDFS 2001 is an interesting class. I recommend that you take this course. There is a semester long project that scares many students on the first day but it is broken up into pieces. As long as you attend lecture and discussion regularly you should do well in this class.

She is great! Really can relate to the students and she tries hard for everyone to do well and understand what we are talking about in class. Very straightforward class and she is very patient, but go to class because a lot of the lecture notes are on the exam.
Such a great class!! No exams, just quizzes. Semester long project was easy and interesting! Just make sure you attend discussion. Otherwise, I think this is a fantastic class!
EASY EASY EASY. Just go to discussion...she posts slides online. projects/ papers are easy...media one is a bit tricky though

great class! you should definetly attend lecture exam questions are straight from lecture (and the points she makes in lecture about the readings) attendance is mandatory for the discussion sections. this class had a lot of papers but they were easy.

Never went to lecture but the class has a weekly worksheet that is worth the most points, 5 pop quizzes throughout the semester (which are just on basic topics in the class), participation in discussion, and the final project which is just writing about a historical song. Overall lots of writing for the worksheet but better than having exams tbh
I never went to class. Weekly worksheets that take you maybe an hour, discussion section that is mandatory but straight forward. Easiest A of my college career.

This class is easy since there are no exams, but there are weekly worksheets that are lengthy and time consuming. I never got full credit on a single assignment or extra credit, even if I spent hours on it. Her lectures rarely speak about the homework questions and you have to submit your worksheet before we learn the content in the discussion.

I'm not a huge history buff, but McElya may have changed that! I had her lectures at 8:00 AM, but I never skipped since her lectures are that good (so engaging!!). She is super passionate and an overall wonderful teacher. Attendance is not mandatory for lectures, but you have to go to discussion sections.

She loves teaching and gives good lectures - You literally do not need to go and all of the homework is on the textbook and historical documents - Go to your discussions sessions and do your homework and you'll have an A. If you love history go to her lectures.
Would recommend for a gen ed, easy A. Homework can be time consuming but manageable. Your grade is pretty much the weekly worksheets, playlist, check in quizzes, and participation. Take this course.

No exams so really no use attending lectures. Discussions are graded on participation, with some pop quizzes called "Check-Ins." Weekly assignment, takes around an hour to do. Easy A, definitely take it as a gen ed.

I loved Proffesor M. She was a great lecturer and made the content so digestibale. Now dont get me wrong some of the readings were tough but it is very easy to get an A if you give a little time to the class.

I took this course because I needed an elective, and now I want to pursue a minor in WGSS. Professor Mckeyla is amazing! She is not only very understandning but she is extremely passionate!. The material you read is very interesting and I assure you that you won't be bored. There are various discussion post but zoom meetings are optional!

Professor McElya is absolutely amazing! She is super passionate about history, and it shows. As long as you are willing to put in the work you will do well. Read the textbook, go to class, and you should be fine. She is also very accessible, and wants to help you succeed.

Prof. McElya was an amazing lecturer who made sure to include not only the history of the country, but also the history in Storrs. She and the TA's did a great job transitioning the class to online in such a short time. She provides lots of extra credit opportunities for the weekly response papers and assigns a more than fair amount of work.

A no technology class. Lecture is not mandatory but the discussion definitely is, they're big on participation and it's graded. Easy homework but time-consuming, 2 tests u get a cheat sheet -everything's on the study guide, u have to do 5 response papers for the semester any weeks u want, don't know ur grade till the end but should be an easyA or B

The TAs are really harsh graders. The lectures are quite different than anything in HS, very thematic and conceptual but kind of in the worst way possible. The workload itself wasn't too bad until the transition to online classes due to Corona for us but that won't apply as much in the future unless they keep some of the policies implemented.

Professor McElya is a great professor, I loved this class. The material is interesting and so are her lectures. She allows cheat sheets for the midterm and there are five response papers you have to do that are short and straightforward. Lots of extra credit opportunities, definitely take this class-- not difficult at all!

Professor McElya's lectures are not great. Its like a speech not a lecture. I barely read the chapters or documents for the response papers and homework assignments and still did fine. The midterm study guide covered everything you need to know and you get a cheat sheet. I got a 100 on the midterm. It was annoying for a gen ed, but whatever.

Take this class is important and enlightening in every sense of the word. The text can be difficult and dense and there are weekly papers, however, they are graded relatively easily and as long as you attend every lecture and participate in this discussion you should receive and A.

I loved this woman. This was my first HIST/WGSS class here, and I want to take it again. She is so much fun, is so intelligent, and always helps you. She's amazing. You'll have to read to be successful, but if I'm being honest, I half read two of the novels.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had in my three years of college. Her class was really fun and engaging. She created a very comfortable atmosphere in the classroom where I always felt comfortable speaking and she always makes you feel heard. Doesn't take attendance, but participation is a big deal. One response paper a week.

This class is a lot of work but it is very manageable if you keep up with the reading and papers. I strongly recommend writing the papers earlier rather than later! And take advantage of every extra credit opportunity!

Most biased, unprofessional professor I have ever had. Pushed her own agenda rather than teaching her students history. I felt as if I was watching CNN rather than going to class to learn about actual historical events.

This class has so much work! The TA's are extremely harsh when it comes to grading and there is a lot of reading and writing associated with this course; I thought I was in freshman english again. Professor McElya is super nice and engaging, but the midterm has way too much material and not enough time is allotted. I wish I took another history.

If you need to take history at UConn take 1502 with Micki! She is such an interesting and passionate professor! Although the TAs can be tough graders, Micki gives a lot of extra credit and allows you to take a note sheet into both exams. Lectures aren't too rough and you'll learn a lot!

Shes a very passionate professor. Midterm and final, 5 response papers through out the semester. The only part that sucks is the discussion sections on Fridays. She gives a lot of extra credit. And you gave have a cheat sheet on the midterm and final.

She's so passionate for history, it's pretty sweet. Do the 5 2-page papers earlier in the semester rather than later. The prompts get harder as you go down the semester so get them done earlier. Try to go to class. It's important to get the book especially for the papers and the cheat sheet. Make your cheat sheet well and you'll be good on the test

Professor McElya is super enthusiastic about history and she really makes good lectures. It is not mandatory to attend her lectures but I went to all of them and really enjoyed. She assigns five papers each semester and they are VERY TOUGH, but she gives extra credits A LOT and if you did all of them you have nothing to worry about.

This class was boring but easy. You get a double sided cheat sheet for both exams, she gives opportunities for extra credit, and all assignments were clear and easy. If you go to discussion section, do the papers, and have a cheat sheet, you'll get an A. Micki is also really cool and passionate about history- has sweet blazers too.

This class was okay. I didn't take it very seriously. I didn't read the textbook except to prepare for exams. I did read for the discussion sections. She allows papers with notes for the exams and I wrote everything on them. She warns against this but I didn't have a problem with it. Attending class is helpful but I guess you could just read.

Really easy class. You get a cheat sheet for the exams and there are so many easy extra credit opportunities that can literally change your grade by a full letter. If you are required to take a history class, definitely take this one!

Absolutely incredible professor. I felt like I was pretty well informed before but taking her class blew my mind. She's so incredibly intelligent and knowledgeable, but most of all she's excited about the material and her lectures are always fascinating and full of information. Take this class if you can! Gives exam questions beforehand to prepare.

Has so much knowledge and clearly has a passion for the material. The only assignments other than the exams are the 5 2-page papers. If you show up to class you will do well. She offers several super easy extra credit opportunities and allows a full page front and back cheat sheet. She is an incredible teacher! Take anything you can with her!
By far the best professor I have come across. Take any course you can with here an you will enjoy it.
She's nice and the exams are mostly just knowing terms. Go to your discussion, there is participation. 5 2 page essays. Reading the book will help a lot for the exams

Attendance is not mandatory but you really need to go. She teaches things in lecture that are not in the book that you need for the exams. There's also things in the book that she does not go over in lecture that are needed for the exam. Overall she is a great professor who cares about her students and want them to succeed.

Best professor at UConn. She completely transformed the way I view the world and genuinely cares about students. Took WGSS 3562 as a related, but it was by far the best course I've taken here. Must do the readings but they're interesting and worth the work. If you get anything out of UConn, it should be the lessons from this course.

Prior comments fail to capture Micki's skill as a educator. She will make you see the world in a completely new and exciting way. The books you read are fantastic and her lecture/discussions are unbelievably impressive. Genuinely cares for her students and helps them achieve.
