easily the worst professor i have had in 4 semesters at uconn. he rambles about his opinions and tells you to read the book instead of teaching.
Total ego and pain to deal with. He made the tests miserably hard, grades even harder and refuses to budge on any set time he gives for an assignment. Be prepared to have a rough time.

Honestly, this class is tough. Material is challenging but Prof. Levin does very well in trying to help you understand. It does take effort outside of class to do well, but attending class and paying attention helps. Don't take this class if you aren't willing to put in some effort on your end but I think the things you learn make it worth it.
His exams are insanely hard for no reason. His homework's are long and time consuming. Don't take this class with him unless you absolutely need it.

Avoid this professor at all costs.There are no practice exams or study guides, and more than half of the class failed the midterm to the point where a 35 became a C after curving. The largest ego I have seen from a professor, to the point where parts of your paper will be crossed out with just "stop" in the margins, has no desire to aid students.
Such a strict professor for no reason. The tests are insanely hard. You get just about a minute per question, and he expects you not to finish. Please find a better professor.

Overall great professor, prepare to be in lecture and participating. There are 3 major tests given throughout the year as well as weekly homework. He encouraged learning and showed a passion and deep understanding of the subject. Gave good real-life examples to help students understand and constantly asked for student feedback mid lecture. 10/10

Remy was one of my favorite professors at UConn. He's great at explaining difficult concepts and always uses examples in class to strengthen our understanding. Exams are hard but he curves heavy(an 84 was an A). He doesn't allow computers or phones but doing so helped me focus better in class. I look forward to taking Econ 3209 with Professor Levin

Despite this course being an interesting and useful subject, this instructor's ability to effectively teach it is mediocre at best. He is experienced yet already has a full and fragile ego. If you are struggling and need help, expect a lecture on the Dunning-Kruger effect instead of him understanding the effects of variance on exam outcomes.

He is a very tough grader. His tests are very stressful with 60 questions on the midterms and 100 on the final. He allows a cheat sheet but it is still impossible to use it with just a minute per question. This class makes me feel like a complete failure even after giving my all. I would recommend taking it with another professor if possible.

Remy Levin is a great professor who really makes their students work for their grade. The class isn't easy by any stretch, but if you put in the extensive work required with the homework, a good grade is within reach. The tests are difficult, but curved nicely.

Remy is a very welcoming professor. He is connected to the class, knows everybody's name, and makes sure people stimulate their senses during the class and participate. It is important to mention this is not an easy course at all, be prepared to read, calculate, and write a term paper.. I do not think it is a hard class, just very time consuming.

Prof. L is one of the best professors I have had at UConn. He provided cited research papers in his lectures to give context to each piece of information given and connected it all in a beautiful way. I will say, his exams were difficult but fair if you study the homework, textbook, and lectures.

This class can be daunting with the amount of math one has to quickly get familiarized with, but if you're willing to consistently follow the course, you'll end up with a very solid understanding of basic behavioral economics. Attending the lectures is a must to do well, and Pr. Levin will conceptualize the material making it much more meaningful.

Professor Levin is a great guy that is truly passionate about his subject. While the class work may be challenging at first in 3209 if you are not familiar with basic statistics but the content is very well taught. The lectures are very insightful and the professor encourages conversation throughout every lecture. Certainly a favorite class.

Professor Levin is a genuine and funny person. Hes passionate about the course but his course moves fast. Homework's were very tedious/difficult, lecture were confusing, exams difficult even witha cheat sheet, and term paper (which you only have two weeks for) is the worst experience ive had. its an interesting class but id avoid it if I could
I had to make this class P/F and retake it for my econ major even though I am a straight A student. just dont take him and save yourself please.

This was a really good class that challenged me, intrigued me, and taught me a lot of theory and calculation. In my opinion, attending the lectures is a MUST to get the full effect of Professor Levin's enthusiasm for and expertise in Behavioral Economics. Due to its intensity, I recommend taking this class in junior year, possibly senior fall.

Prof Levin is a great lecturer, he's engaging and passionate about the class. The exams are tough but the scale is generous. Homeworks are reasonable and good test prep. Attendance isnt mandatory, but participating and asking questions is the best way to learn the material, so participation is key to a good grade. Overall, good class, great prof

Professor Levin is awesome to talk to and is super passionate about the topic. The math can sometimes be a bit intense and the exams are quite difficult, but he usually grades on a curve and boosts the class's grades. If you show up and actually attempt the homework you will do well.

Prof. Levin is definitely passionate about what he teaches. There is a textbook, but I mainly used it as supplemental material from what was taught in lecture. The tests are graded on a curve, so sometimes a 56/100 can be curved to an B+, etc. If you show up to lectures and put in the effort to learn the material it is a very rewarding experience.

This is my second time taking Prof. Schafer and honestly she is so nice and accommodating to her students. This class is not easy as it takes you outside of your comfort zone but if you meet with her she will make sure you are on the right track. Even better, she grades fairly leniently on the final paper so don't fret!

Lots of readings, with a sheet required for each day's reading. She collected them randomly but had chances to make up missed ones and sometimes would warn us in advance of collecting. 3 papers and participation (talking/reading in class and reading sheets) is all the grade was

Professor Schafer is the absolute bomb. As someone else already said below, she definitely pushes you to be a better writer. Super chill and accessible outside of class. Lots of reading, but seriously if I could take her for every class I would.

I loved Professor Schafer's class. Although there were a lot of readings, the material was extremely interesting. If you manage your time well, you will be fine. I will say, there are 3 essays for this class and she is not an easy grader. You truly have to put effort into the class and readings to do well. Although, she offers important feedback.

I adore professor Schafer. She pushed me to be the best writer I could be, which I always appreciate. She made sure to explain the material and be as responsive as possible. I loved the materials she chose for us to work with, although the readings could be a bit heavy at times.

Professor Schafer is such a nice woman, and she really cares about the material that she teaches. The class itself was a little boring, but I blame that on being completely online. Definitely a solid choice for a professor! She grades reasonably too.

Prof. Schafer does a great job of clearly conveying the content for the course. There are discussion posts due every week for the weekly readings and lectures which is not that much work as long as you are consistent with it. The only other assignments are 3 500ish-wd. essays that are fairly easy as long as you've read.
I loved professor Schafer! She's so kind and makes a comfortable space for discussion and is overall just a very good professor and person.

This was the most enriching course I have taken at UCONN, so far. Professor Schafer is an amazing person. She makes you work hard for your grade, but youre being graded honestly and fairly. Shes patient and caring but blunt with her criticism. This is a good thing! You can learn so much from her, if you take the time to. I received a B!

Prof. Schafer makes you work for your grade, but she's very caring and helpful. Class discussions are interesting, and together with some easy prep sheets on the readings and 3 papers, make up your final grade. She grades papers fairly tough and is direct about it, but if you are invested in the class and take her advice, you'll do fine.

Although the class is pretty difficult if you're not the best essayist, the class is extremely interesting and you learn a lot about European literature. Participation is essential in this class, so you need to show up. She is extremely brilliant and kind and knows a lot of historical background of Europe. You have to work for your grade though!

Prof Schafer is awesome. The workload is super manageable, and she seems like she really cares about students doing well and enjoying the topic that they're researching. She's always willing to meet with you discuss your work. I really got a lot out of the class as far as research skills and different types of history.

Professor Schafer is one of the best professors I ever had. She is a tough grader, and makes you work for the A. However, she knows her facts and class is really fun to attend. There is no exams in this class, but only two papers and a final proposal. She expects a lot from you but you learn a lot from her.

The workload is above average, but worthwhile. The three papers take up most of the grading percentage and she grades them with high expectations. A hard class to get an A in but you will learn a lot and be pushed to become a better writer and thinker.

Highly knowledgeable professor. Keeps track of how many times you participate in class and assigns prep sheets for every class (usually .5 - 1 page long). There were no exams, just three 4-6 page papers, but she can be a very tough grader when it comes to those. Either way, you walk out of class feeling that you have learned a lot more than usual.

She's a great professor. I learned a lot about historical writing and analysis in her class. She's a fair grader and was always available to help out with the papers. I totally recommend taking her class. It's not a ton of work, but you do feel like you are getting a lot from this course. This class is required for history majors, so def take her

One of the best professors I've had at UConn. She was so understanding and nice. Made class interesting, was all about discussion, not a lot of reading. Only one textbook, two papers and one final paper. Used primary sources which was interesting. Was one of my favorite classes I've taken so far. Would definitely take another class with her

Love this professor. Took both Gender and Sexuality + French History. She utlizes novels alot as primary sources - which is very interesting. And discussion is a must, you have to write a discussion write-up for every class, she randomly collects. Overall one of the best history professors. Much of class is discussion, which makes it very engaging

Professor Schafer is the best professor I have encountered at UConn. It is obvious she really cares about the class subject, and the students in her class. She is meticulously organized. Her syllabi are so helpful! During discussion, she responds enthusiastically to everyone's comments. She is encouraging and makes you want to do your best.

I took two classes with her and I have to say she is one of the better HIST profs at UCONN. Books used in class are literary works, not text books, and one book of "selected readings". total book cost is avg but you can probably share with someone in the class. very approachable, very interested in subject. easy daily hw assignments, essay exams

Test were open note; this was not helpful at all. Learning modules were outdated and in-person lectures were useless - they did not pertain much to the homework or exams which are the only things graded. Don't ask for help on the homework because he will put a twist on it and confuse you more rather than help. Be ready to spend hours on homework...
Good professor. Interesting demos in class. Tests are open notes.

Class materials you're tested on are in online prerecorded modules. His in person lectures don't really cover the online material well, though you'll need to go to them because there will be one or two questions on the exam that are only covered in his lectures. Homeworks are long and often confusing. Strict grading criteria.
Can be belittling towards students asking questions about HW. Stinks he is the only one teaching this class. I can bet there are a lot more poor reviews coming from other students soon.

The lectures are dull and unproductive. The professor condescends to students and is unavailable beyond class. Exams are challenging, covering untaught concepts. Homework is lengthy and difficult, graded inconsistently by TAs with unclear criteria. One TA grades significantly harsher. Best of luck, you'll need it.

Professor Tonn did a very thorough job of teaching this course. He offers many videos that have solid examples. More examples would have been nice, but he does give quite a bit to work with. Class is mostly homework which is very doable, but be sure to start in advanced. Final project is a research paper that was actually really fun to do.

He loves to hear himself talk, his lectures and online videos are long and useless for the HW/tests. He makes his own convoluted HW problems, every week several students email him with HW questions and he won't help. I would have dropped his class after the first week if it wasn't required for graduation.

The grading scale and structure class are not suitable for the success of the students. There are online lectures, but they take forever to get through especially when taking notes. The in-person lectures are mostly irrelevant to the homework. He doesn't provide much guidance in the homework even after several students have emailed asking for help.
Great lectures.

I am not one to hold a grudge, but he would not give me back points on an exam for an obvious grading error. If that had made a grade letter difference I would have been infuriated. Otherwise, his lectures are useless, you must watch all the online videos but they take absolutely forever. Afterwards, you're still under-equipped to complete the hws.
This professor made my life very hard. Final exams are very hard. TA of this class is not helpful.

Took this class over the summer and was asynchronous and there was little communication with the Professor. Videos were interesting but there were few problems done in lecture and did not relate to the homework well, this made the homework take much longer. Interesting applications of the knowledge though, may have just been the class format.

For an Asynchronous course, I was impressed by this class - it was very manageable at first, but then got REALLY HARD all of a sudden; especially the HW, which got quite tough. We also had an exam, 2 assignments, and full lectures during the week of the election, which sucked. Exams were very fair, with a Bonus, and he gave good partial credit.
Fine professor, but underteaches and provides little to no guidance in our textbook regarding content. Ambiguous about grading policies.

WOW. Let me just say I have heard amazing things about prof Tonn, but holy guacamole I spend at least 3 times more time on this class than any other of my engineering classes. The lectures take me HOURS to go through and take notes, and bc its all online I am still confused anyways. seems like a good dude though, very time consuming online class.

Professor Tonn is a natural teacher. He makes things extremely easy to understand, and although he certainly isn't a very engaging personality, he absolutely cares about the students and the material he is teaching. I will say that he can be absent minded at times. Also, I feel that multiple choice exams for a CS class are rather reducing.
The best Professor I have ever met, his exam is not hard, and everyone could get A

I really enjoyed his class. Hes super approachable and definitely wants to see his students do well. Honestly one of the friendliest profs out there. Needed the textbook solely for homework problems. His online modules are extremely helpful. pay attention though, every now and then theres an exam question he only briefly talked about in class.

Took him for Introduction to RF / Microwave systems and I really enjoyed the class. He is easy going and a great lecturer. Works you through the hard math in class and prepares you for the HW. Brought up many examples of applications and made the material interesting. Exams are open book/notes so having the textbook is key. Would recommend.

Dr. Tonn is a fantastic teacher. I came into the class with basically no knowledge of circuits and really enjoyed the class. Homework can seem challenging but usually is pretty easy if you understand the concepts from lecture and his online videos. Tests usually aren't too bad either. He's a really great guy, one of my favorite professors!

Honestly, I really liked this class. It wasn't easy, it took a lot of work, but it was pretty rewarding. Nothing unmanageable, 2 papers with multiple choice questions for exams and a group project to make a marketing plan for a company (didn't like the company we worked with in Fall 2020). Isn't easy but definitely worth it.

Professor Satornino doesn't deserve the poor ratings she's getting on here. The class is hard but it's hands-on, experimental learning so it makes sense it's challenging. She's super accessible and really does want her students to succeed. I feel like I learned more in this class than most other business school courses. Honestly, a great professor.

The reason Cinthia's class is hard is because you actually have to apply your knowledge to real-world examples instead of just memorizing concepts. The written assignments are tricky but the grading wasn't harsh at all if you put in the effort. Don't be afraid of this class, if you pay attention and participate you'll do fine.

I will say that this class was definitely not easy. But, it felt like the professor adjusted well. 1 live lecture per week and 1 pre-recorded. 2 "knowledge checks" - 20% multiple choice (use textbook) and 80% pre-written response. We had a group project at the end to design a business model for a company that was A LOT OF WORK but enjoyable.

She may be one of the most annoying professors at UCONN. She really thinks she is special and lets you know it often. I would avoid her classes. If you do take them, just focus on the textbook and make regular comments that support her points. She loves people that kiss up to her.

She definitely is not an easy A professor. I will say this was one of the harder marketing classes I've taken however, I learned a lot in the class. Cinthia refers to the textbook in lectures and class participation is mandatory during case studies to get a good grade in the class.

Towards the end of the semester her grading was very harsh and comments were condescending. She expects you to do a full marketing plan perfectly with little guidance, and itll take up all of your time. Even the small assignments take a great deal of time and effort. Dont take this with a full course load or you wont have time.

She was very intimidating at first, then I realized that she really cares about students doing well and being prepared for the real world. However, she creates an unhealthy learning environment by putting SO much stress on you. She makes assignments way harder than they should be, and is extremely condescending. good luck.

This is the hardest class I've ever taken in the business school. You have to prioritize this class (regardless of your major) in order to pass. Like everyone is saying, participation is HUGE and her class is not designed for introverted students. There's a group project that is really long as well. She is a good lecturer but extremely strict.

Grading was not as hard as it was made out to be but took a significant amount of effort to do well. Overall exams and the group project were fairly easy however she acts as though she's better than all of the students instead of treating them respectfully. Go to class, read the book, and prepare for discussions and you'll be fine

Grading scale was much harder than other professors. Rubrics for written assignments had vague and arbitrary defined criteria. Go to every lecture, especially on days with in-class activities. "Substantial" amounts of participation required for full credit in case discussions. At least there was extra credit and a curve at the of the semester.

GO TO CLASS. First things first, you need to go to every class as participation can count to up to 22%. Exams are not very difficult, but require knowing tons on information. There is a semester long project that is not too bad. Lectures drag on and class feels like middle school style of control of class of one way interaction at times. Stressful

These bad reviews about her are accurate. Her grading is the most EXTRA in the department. The class becomes super time consuming that it is hard to "prepare" for the course when taking other challenging courses as well. If you are a marketing major, you will learn a lot but best of luck. All other majors do not take her.

She's a very tough teacher. Participation makes up a significant portion of the grade but she was not clear with how we would be graded. Did not give satisfactory guidance on our semester long project. She reads straight off the Powerpoint slides and doesn't provide any information that is not from the textbook. I would not recommend her.

Dr. Satornino is one of the best professors I've ever had. People who complain that she is "too hard" clearly have never had to put actual effort into a class before. Everything she assigned was relevant to the real world and will actually help students in their future careers. I learned so much in this class, and can't wait to have her again.

Dr. Satornino is a great professor. She tries to help students understand and be prepared for what the real business world is like and does a great job at it. Participation and effort are required for the class, but if you do the assigned and come prepared its easy to do well. The only way to do bad in her class is if you're unprepared.
Her goal is to "train" us, but she is actually traumatizing. Too caught up in her PHD to see a normal student's perspective. Her grading is also very bias towards the "shining students." Avoid.

Cinthia says you will have the same workload as other professors and she "records" your grades. Truth is, she makes the same workload more challenging (and by that, more points to loose) and GIVES you a harsh participation grade. Awful.
It's unreasonable to be this hard.

This class contains a lot of tasking busy work. Participation is worth a large portion of your grade but she makes it difficult to participate in her mandatory discussions. Her exams are annoyingly specific and she finds it amusing when a student does not get an A. I finished the course with an A but would definitely not recommend her class.

HW is due every single day. It's not Cansler's fault but it gets extremely frustrating. She is very sweet and does give a lot of extra credit which is VITAL to do well in this class otherwise, you won't probably get above a B+. Loved how organised the class was only thing is there are exams every 2 weeks (60% weight) which is hard to keep up with.

Suzanne Cansler is one of the best professors I have ever had. Yes, the class is an exam-heavy course with 60% of it being your grade but you have 2 weeks to study two chapters before taking the exam. There is a lot of extra credit, and a lot of homework as well, but honestly just keep up with the work and you too can get a good grade.

Professor Cansler is such a sweet human being. She actually wants to get to know all of her students. This class has a decent amount of work but it's not like it's her fault nor is it that difficult. 60% of your grade consist of 6 quizzes and the other 40% are homeworks. And, you can get 5% in extra credit which brought me from a B+ to an A.
Professor Cansler is kind, and cares, she wants the best for you. Yes it's a lot, but the homework's do help, and the practice quizzes are pretty similar to the exams, which are also important

Professor Cansler is a fine professor however the class is very test heavy (like 70%). Homework's are basically useless, they don't really help you learn accounting. Practice quizzes aren't really like the actual quizzes that much at all. Extra credit was helpful. You'll need to dedicate all your time to this class to do well.

I loved Professor Cansler. Really cares about her students and wants them to do well. Has so many opprotunites and resources for you so that you can do well. She's super sweet and caring and made the class really manageable.

ACCT2001 is one of the most hated courses in business, but Suzzane made the class a little less stressful. She allows for a lot of extra credit opportunities, which really pull through at the end of the course. She holds office hours super frequently and records her lectures, so you can watch them back.

Professor Cansler is amazing! One of the most caring professors at UCONN. She wants her students to succeed and always offers words of encouragement. Accounting is hard, but she makes it exciting to learn and is always accessible outside of class for extra help. In addition, offers a lot of extra credit. I would 100% recommend her. Awesome class!

Pretty awful class and professor. Exams are like 70% of the grade and they are extremely difficult. I took this class online, perhaps this class would be easier in person seen as the in-person section averages 15% higher on exams. The exams are nothing like the practice ones assigned. I strongly advise against taking this class.

Very nice and good at her job. Very hard class especially in a Covid-19 year. Needed 1.8 points for a C and she didn't bump me. Brutal. If you're smart you'll do well with some hard work. Unfortunately, I am not very smart.

The tests in this course are impossible and are nothing like the homework/quizzes. The way she grades is unfair and the tests count for so much of your grade. Dont take this course if you're taking other hard courses. She forgets that students have other classes and not just hers.

Hard class but not crazy hard to do well in. Her lectures were good and engaging, there's a good chunk of hw but you need to do it to do well on exams-take advantage of extra credit and practice problems. She cares a lot about her students. From someone who was nervous about this class's reputation, it wasn't nearly as tough as expected with her.

Professor Cansler does a really good job giving good assignments, but this class isn't easy. Definitely need to attend lectures, read textbook, and do all practice problems to get an A. Her voice is annoying

Honestly, my fav professor of all time. Prof. Cansler is extremely nice and teaches amazingly. Even though ACCT 2001 was a lot of work (weekly hw and reading assignments) I was able to get a lot out of the class.

It's hard to fail this class, because 50% of it is through homework, practice exams, and clicker participation, but that doesn't mean it's easy. There's a lot of work. Cansler is pretty nice. Sometimes she goes rogue and gets off topic, and other times I question if she knows what she's doing. Plan everything out, and study hard for the exams.

Professor Cansler truly cares about her students and it shows. If you pay attention in class and do the work, its not that hard. But Professor Cansler is awesome and literally the nicest person ever. Highly recommend this class.

A lot of her rating make the class sound impossible but accounting is something you either understand or you don't and she puts you in the best position to do well either way. Offers 4% (overall) worth of extra credit for bonus problems and exams are similar to practice exams/homework. Good amount of hw but it isn't difficult and helps you learn.

Suzanne Cansler is one of the best professors I have ever had. She provides you with all the resources you need to succeed, but you need to put a lot of work in on your own. Her exams are hard, but she's willing to loosen some of the grading requirements if she needs to. She is truly a kind and inspiring woman. I never wanted to miss a class.

Professor Cansler is great! She is super nice and always eager to talk to students and get to know them. ACCT 2001 is a demanding class no matter who your professor is. She is the best you could hope for! Definitely take this with her.

She is one of the nicest profs ive ever had but doesnt mean that her class isnt ridiculously hard. The amount of time & effort required to put into this class w/ excessive homeworks & readings makes it difficult to do work for any other class. 80% of my time was devoted to this and I am still doing poorly-- prob just me but expect to be dedicated
If you're looking to take this class with Andrews for the E credit or just a simple gen ed. Do it. Super easy, don't think twice.

Professor Andrews is so knowledgeable and passionate about poli sci. She cares a lot about her students and is willing to give extensions and work with students to improve their grades. Her exams were relatively easy. There are weekly readings and summaries that were a bit more difficult, but still very doable. You don't actually need the textbook.

Professor Andrews was a decent lecturer who despite just reading off of slides, was able to engage the class somewhat in dicussions about various public opinion topics. Her exams are copy and pasted from her slides so the exams are pretty easy if you just reread them. Also attendance is mandatory because you have to discuss articles in groups.

One of the best professors at UCONN, she lectures amazingly and makes everything interesting. She cares very much about her students. She makes the course content very manageable; 8 required discussions, a weekly textbook quiz, & exam review. She makes it very clear what will be on exams and how to prepare. Im very glad I took this course for my E.
Dr. Andrews is great, this is the E course you want. Not too work intensive and actually interesting. Simple

Professor Andrews is a wonderful, passionate professor who is always happy to assist her students in learning. She is one of the few professors at UCONN who care about their students and want them to succeed. I have taken three classes with Professor Andrews so far and recommend her courses to students of any major. Reasonable workload and grader

Professor Andrews is an awesome professor! I loved her course. The material is super interesting, and it is clear that she is excited to teach it. Her lectures are great, and there is not too much work, the assignments feel purposeful and aid in learning the lecture material. She is one of the best professors at Uconn, take her class!

Dr. Andrews is the best instructor I've had during my three years at UConn. Her contagious enthusiasm and passion for the subject matter is inspirational. When Dr. Andrews feels that the class has met her learning objectives before the end of class time at 1:45pm, she'll end class early.

Professor Andrews is caring, passionate, and funny. Her class is always the highlight of my day. Take every one of her classes! She is hands down the best lecturer I've had at UConn and incredibly smart and knowledgeable. She knows how to relate to students and is highly respected as an amazing professor.
My favorite Professor and the best professor at UConn

Professor Andrews is hands down the sweetest professor here at UConn. Class is not mandatory because she posts all her lectures online but make sure you ask questions during the review because she tells you what is on the exam
Super engaged and wants students to succeed.

Prof Andrews is easily one of the best professors here. She has very engaging lectures and always wants her students to succeed. She's also clearly very knowledgeable about environmental studies and her passion comes through in lectures. Discussions and quizzes are very simple and straightforward. I 1000% would recommend you take a class with her!

Andrews was a caring and energetic professor. Her course was very easy, perhaps attributable to my enviro background, however it has interesting content. The grading structure wants you to succeed, so if you want an easy POLS, take this. There is a midterm, a final, a really easy group project, and weekly discussion/quiz grades. She is super kind!

Professor Andrews is so kind and a great professor. Though the class was relatively easy, the material was interesting and I liked how she structured the class: lectures one day and discussions the other day. No final, but two group projects, so definitely took the pressure off. Super nice and very responsive to emails and feedback.

Although this class is easy, I learned way more in this class than in most of my other ones. Professor Andrews is the sweetest and she is extremely smart and loves what she does. Perfect example of how UConn professors should be, she is a rare kind here! Take her as many times as you can!

Professor Andrews is super caring and accessible outside of class. She presents the material in a clear and concise way and always has great answers to questions. She keeps the class engaged with humor and fun facts. She definitely loves what she does. Definitely take her class if you get the chance.

Very easy class! I put in minimal time and effort into homework and quizzes, and probably only went to like 7 lectures and I nearly got a perfect grade in the class. Stay on top of your work, and you will do just fine.

Professor Andrews is by far the kindest and most accomodating professor that I've had at UConn. She goes out of her way to help you succeed in her class, and is very easy to contact if you have questions about an assignment!

I wish I took this class when I was undecided as a freshman interested in something environmental. Very easy, but still kept her lectures engaging. Had a guest lecturer from different departments come in to talk about their field in relation to the environment. If you are interested in the environment but have no idea what field, highly recommend

I'm a international students who has been taken his English courses 1003-1004, I would have to tell everyone that Oliver is a great English teacher to have for your first year at UConn. He cares about students very much and greets you before each class to see how you have been today and im pretty sure you will be doing better in his classes.
Really nicehelps you alot even you are no longer take his class

Oliver is a very nice professor. Though he might be a tough grader, he is kind and easy-going. Feel free to ask him questions after class. Professor Hiob's ENGL1003 is more than ENGL1003. The class is challenging, but worth a try.

Although the course itself is boring, Oliver definitely tried his best to make his classes as interesting as possible. Besides that, Oliver really cares his students and willingly to give you some valuable suggestions. The course itself is not difficult unless you really really have no idea about academic writing.

He is a really nice professor! He understand some difficulties for international students to write English essay. His teaching methods are useful and straight forward. The only thing for you to do is listen carefully and participate during the class. Try your best on your essay, then you are ready for the rest of the English class.

He is not so helpful because he is "busy" all the semester. Since that, he will not grade for paragraph structures but for word counts. After a semester, I cannot get any hints for improving my paper.

He's a really nice guy. His class's always compelling and captivating. Your participation (not attendance) covers 25% of your final grade'll never exceed 90 unless you're hyperactive and paper grade'll kill your GPA since he's very RESPONSIBLE. Don't worry. As international students, you have to take both ENGL 1003 and 1004 whatever you SAT R/W is.

For international students This is your life: You got a fair score in SAT Reading and Writing (650+) and then was placed in ENGL 1003. You have to take 1004 then because the professor would tell you that you are not able to take 1010 because of your poor Writing (What?) Yes, it's not because you're poor, but because you're international
TAKING HIS ENGL1003 IS MUCH TOUGHER THAN TAKING ENGL1010 OF ANY OTHER PROFESSORS FOR HIS GRADING CRITERIA

The worst professor I have ever seen. His class is harder than 1010 since he shows his responsibility by lowering your GPA. His writing method will never get over 20 in Writing in TOEFL. However, you are forced to be educated by this method in his class. If you want to pass his paper, just write as much ** as possible. He will definitely like it.
Maybe good for teaching other courses but not the one for teaching an easy course

Why does not his class be called Honors English for Non-Native Speakers? He is a hyper tough grader who could take away your hope to get A what you deserve in the first month. You could learn nothing but MLA format from his class.
He has an ability to make an easy class to be the hardest class in Uconn

Hiob is a great guy, he really cares about the class and his students. He is really helpful and his TA's are really great too. It's an easy gen ed and while his lectures are sometimes a little long, it's worth it.

Attend the lectures and you get an A. Very easy. Notes are gone through during lecture and contain all the answers to tests/quizzes. Journal entry due every 2 weeks, very simple and easy. YOU DON'T NEED TO BUY THE BOOK!

Very easy class if you just go to the lectures. There are journals due every week, but they only have to be about 300 words long and different topics for them are given in lecture to help you. Exams and quizzes all based off of lecture. He says reading the book is important, but if you go to the lecture, then you won't need the book.
Just attend class. I attended every class and didn't read the texts and got an A. It is much easier than reading all the texts and not attending. He is really boring a dry, but easy.
Go to class and enjoy the films! He cares about his students and the topic, but does grade on attendance and participation. The papers aren't hard. Movies are pretty good. Enjoyed the class!
Easy A, requires little to no studying, make sure you show up

Pretty easy class as long as you show up. I got an A- and studied for 20 minutes before the final. You need to go to each class, which isn't hard since its only once a week. Pay attention to the class discussions after class, it'll help your journal entries! He also says participation is important but its not.

Professor Morey is an odd teacher. She's young, yet is very condescending and wouldn't reply to my important emails just because I didn't call her "Professor Morey". In lecture she is great at explaining concepts, but the tests are always VERY hard in comparison to class / book examples. Lab is easy, just show up and study for the quizzes.

Spends too much time on the basics, then ends up having to oversimplify things that actually need to be explained well. Due to this, the exams and lectures are night and day. In lecture, you're falling asleep while she is doing her 10th density example, then you realize you are not well prepared for the exams when you take them.
Dr Morey was awesome! Explained stuff well, and was dissappointed when I couldn't have her second semester too! Highly suggest her, easy A :)
Dr. Morey was easily my favorite professor this semester. She explains the material slowly and in a comprehensive manner. As long as you go to lectures her class should be a breeze.

Professor Morey is awesome! If you struggle with Chem go to her for help she is very nice and often tells you things you need to know for the exams. I wish she taught Chem 1128 because that would make taking the class so much easier!

She did an excellent job at explaining the fundamentals. But watch out because she does tend to oversimplify things! She'll do basic examples in lecture and explain them very well, but the exams are harder. DO THE PRACTICE EXAMS! Exact same format. Exams are very long, so pace yourself. Do well on Owl hw and lab! Got 70,84,81,84 on exams. B overall
Slightly annoying as a person-but a great professor. She explained concepts quite clearly and was helpful. Exams weren't bad; study the old ones she posts online, the format is practically identical.

She is a great professor because she is helpful and goes through the problems and new material while constantly checking to make sure everyone understands. Go to lecture and do your work and you can get a decent grade.

She is really good at teaching the basics for each topic. Once you understand the basics, you should be able to get through the problems. Definitely, do the problem sets because the exams are based off of them. The book and your TA are great resources if you need extra help.
she just reads from the slides. tests are impossible. and she flies through the material so you have no time to process any information. get a tutor... hell be your new bestfriend.

She is such a nice, caring professor and she really wants the class to understand the material. She has review sessions before exams and is willing to help students with any problems they may have. Take her class, its an easy A if you just do the work!

She over simplifies lecture problems, and sometimes treats the lecture hall like a second grade classroom, but she does do a good job explaining the concepts thoroughly. The number of OWLS are a little unsettling and very time consuming, but otherwise homework and lab is easy. Exams are basically just like practice exams so study off of those.

She gave our section hundreds of questions on OWLs which no other semester received. She goes over basic problems in class then on the test puts the most difficult questions she can find. Make sure you take advantage of the regrades because they usually don't do a good job grading.

Easy class as long as you do the homework, go to lecture, and really study the practice exams. You're guaranteed an A as long as you understand the material and do all of the lab assignments, OWL, and do well on quizzes and exams.

LOVED THIS CLASS. Seriously, if you're going to take 1127 take it with Dr. Morey. She makes everything so clear and the exams are very similar to her practice exams. My TA was awesome too! I was afraid to take Chem because I heard it was hard, but there's nothing to worry about with this class as long as you keep up with the work.

She was a really nice professor and extremely clear and helpful. The class material was easy and she went through everything slowly so there was no trouble getting everything down. With just a little effort it is an easy A!

The examples done in lecture are nearly the same on the exam. If anything, the homework is the most difficult. Everything she said made sense, though sometimes I thought her way of doing math was a bit odd. Overall, if you pay attention and do the examples along with her, you can do well in this class.
She's beautiful. Absolutely gorgeous, if there's one thing i'll miss it will be looking at her for two hours every week.
Morey's examples in lecture are not even close to what you should expect on the exams. The examples from class and the work expected on the exams are like night and day so be prepared.

amazing teacher. test r hard if you dont understand how to study for the class. Morey does over simplify the concepts but i realized she is here to teach the basics not be our personal tutor. but she was AMAZING wen i went 2 her for extra help. An A is VERY attainable in this class, i failed the first exam, had a 70 average in lab, and i got an A-

Open note online exams, you have to try hard to fail. Highly knowledgable professor with a laid-back and approachable personality. Worth taking, whether you're interested in cancer biology or just trying to get free credits.

Dr. Giardina is amazing, he is very knowledgeable about the field of cancer, both in terms of biology and genetics. He always made sure his lectures did not drag, and you will learn a lot from him. Very nice professor, accessible after class, and is very caring. His study guides may seem dense, but do them and you will be fine for the exams.

Such a smart guy, clearly knows so much about the topic. Very easy to talk to outside of class. His study guides were so similar to the exams, so if you do that you should be fine as all the exams were open note. Great MCB easy A!

Great lecturer and taught 12ish weeks of cancer cell bio, the rest of the weeks were taught by Prof. Nelson. His 2 MCQ exams were very similar to the study guide he gave out, so as long as you ask questions and fill in that study guide you should easily get an A in this OPEN BOOK class.

Really nice guy, lectures are clear and he presents them well. Answers questions well and is incredibly knowledgeable. Open note exams, but make sure to do the study guide he provides, they are long but helped me a lot on the exams. Definitely recommend him, but respectfully I don't recommend that he keeps Nelson as part of this class.

I had Dr. Giardina for cancer cell bio and had him again for his grad class. Honestly, he is so sweet and kind and willing to help with students. Exams were very easy as long as you fill out the study questions and read the papers. Easiest grad class

Take cancer cell bio with Dr. Giardina! He is a very sweet prof and the class is very easy and interesting. All the exams are open-note and open-internet. Definitely fill out the study guides which will help on exams. If you are in honors, definitely convert this class for honors credit since the honors project is very easy.

Charlie is very sweet but his teaching style doesnt work for me. He makes slides but does not lecture with them. Writes on the board and shows the slides after. His slides have blank spaces in them where hes supposed to add annotations in so we can use them to study, but he always fill them out. Class is very test heavy & a lot of material on em.

Solid choice. One of the easier upper level MCB courses. Lectures can be a little dry and boring, but the exams are straightforward and the questions all come right from the slides. Spring 2021 exams were open-note and online. Definitely very knowledgeable about cancer cell bio, and a pretty nice prof.

Great professor, super interesting material. Giardina is an expert in Cancer Biology and I felt as though I learned more from this class than any other MCB class. 3 exams, top two are 40% each and lowest is 20%. No homework outside of class, just keep up with the material and the exams are straightforward. No cumulative final.

Dr. Giardina is a great professor. All the material you need to know is presented clearly in lecture, so if you take good notes in class you should do well. Be sure to do all the review questions and to be able to interpret figures of the pathways for the exams. Exams are very fair and not cumulative.

I would recommend this class to anybody! Dr. Giardina is super smart and nice and gives really interesting lectures. He gives study guides and holds review sessions before each exam, and there is no cumulative final. Decent amount of information to know but his exams are straight forward and fair. One of the best MCB courses available.

Cancer biology was one of my favorite classes at UConn! He explains the material very well. Everything you need for the exams is found in the lecture notes. The text is not necessary. There is a lot of information, but it is presented in a very clear and interesting way. Would definitely take him again!

Great instructor and one of the best at Uconn. The hardest part of the course is the significant amount of materials and the need to fully comprehend the mechanisms, functions, origins, and how each of them work. The class requires significant understanding. The ppt slides are extremely helpful in exam preparation.
Great class, no book, but required outside reading and great note taking.
Excellent professor! Clear in class and very helpful!!
gr8
He is a great professor, and his exams are easy if you just complete his study guides.
Really good, only teaches the first half of the semester. Tests questions come exactly from study guide so if you know that youll get an A on each exam.
He's a great teacher! By far the best and easiest bio 107 professor...uses huge curves on the exams too! You're lucky if you get him!

Best professor. Kind and knowledgeable, awesome discussions. Allows you to make up work or submit late for personal issues. Great if interested in kids, you learn how adults can come together to combat barriers to a child's learning. 2 reflections, 2 single projects, 2 group projects. Grades easily. Just show up and discuss the readings together.

She is a nice professor and will give you an extension on papers if you ask, but she changes the syllabus often then does not update it online. I wrote more in both of her 3 credit regular classes than I did in my W. Also, be prepared to read around 30-40 pages of her own published articles a week. Do not take classes with her, seriously.

Professor Harkness is very sweet, but not tech savy. She did not know how to navigate anything on the computer and needed a student to come up and do things for her. Not a writing class, but the entire grade is composed of three (very long) papers and a group presentation. She doesn't actually lecture anything you just read and discuss in class.

She has no idea of how to live in a tech-based 21st century, but will shame the class on not following US politics. Class is incredibly disorganized; prepare to learn very little. She demands class participation, but will always refute whatever you say and basically say you're wrong. This should be a W class, too. Way too much work and stress.

Very sweet. Generous grader. Not tech savy at all. She took some stuff off the syllabus to make the course easier due to pandemic. Changes dates around alot which is annoying but also good if everyone in the class feels behind. Very easy papers if you read the books. Always asks you to have your camera on and will call one you to participate.

I am taking this class during COVID. Her instructions are so unclear this class is so unorganized it makes me want to pull my hair out. She also doesn't stick to the syllabus which is irritating. Also has no clue how to work Microsoft teams after weeks of using it. Honestly, she shouldn't be teaching this class! somethings she says are ignorant.

This was the most unorganized waste of time class I have ever taken. You aren't allowed to use the bathroom during class and I can honestly said I learned nothing from this course. She doesn't answer emails yet always tells students to communicate through email. Takes FOREVER to grade. Received my final a week after the deadline. Avoid this prof!!!

One of the worst professors I have ever had. She takes weeks to reply to emails and then blames you for her not seeing them. She is rude and clearly thinks she is better than everyone. She gave us an insane amount of writing in the last two weeks of class and still have not given us our grades back despite it being a week past the deadline.

She has NOT posted grades for any of the tedious assignments shes given us. Its now almost 3 weeks after our last class and past the deadline for final grades to be submitted. SHE NEVER ANSWERS EMAILS! We had 2 essays and a group project assigned in the last month of the semester while the rest of our time was spent on ungraded busy work.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. She is extremely rude and doesn't even teach about low income families. You read chapters of books from 100 years ago. She doesn't know how to use Huskyct, does not believe that students are required to get their grades back, has a huge attitude problem, is literally the worst prof I've had at UCONN.

She puts you in a group for the semester and requires you to buy books for class discussion. Half of the class is spent with her not teaching and letting everybody talk. If you leave the classroom to go to the bathroom at any point youre marked as absent. So if you have human needs, dont take her class.

Don't listen to any of the good reviews on here. She's the worst professor I've ever had. We read chapters out of a book for class and "discuss" there is no up to date materials or discussion on current events. We have to write an absurd amount of papers and it really should be a W course. She yells at students for yawning and going to the bathroom

While she is a sweet lady, her knowledge of low income families is subpar at best. She shouldn't be teaching a low income class. She didn't even know who Ruby Bridges was until the class told her. Also, a low income class of course can include content about white people but shouldn't be the focus. She is very ignorant to what has happened.

Dr. Harkness is a great professor. Those who disagree just don't appreciate the teaching style of the class. There are lots of readings and 3 essays. The essays are the only thing graded, so your grade depends on them. She is not a tough grader, but she does expect intelligent/good writing skills. Great teacher and a really interesting class.

Dr. Harkness's class was one of my absolute favorites. It's pretty difficult, and there are a lot of readings, but if you put in the work, it's a rewarding class. She answered any student questions clearly and to her best abilities, and is very reasonable regarding paper extensions for good reasons.

Requires a 10 page term paper. With the paper is an outline, proposal and poster presentation that aren't graded. Also requires 1 panel discussion per group. This class is easy, she hands out "worksheets" to be done in your groups. i did not learn much nor did I find the books too interesting. She's very opinionated. Exams are take home.
Took her class in '06 - thought it was fine. You complainers are just not into the subject.
Good teacher - I found the info engaging and liked the research she sited.

she talks ALOT about her trips overseas. I ended up with an A in the class. There are a lot of writing little assignments. pay attention to the slides esp the graphs, make sure you understand them because they are on the exam. exams are not so bad but they are really long.your hand will feel like falling off by the end. make sure you get a good TA!

awful. presents material in a confusing manner. rather than going from infancy through adolescence in a chronological order, each lecture is a topic gone through chronologically as opposed to the ENTIRE COURSE being one continuous chronologically-based class. also gives way too many of her own research as "special focuses" . prob just for her ego
Good professor, interesting course. Average course load, weekly readings, discussions, and homeworks, 4 exams in total. Easy to do good if you try.

Great gen ed. Easy and pretty interesting, even for someone who is horrible with maps. Exams are multiple choice and are easy if you look over the notes. Attendance is a must, the slides are posted online but you need to fill in the blanks.
Class was not mandatory but it is necessary to get all notes. Powerpoint sometimes posted but not always. Test were very straightforward taken straight from power point slides.

Professor Bentley's class is one of the best gen eds. Notes straight from the textbook. He posts power points online, but you have to go to class to get them filled in. Just read the textbook if you don't want to go. Homework and discussions are easy grade boosters.
Professor Bentley is super hot and super interesting to listen to. Definitely go to class to save yourself the trouble of making up notes, but it's a fun and easy class overall.

Nice guy and overall not a difficult class. Some of the tests are hard and the homework assignments and discussions are really unnecessary. You have to go to class to get the notes but he goes through them very quickly so I suggest printing them out and just filling in the blanks.
Great professor!

Georgey B is the man you want for geography. Tests are strait forward, you get to learn some interesting stuff about other parts of the world and homework is a piece of pie. Also gives extra credit if most of the class decides not to show up and you do because you just love geography that much.

A MUST TAKE GEN-ED AT UCONN! Dr. Bentley is the man! He is very nice, young, and approachable. Class is pretty easy as long as you study for each exam (75 mc questions). The material is not hard at all though and is pretty interesting. There is a hw/discussion every week but it only takes 30 minutes tops. Overall a great class!
One of the best professors I've had. Real genuine interest in students. Exams and assignments are easy as long as you put in a small amount of effort and attend classes. Really really nice guy.

This was probably one of the easiest classes I've taken at Uconn. He is a nice guy and he makes it easy to get an A. The quizzes and exams are all multiple choice and he gives you a lot of the questions for the exams before. Study briefly for each and you should be fine.

If you don't take Geography with Prof. Bentley, you're making a mistake. Lectures are crystal clear and there are many opportunities to do well. Exams do not trick you, and as long as you read the book or listen to his lecture you will do fine. One of my favorite classes.

Take this class, it's easy and a nice breather from other challenging courses. And it's not like just because it's easy you don't learn anything, I've learned a lot and the class is pretty interesting. Bentley is a great guy, just go to class and follow powerpoints. Homework's simple, exams are multi-choice, easy. Take this class yo.

Class is really easy and really simple. He is a nice guy. IF you are going to take geog 1700 and you don't take it with Bentley it will be a huge mistake. I can't think of one bad thing to say about this class unless you don't like getting an A. Take this class because George is the man.

If you just go to class & fill in the blanks in the Powerpoint slides, you will get an easy A.Every week a 2 page essay is due about the development level of a country,yet it's pretty straightforward and takes an hour. Just review notes briefly before one of the 5 quizzes, and midterms include a lot of quiz questions, which are posted on HuskyCT.
One of the easiest classes you'll ever take, but you learn a lot. I really enjoyed the class! Take with Bentley!
George is a very helpful teacher, if you want take Geog 1700, take it with him!!

you either have to go to class or read the textbook (very easy read, a light skim and maybe a few notes). very hard NOT to get an A. the only thing is he wouldnt allow a make up when i joined the class late and only have 1 day before the first quiz (without notes or the textbook at that). quizes = 1/3rd exam even with the 50% i got an A...
Easiest class I have ever taken. Probably easier than my 6th grade geography class. Didn't go to any classes but still getting an A.

George is great. The class is really quite interesting, very straight forward, he gives you opportunity for participation credit and he repeats questions on quizzes on exams. You actually feel like what you're learning is worth while. Go to class and take good notes, book is not needed.
great professor 10/10 would take a class with him again

Professor Xygalatas' research is super interesting but I was glad it was only incorporated into class when it was relevant. There were a few pop quizzes and the things on them are from in class discussion so attendance is a must and my best advice is to take notes on discussion. Always looked forward to his class!

I don't like the form of the class at all. participate Matter in his class. lecture is the discussion of concept so you do need to read all articles before class, pop up quizzes so you will miss them if you miss class. personally don't like the structure of lecture,, if you are seeking organized points' PowerPoint, not really you class.
Nice guy and interesting class. Come to class because there are pop quizzes (pretty easy though), skim the readings, and you'll do well.
Hes a super nice guy and is willing to sit down outside class hours and help you with anything. Class is a breeze if you keep up with the weekly quizzes

Professor is very experienced, but also very boring. Discussion sections are all different, depending on TA. Grading is not very consistent, and whats expected of you is rarely clear. Still an easy class, but was also way too stressful. Best suggestion: take the class with a different professor.
Lectures you don't have to go to unless you want extra credit. Discussion once a week that was nothing besides one presentation. Midterm may be tough final optional. Easy A if you try

miscommunication with ta's and professor this semester, especially for how our final was being graded, he eventually told us that he told our ta's to purposefully grade us harder and then every got poor grades on the final. Besides that theres a quiz due each week and several of the answers to choose from essentially mean the same thing. Weird.

I didn't hear 2/3 of what was said in lectures due to how quietly he spoke. ANTH1000 with him was an awful experience. For every question on his quizzes, the possible options for each question were just synonyms of each other. The midterm was given with NO instruction and graded extremely harshly. Just a different class than w/ any other professor

Dimitris is a good dude with plenty of experience in the anthropology field. He mixes in some videos to make the lectures more entertaining. You have to do weekly online reading quizzes and short essay questions, and also a midterm essay, but no exams until the final. Surprisingly, the average for the midterm was a D- but that was graded the TAs.

Very easy "International Double Dipping" class that requires minimal effort. Just write the weekly paragraph on TopHat and complete the online mini-quizzes. Lectures are not mandatory, but 1 out of 3 classes he offers in-class extra credit so show up and you will gain all the material you need for the final exam just by listening to him talk.

This class was one of my favorites this semester. There is extra credit in nearly every lecture so attendance is semi-important. Going to the discussion is 100% mandatory. Grading was largely based on weekly quizzes and journals that weren't that difficult. One midterm essay and the final was a BREEZE. Highly recommend for a gen ed course.

Dimitris is a literal unit. He always makes me laugh in lecture. You do not need to attend lecture to understand what is going on but he gives a lot of extra credit opportunities in class. Workload is not bad, assignments are graded easily. There is only one exam which is the final and it is nothing to stress over. Highly recommend this class.
Best teacher. Makes you understand the material so easily and a very chilled out guy. Would recommend 10/10

Dimitiris is a literally angel and I love him. I changed my schedule so I could take more classes with him. As long as you participate, class is fun and entertaining - he makes a lot of effort to switch up what we are doing in class to really get people involved and so it isn't lecturing for an hour 15 every class. Minimal effort for an A

I had never attended a field course before. Mauritius is the stuff of fairy tales, and being part of this class was a learning experience 24/7 for a whole month. Hands down, this was the best part of my university education ever. If I wasn't graduating, I would try to fail just to take it again!

This is a field course in Interdisciplinary Ethnography taught in Mauritius. The most amazing experience I've ever had in my life! We got to live with a local family, travel around the island and attend crazy research projects. I did not know I liked anthropology until I attended this course!
Great class, teaches you that anthropology can be much more scientific than I thought

Great course, it teaches you so much about human diversity and connects the material to the other disciplines. I wish I had taken more courses like this earlier on. If you want an A, you should attend the lectures and not miss any of the discussion. He gives extra credit for unannounced quizzes.

Easiest class I've ever taken. Skipped lectures for half of the semester, started showing up again when I heard he was offering extra credit. His lectures consist of showing a few pictures and talking about them in an attempt to make it seem like he knows what he's talking about. Lectures are completely unnecessary, just go to discussion.

Dr. Mayerson gives very clear and concise lectures. The ATI and MyLab assignments are very helpful, and the tests are fair and straightforward. She is very accessible outside of class and although the content is hard, she makes it much easier to understand.

Dr. Mayerson is very sweet and is knowledgable about pharmacology. iClicker can be annoying but I missed a few classes and still got a 100 for participation. Her exams can be confusing, just really study and put in the effort for this class. Homework assignments are consistent and really helps your grade. I wish she offered extra credit, but 10/10

Dr. Mayerson is very knowledgeable about pharmacology. She's really good at answering questions and will give you a very detailed response. Exams are mainly mylab hw, iclicker, and ati questions, so if you study those you'll do fine. Attendance is graded via iclicker. She also co-taught this semester with Dr. Reagan, who is also very nice.

Class is very participation heavy. A lot of the exam content comes directly are from class participation questions, so if you're absent due to sickness you won't know the answers for some of them. Professor Mayerson is knowledgeable in the material, but very stern and strict. Students are often scared to ask questions or approach her with issues.

Dr. Mayerson gets easier second semester after taking NURS 3100 because you will get used to her teaching style. I will miss her next year because she is such a great and understanding professor. If you are sick, then let her know and she is very understanding and accommodating.
Dr. Mayerson is the best. If you put in the effort and attend class then it should be an easy A. No reason to read the textbook if you attend lecture and complete all homework assignments.

I adore her. Although her class is at 8am, she is one of the best professors. She makes the exams easy by giving you a direct outline on what will be on it and how to prepare for it. She is fast with responding to emails.

Mayerson is one of my favorite professors at Uconn. She understands that learning pharmacology is not easy and her exams are pretty fair if you study. She wants to see all of her students succeed and she tries to make the class enjoyable. Definitely try to go to class and stay on top of the work, it can get overwhelming if you push it to the side.

Professor Mayerson is definitely one of the best professors in the Nursing program. Her exams consist of homework questions, with some others (like 12 questions) that she makes herself. She is so kind and wants all of her students to succeed. She understands that learning pharmacology does not come quick and easy for most people.

iClicker questions in class are graded for extra credit purposes - very helpful. Around 3 assignments each week but it's very manageable. Lectures can be kind of boring but iClicker helps keep you awake.

Dr. Mayerson is one of the best most caring professors at Uconn. She is so sweet and respectful. Lectures are only hard for students to watch because the class is at 8am not because she is boring. but she is extremely smart and passionate about what she talks about, and I love going to this class!
She is an absolute sweetheart! So funny. Her exams are very straightforward. If you put in any sort of effort, you will do well. Wants you to succeed.

Such dry lectures especially at 8am. Super passive aggressive and never even lets the other instructor get a word in. The one time Dr. Bernier Carney taught the class when Dr. Mayerson was out, it was 10x more interesting. It sucks that she is the only professor teaching this course because I can't take another semester of this hell.

Lots of homework, she doesn't announce things on email only in class, test heavy, and lots of content. This stuff is very dry and so is her teaching style. Only nice thing is the exams have the same questions as the homework (ATI & MyLab).

Professor Mayerson is nice but her lectures for 3100 and 3110 are very dry and early in the morning. Both classes were online and the grading was clear and fair. 3 exams, all multiple choice, all questions taken from homework. Extra credit for coming to class. Easy class as long as you do the work and review HW questions before exams.
okay professor. not the most interesting lecturer at times, but has really clear expectations. is easily available to communicate with and is a pleasant lady. just do your work and you will be fine

This class was online for Fall 2020, but overall it was a good class. ATI assignments and MyLab assignments every week with power points summarizing each chapter. Professor Mayerson is very knowledgable, but she needs to keep her politics out of the classroom. She made her side clear when it had nothing to do with the content.

Professor Mayerson was hands down the best professor I have had at UConn. She made the class enjoyable with out it being overwhelming. Weekly group discussion board posts, and every other week short journal entries. 3 exams, 25 questions each, all multiple choice. Easy A if you just do your work. Very easy A, she tells you what exactly to study.

she made a big improvement in her teaching skills. the class isn't an easy A, but nursing school isn't easy. people are complaining that she's horrible, but she's not. if u don't study, u won't do well. last 2 exams were FAIR. people just like to complain and blame the fact they didn't do well on others, but not admit they didn't put in the effort

While she may have made mistakes at the beginning of the year, she has used feedback from students and has restructured the class. The textbooks are expensive ($330 for a print package or $300 for an e-package) you can easily find these on Amazon and rent them. Exams are pretty fair if you come to class and take notes on what she says.

This is the second course I have taken with Professor Derevyagin. The course has 5 quizzes (drop the lowest), a midterm and a final. Quiz problems are taken directly from homework and he outlines the types of exam questions ahead of time. Overall, he is a great professor who gives many examples, and I would recommend.
Made class engaging and fun.

Graded on 5 quizzes (drop the lowest), 2 tests, and a final. He has a very dry sense of humor that I very much appreciated. Posts notes online but would still recommend going to lecture. He was very encouraging and genuine, an overall solid professor.

Maksym is the GOAT. He explains concepts so well that I didn't even need to study for any of my midterms this semester and have gotten a 100 on both midterms thus far. He is so funny and caring of his students and even gives out candy if you correct him. He is the absolute best professor ever and I am so lucky to have had the GOAT professor.

He's a nice guy, but his teaching isn't engaging and he kinda just does the problems during lecture without explaining what he's doing. Would not recommend if you're not a math type person or if you have no prior experience with Calculus, because personally I relied on my knowledge from high school to get through this class.

Maksym is a really nice, unintentionally funny guy and he clearly cares about his students. There are probably better professors from a teaching standpoint as he does mumble and will sometimes do a problem wrong and have to backtrack, but generally he teaches alright. Learning from the textbook outside of class is useful.
It was an okay class, big lectures, terrible room. Having discussions helped. Dr. D did a pretty good job. Used his lectures to cram for exams.
He is really nice and was helpful during his office hours.

Maksym is a nice guy but a bad professor. He mumbles through his explanationswhich arent good or thorough to begin with. Most of the class stopped attending lectures after the first exam and most people just learned from the McArdle pre-recorded videos he uploaded to HuskyCT. Dont take Maksym unless you already have a good calc 2 understanding.

1) no homework that is graded, only quizzes using questions directly from the homework so you can't afford to do poorly on them. 2) have to teach yourself Mathematica because he doesn't teach you nor does he give help on how to code. His answer is "use the help button". 3) Lecture you are left confused with no explanations. Basically teach yourself
Absolute worst so depressing in class. Does not care. A joke

The quizzes were similar to the hw's, just different numbers. Exams are fairly easy as long as you go back and study the homeworks. Answers questions during office hours, and his lectures go over many examples, which is helpful in math. A super nice professor. Posts his lecture notes on huskyct, but I recommend going to lecture still.

The math part of the class was very similar to 2410Q, and the exams were really similar to the hw, just w diff numbers. The writing portion was overwhelming if you leave it for the last minute (as I did every time), but he gave clear feedback on the drafts and his office hrs were helpful for clarifying what I didn't understand. Great choice!

The course is straightforward about what will happen and what is assigned. The course was difficult for me because it was basically all online and there were many lectures. Participation in Piazza is a must and there is a pretty large amount of homework weekly. Prof. Derevyagin was only available during office hours.

I had him for MATH3146 and MATH3710W, he was excellent. he may seemed annoyed at times, but he does whatever he can to make sure students understand the material, always asking "is it more or less clear" during lectures. he grades VERY leniently, not taking many points off for wrong answers. i would take him again in a heartbeat

Prof. Derevyagin was barely present, to be honest. He didn't do any grading and I can tell my TA was pushed to do all of it. During this online course, he uploaded lecture videos from another professor and you really didn't get to hear from him besides his office hours. He seemed a bit annoyed when students asked for help during office hours.

Derevyagin is clearly disconnected from students in his class. This course has been extremely difficult for me. I feel as if he has done very little to offer any additional help despite some very brief office hours. The only resource we have is lectures taught by another professor and nothing more. Just rugged individualism.

1131Q was taught entirely online/asynchronous this semester. Hardly talked to him the whole semester as his office hours were unhelpful ("How do YOU think you would solve it?"). He occasionally answered questions on Piazza but that was rare. 1131Q was just not a great course this semester, don't think the prof matters too much when it's all online

Interesting guy, however he says "bless you" almost every time someone sneezes so he gets some brownie points for that. Pretty chill guy and posts notes online so its okay if you miss a class or two. However you take a lot of notes in an hour and 15 min. Depending on the TA you get, some suck so I suggest forming study groups with friends.

The exams were a bit long but he was a very lenient grader. The writing portfolio was easy and gave students free rein of their topic of choice. In order to succeed, be aware that you need to put some thought into the assignments. He is always there to help if need be. The textbook was only needed if you take the W course.

Dr. Blackman Carr is a really great lecturer. Our grade was based on a midterm, final, semester long group project, and a few small assignments. The content is not super difficult and if you study the learning objectives you will do fine on exams. She is a harsh grader on assignments so make sure to be extremely thorough and follow the rubric.

If you are going to lectures and reading the textbook, this class is not bad. There are a few exams and they are on lockdown browser in person, but they are majority multiple choice and not difficult questions. Definitely a doable class and the homework assignments are easy.

This course honestly was not that bad. As long as you keep up with the notes and go to lectures, you should be fine. Yes, this course was very content heavy, but it was not difficult content. You have to put in the work for the grade you want, but this should not be a class to stress over if you're keeping up with it.

Unreasonably difficult for a 1000 level course. Lectures are droning and she just reads directly off her slides. You need to know virtually everything on the lecture slides for the exams. Do not take the course if it would bother you to do 2 projects where you track every single thing you eat for 24 hours. Homeworks are easy, projects are tedious.

I'm a stem major, I know hard courses, i've taken hard courses. This is an INTRO COURSE. She's to content dense, she barely communicates, and she makes her exams impossible. She also purposely leaves sections of her slides blank to make class mandatory AND refused to send them when I was sick with covid. DO NOT TAKE HER.
Just don't take this professor trying to saves lives... Period

This class was a lot! Yes, it was a ton of work, however, I learned so much during the process and my view of food has changed entirely. While, I do agree that Professor Blackman Carr is a strict, and the lectures can sometimes feel long, I met with the TA and she was helpful. I got a 40% on the midterm and then got 98% on the final.

I would discourage anyone from taking this course with professor carr. She lacks heavily when it comes to communication. She has so many slides and only reads off of them and never expands knowing how much information needs to be covered. She needs to be fired and stop putting grades at risk. An intro-level course should not be this complex.

The people who complain about this class are the ones that don't study and expect to just slide by. This was one of my favorite classes this semester but it does require you to put in some outside class time studying material because there is a lot of memorization. There are only 5 homework assignments and 3 exams but the lowest gets dropped.
