Professor Carr made a 1000 level course much harder than it should have been. The course is mainly graded off of 3 exams where the lowest grade is dropped. Each exam covers a hefty amount of material and are focused on the most minuscule details from each chapter. As for her lectures, she rushes through content and mainly reads from the slides.

Class graded almost exclusively by exams. Refused to allow me to take an exam at a later date following the death of a family member, stating that I had provided "no reasonable rationale" for why I would need to take the exam at a later date.

Not easily accessible outside of class and wants you to meet with TA before her. She can be condescending/ short and not very approachable. Does not grade anything timely especially for the project that build on itself you have to submit the next step without feedback from the previous submissions. Overall not a great experience.

Where to start. Reads directly off slides, hard grader, is not accessible outside of class, extremely condescending when talking with students, awful class structure, hasn't graded anything in months, and poor pacing. If you don't need this class, don't take it, it's that simple.

She isnt that bad, easy at first with basic nutrition then gets super hard. do not go to lecture just make quizlets on her slideshows. she does read them off wordforword. exams are a mix of easy questions with lowkey hard questions espeically during the second half of the semester. second midterm is actually hard.

worst professor I've had. so unreliable with emails and course content. exams are a guess on what to study, so be ready to read 1,000 slides. grades extremely hard and gives no specification or reminders on due dates in class. if you don't do well on exams you'll get a C because of how hard the grading scheme for individual and group projects are.

horrible. She does not state when assignments are due. Grades assignments way too harshly. Class isn't really mandatory because while there she will just read off her slides word for word which she will post anyway.

Mediocre professor at best. Can be nice at times but honestly avoid this class unless you are dietetics/NUSC DPD. Take literally anything else as an upper-level nutrition elective. Grades assignments way too harshly after stating several times that the class is "not a graduate-level class." Boring content. MCB 2000 was more enjoyable than this.

Worst teacher I've had in my lifetime. Asked for the simplest of favors through email multiple times and was never granted any of them. Tests are impossible as she won't tell you what's on them. No homework or projects really. DO NOT TAKE unless you are good at memorizing hundreds of slides word for word. Alsothe class seems really easy first bewar

This was the worst class I've ever taken. The assignments and homework are easy but there's only 6 homework's and 2 assignments, so you have to do well on her exams. She doesn't specify at all what will be on the exam even if you ask so get ready to study hundreds of slides. Don't bother showing up either she reads off the slides that are posted.

Very lecture heavy class and doesn't give many assignments or extra credit opportunities so it is hard to get a good grade unless you really do well on exams. Hard to memorize everything on her slides. Professor is not the most accessible but does reply to emails; does not give any feedback on how you can do better.

The teacher was nice but I only took this class as an elective. He always recorded the lectures which I appreciated and the discussions on Fridays were short but if you didn't understand the material, it definitely sets you back. If you're taking this class as an elective, DO set time aside for this class, or else you will have a hard time (I P/F).

Lectures always seemed so common sense, but then the tests were surprisingly hard. The textbook is not necessary though, and you can find it online for free. Adler himself is very kind and a good lecturer. Lectures were either extremely interesting or quite boring depending on the topic - which is very broad.

Dr. Adler is one of the best professors I've had here at UConn. He tries to make his class interesting even though it can sometimes be very lecture-heavy. His tests aren't too tricky if you study but they do cover a lot of material. Dr. Adler really cares about his students, he's the kind of guy who if you talk to him he'll never forget your name.

Prof Adler was a great professor. His lectures were pretty interesting and he also posted them online after so it wasn't mandatory to come to class. The midterm and the final do make up the majority of the grade but if you study you should be fine.

Adler is fantastic. His Lithic Technology class was incredibly reading heavy, but every reading is needed to pass. In depth and incredibly knowledgeable. Very few assignments, and the class is very open discussion. He's super fair in grading, and reachable outside of class. If you ask for help or let him know you're struggling, he will support you.

Very self-important and condescending. When students ask questions, he usually doesn't know the answer, so he spouts off some random semi-related info that doesn't help at all. The lectures are really interesting though. He does a lot of guest lecturers. The labs are a bit too long for the class period given. The exams are multiple choice.

Asynchronous BUT Two 1-2 Hour Lectures per week - in video format only. Discussion post and 2 replies due at 5:00PM EST instead of 11:59PM EST. Readings consist of 4-5 LONG archaeological papers PER WEEK. Final paper is 10 pages AND there is still a final exam. DO NOT TAKE unless you really really really really really really like Neanderthals.

Lecture way too much info to the point where it would be more productive to halve the book and assign textbook readings. Assigns current event readings. Graded by testing 2-3 tests followed by the final which is cumulative. Covers general history of archaeology from Ussher to modern relics. Memorization required. Tests are MC, 5 EC if he feels it.

Great class if you want to learn the timeline from early humans in Prehistoric Europe to neanderthals. Slides cover 60-75% of the general material while article readings cover the rest. Textbook is supplemental unless you need more context. Fair dude, watched documentaries and movies sometimes, lectures can be hard to take in, and 4-5 tests overall

I took his lithics class having no prior experience in the subject. It was not an easy class, and you have to do the readings. That is an absolute non-negotiable. But the professor is knowledgeable and wants you to succeed, and if you work for it, you will.

I took this class and thought it would be interesting but personally, found it extremely boring. The lectures are thick with information and you are responsible to knowing all the info off of twenty, 30 slides presentations for the midterm. Final is cumulative. I just felt lost with what to study. I found Adler unlikable, but he knows his stuff.

Reads off the powerpoints that he will post onto HuskyCT. Two very easy assignments. Midterm was very hard, provides NO study guide, the review session he told us everything is "fair game" TA's can't really help you on the exam as well. Final was a little less hard. Assigned readings but you don't need to read

Dr. Adler is a Harvard-trained archaeologist who is highly knowledgeable about his field. He can come across as cold and very opinionated, but he is approachable and willing to speak with students. The class is an easy A as long as you attend lecture and spend some time studying the terms and concepts before exams.

Dr. Adler is great. He's funny, knows his stuff, and super helpful. He has 2 exams (midterm 30%, final 40%, 10% participation, 20% 2 assignments). Working in groups in discussion is horrible, but the TAs are great (Ashley and Alex). He uses lots of guest lecturers who can be really cool. STUDYING and attending lecture are the only way you'll pass.

Midterm is 30% of your grade, and the final is 40%. The rest is done in section. Even though lectures aren't mandatory, they're really interesting and worth attending for that reason alone. Plus, they help on the exams.

2 assignments in lecture, midterm, and final. The lectures aren't very helpful, you're going to have to study a lot outside of class. Both exams are all multiple choice but don't let that fool you into thinking it'll be an easy A. In lab/discussion you play with rocks and talk. Assignment 1 is pretty quick and easy, assignment 2 is a 4 page essay.

Attend the lectures and you'll do decently but you need to study if you want to get a really good grade. There are two exams and two assignments. The assignments are pretty easy. You can get by without the book but it doesn't cost that much.

I know people have said it's an easy A but it's not. Attendance is mandatory as mentioned, but the midterm and final ask detailed questions which often you did not even have in your notes. The lectures are also extremely dull. Discussion is mandatory but isn't bad at all and will help to boost your grade.

Attendance mandatory, no slides on huskyCT. If you take good notes then exams are really easy. Exams multiple choice so that is a plus. Never cracked the book so dont waste your money. Overall a good class with a good professor

Prof. Adler is a very engaging professor. Go to class, take notes like crazy, and always go to discussion! He's a great teacher and his material is interesting! Clearly passionate about the subject. Easy A is attainable if you go to class and take your time on the multiple choice tests. I would recommend this teacher!
I loved the way she set up the class and lectures were easy to follow. I wish she stayed at UCpnn! She went to Quinnipiac.

I go to Quinnipiac cause she teaches there now. Awful teacher. Expects so much of a entry level course for freshman. No, you should not be studying 6-9 hours for an entry level class regarding the easiest part of business. Bad professor. Needs to understand how to teach at a 110 level. Not at a junior course level.

Professor Fisher is my favorite professor at UCONN, she honestly cares about her students and doesn't really care about attendance but if you don't show up it'll be harder to get an A, show up to her class every day and write down what she writes down and you'll get an A easy. Lots of my friends only showed up for quizzes and tests , still got A's
Expect to put in a lot of work to do well but it was an easy class.

she assigns seats but if you askanswer at all you get extra credit. goes over graphs in class n you must read to get a good grade. quizzes are easy and she drops the lowest threedrops the lowest three hw's. learn the vocab. pay attention to the graphs. such an easy class. never got an A on an exam but got an A in the class. she is so nice too.
Pretty good
Professor Fisher is very nice and wants to help. Was a little scrambled in class. Did not make the material easy to understand. I taught myself from the book.

she is really a tough grader, I think she should focus on how to teach students, not only assign students do so much work, every chapter's reading check and homework, and the quiz in discussion. Besides, the reading check is not really helpful to students, the reading check is supposed to check whether students understand the material,not just read

Weekly pop quizzes based on (1) that weeks reading (focus on vocab) and (2) application problems from the previous week. Usually 2 or 3 multiple choice and an application problem. Lowest 3 are dropped. These quizzes can make or break your grade! The exam is mostly based on what is taught in lectures, so attend lecture and take good notes

Very straightforward class. Most of your grade comes from weekly quizzes which are easy if you do the homework and go to lecture and pay attention for part of the class. Very Generous with dropping of quizzes, homework, and poor of discussion attendance. Extremely accessible for office hours which are incredibly useful. Really cares about students

She wants her students to understand the material. Quizzes were 40% of your grade, and we had one each week (dropping lowest 3). They were easy if you studied for them. The two midterms were only 10% of your grade each but I would advice you to study for them. She is always available for extra help and is pretty interesting during lecture.

Linda is my favorite teacher so far at UCONN. She really cares about her students and makes the lectures interesting. She is willing to give you whatever time you need for extra help. Her weekly quizzes keep me on target and participation keeps the class interesting.

Quizzes are 40%. most of the people complaining probably didnt do the reading. I really wanted to learn econ so I made sure to do it and got a 100 on every one so I only needed a D+ on the final to get an A. Her grading makes it SO easy for those who make an effort, but she really can't teach. Self taught class, but really understandable textbook.

She gives in lecture quizzes which takes away from her lecture time. I learned the majority of the material from my TA and from teaching myself. She cares about her students a lot, but makes you have assign seats. Doesn't know how to handle a class of 350, students don't respect her. Since she's a new professor, she doesn't know how to make exams.

She has no filter, so she would say things during lecture that were outright offensive. However, it is an easy A. Exams aren't tricky; if you show up and do the readings you should be able to get at least a B. Quizzes every Monday (lecture was Mon Wed) on material that you cover later in the week. They are 40% of your grade, so gotta read.

Without a doubt the worst professor I have had since studying at UCONN. Only professor to even waste time giving you assigned seats in a 300 person lecture hall and requiring Lecture participation points. Takes pointless points off of your quizzes and exams if your hand drawn graphs aren't at a correct slope. DO NOT TAKE EVER take online if can.

Linda is the worst professor I have ever has at UConn. Her 300 person lecture has assigned seats and participation counts. There are quizzes almost every lecture, but they are inconsistent. Her lecture is full of handwritten, confusing notes and teaches the class similar to pre school. She is an easy grader, but don't expect to learn anything.

Lectures are long and boring. Assigned seats. Instead of doing PowerPoint she does live notes which leads to a lot of mistakes on her parts. Quizzes every week that are either very hard or very easy. Quizzes are on Monday on material she goes over after the exam and on Wednesday. Material she teaches is straight from the book. TA saved me.

Linda is by far my favorite professor at uconn. she makes everything easy and is really funny, also. she gives quizzes every week but it makes studying for the exam that much easier. always willing to give extra help and she inspired me to switch my major to economics. if you take econ with anyone, take it with her!

Lots of quizzes and assigned seats. Sometimes tough to understand but the online HW and reading can teach you all you have to know. Exams and quizzes are super easy if you skim the chapter. Actually is a nice woman who is more than willing to help and adapt to students' needs.

I loved her! She is a great prof. It was at 8AM 3 times a week and I went to most of them. Easy gen ed but it was actually really interesting and fun to learn. Go see your exams after grades come out, and write down the ones you got wrong because it's likely you will see it on the midterm/final. Really good class overall, definitely recommend it!

SUPER easy class and its actually really interesting. i took it just as a gen ed but you learn about things like brain tram and speaking disabilities - stuff i just didnt know about. Brom is a great teacher and tells you exactly what to expect on the tests

Seriously, the easiest class that could possibly ever exist. Even though I'm a PNB major, she makes the class interesting, fun, and easy. One thing, you have to go to class, she tells you what's on the exam and rewards those that go with extra credit. The first and only class where my final grade was greater than a 100. haha.

Take Intro CDIS with her!! Most straight-forward and fair class I have ever taken. Tells you exactly what will be on the test so you really can't go wrong! Just pay attention in class and study one to two days before the test. She makes class interesting by telling about her own work experiences and applying everything to real life.

She's a really good teacher - tells you exactly what's going to be on every exam so there's no reason to not get an A in the class. The class is interesting and I learned a lot. And she gives several extra credit opportunities. If you're taking CDIS1150, DEFINITELY take it with Deb Brom!

AMAZING teacher. She not only teaches the material, but makes it interesting as well. I actually enjoyed going to class at 8am because of her! You do not need the book if you go to class...everything is on huskyCT, however she teaches information in class that is not online. By far one of the best teachers and classes at UConn!

The class was the first 8AM that I've ever happily attended and hated missing. She is passionate on the subject and beyond interesting. If you go and listen you'll do great in the class. Also she is incredible and I've openly admitted to my girlfriend I have a crush on her (My girlfriend does as well). Professor Brom, I adore you. You are awesome.

This class is SO easy. You don't need the book if you attend class, but I stopped going after the first exam (which I aced) and still got a B+ on the second exam. She puts the slides online and tells you what to study for the exams. Easy A, take it for a GPA boost
Extremely easy class. The tests are straightforward and going to lecture will help. Don't buy the textbook you do not need it.

She is very fair. Her tests come right from the study guides. She gives a lot of extra credit and you do not need the textbook. She is also extremely helpful if you are interested in the communication disorders field.
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!! Loved the class! Very interesting, teacher is amazing! Easiest A you can get! (you don't need the textbook either)

This class is really enjoyable, the professor is amazingly nice and she is great at teaching and explaining the material. Going to class is important because she explains her slides in more detail and tells you what is going to be on the test. I never knew that Communication Disorders could be so interesting!

She is very helpful, and loves what she is teaching. I would recommend this class to anyone. Especially with her! She is very sweet and cares about her students. She gives extra credit and puts her notes up online, however, I do recommend going to class because she discusses material that are not posted. Getting an A/A-/Bt is not hard at all.

Very straight forward helpful professor. She puts all her notes online. Gives enough extra credit to raise your grade a letter grade. Tests arent too difficult and you get 2 chances on each quiz. Make sure you go to class because she goes over her notes in detail which arent seen online. Overall an easy a if you go to class and put a little time in

dont buy the book for starters. everything is on huskyct but shell explain it really well in class. not hard, she gives extra credit, 2 chances on homework, and will tell you what is on the test. if you dont mind an 8am shes a great teacher and if you do your work its literally impossible to do worse than a B-

Her interest and passion for the subject is keeps the entire class alert. She encourages everyone to consider a career in speech pathology and, after taking her class, I think I will consider it! She shows you videos from YouTube as examples for each lecture and DOES go over test material in class that is not in the notes, so don't skip class!

She knows what she's talking about, and has an interest in it which helps. It's a great class, even if it's not something you're thinking about pursuing. We didn't even open the textbook, but on the bright side everything you need to know is right in the slides she presents. And she throws the students who attend class hints about the tests!

Don't buy the book for CDIS 1150! I'm kinda ticked that she even told us to get it because it's completely useless. Aside from that the class is super easy. Go to the lectures and skim over the slides she posts on HuskyCT before the tests. Easy A.

This is a great class to take for a Gen Ed. She tells you exactly what you need to know for the tests, so it come down to you spending a half an hour the night before the test memorizing everything. It's as simple as that, and because the class is no cumulative, it's even easier. She is a real sweet heart too. Fun class, would surely recommend.

I took this class originally to fill a content area and to get some easy credits but it turned out being my favorite class to go to. Deb was a great teacher keeping me interested and attending class got me A's on all the exams. GREAT CLASS AND TEACHER

Every day Prof. Joo would start by telling us he hoped we were staying healthy. He truly cared about the material and his students. The class had a lot of writing but that's to be expected for a W class. I think things could have been graded a little more efficiently. The labs could be hard but our TA really cared about helping us through them.

In the first book of the Bible, Genesis, "God made man in his own image" and Prof Joo is the living embodiment of the Word of God. This man will not only bless your grades, but your soul down to your bone I would happily die for this man. He will do everything he can to bring you success, and will help you with whatever you need. Best professor!!

If you want a good GRADE in physics, take Joo. Exams are literally questions taken EXACTLY from the lecture slides, numbers are kept the same and everything. Memorize the problems he shows you in lecture and you'll get A's on the exams. Tons of partial credit is given if you go and see the exam grader and complain. You won't learn but you'll pass!
If you spend time to watch ppt, then you can get a good score.

Lectures are unbelievably bad, he walks in a consistent 5 minutes late and reads PowerPoint slides without additional explanation. De taught the whole class without writing a single word and will half solve a problem without getting a numerical answer if asked, never posting anything online. Clickers are listed in the syllabus but were never used.

Your grade is based on the performance of your peers so it's a blood bath to try and get an A in this class. Lectures are very boring. he walks in wearing navy blue and a cup of water. He never posts any of the solutions to the practice exams so bless your heart if you know what's going on
I really confuse that why he can get the rate of 4.1 at the beginning of this semester. Useless lecture, hard assignment and unreasonable grader. If you like anyone, he will be the best choice.

Just 20% of students in his class can get A or A-, so if you miss any lab or make any mistake in the three exams, you will be B+ or B. And if you are not good in physics, you will absolutely get C. Even his homework is more helpful than his class and the homework is really hard.
GOOD LUCK!

Lectures are basically him reading PowerPoints posted online, he never will actually do examples or show how to use equations. The grading scale described by others means you have no idea what your grade will be before the course is over, and when you ask about your individual grade he responds "It doesn't matter" and refers you to the syllabus.

Exams may be graded tough but they are the same problems that you did in HW and solved on the doc cam. Exams are a big part of your grade and Dr. Joo makes sure to solve as many problems on the doc cam as he can before the exams, he may even tell you some of the problems on the exams. Labs depend on your TA.
Goes over all the important problems on the doc cam. HW problems are recycled onto the exams so make sure you attend all lectures for some free points.

Straight forward class. You put in the work for a 4 credit class and you would easily get an A. Dr. Joo makes his exams similar to practice problems and some of them are even told to you in advance if you attend the lectures. The first exam had around 6/20 questions that were literally showed to us before the exam. Clickers20%

Prof. Joo has a grading scale. The bottom 20% of the class gets an F. The next 20% of the class gets a D, and so on. This is not fair because if the whole class got A's on an exam (highly unlikely) the lower A's will fail. He speeds through powerpoint slides and is very hard to understand. Khan Academy will be your best friend. AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!
Dr. Joo is an incredible physics teacher. The best at UConn and better than I had at other schools as well. His knowledge of physics and ability to explain concepts is literally unparalleled.
Beware: He curves DOWN if grades are "too high." I got a 95, and he gave me an A-!! Also, lectures are extremely boring and unhelpful. Read the textbook if you want to understand anything.

Does not care about this class. Was gone the entire last month. Didn't even post a practice test to tell students what was on final exam. VERY defensive. Most important: CURVED DOWN. A 95 was an A- and a 93 was a B+. Clearly shows no concern for students' grades or learning. This class is his lowest priority.
not great teaching ability. TA's were much better as well as sub lecture teachers

At times difficult to understand. Homework problems sets are difficult and take a long time to complete, but definitely help in your overall grade. Posted lectures online ahead of time. Exams are kind of tricky. In the end, I think he was a bit of a pushover b/c I ended up with an A-, when clearly my calculable grade didn't yield the same letter.
well organized lecture.

Prof. Finger is a wonderful professor and a kindhearted person. The class is really interesting and she cares about the subject and how we play a role in media literacy. There are some written assignments (blog posts) and a final project, but she's a very fair grader and gives good feedback. A+ class would def take as a gen-ed.

Dr. Finger is AWESOME! She made this E course so interesting and really made it fun to learn about German environmental studies. She makes half the classes online, let's you do almost any project you want, and is SO flexible with attendance. She is honestly one of the best professors I've ever had. She is a bit quirky but it works so well!!

Anke's class was my favorite to go to every Tuesday and Thursday. I took Contemporary in Germany and Anke makes the class more about the culture and what we could learn from Germany. She includes a lot of her own family history in the class which I found interesting. She does give a participation grade. Love Anke wish I could have her again.

Professor Finger is an incredibly kind and well educated professor. I took Germany in Contemporary Europe and found it to be really interesting. It is a very chilled out and lowkey class with a lot of freedom about what is discussed. The assignments are very open ended and easy to stay on top of. Would 100% recommend this course and professor

Professor Finger is a very nice and respectful person. There were a couple of fun group projects in this class and down to earth group discussions on Blackboard every week, you just have to answer in a couple of hundreds of words and respond to a few of your classmates, sometimes Professor Finger replies to you.

Great professor. Had her a few years back. I just wouldn't recommend you use her as a source for recommendations if you want to apply for grad school. I asked for recs for a few schools in August (2020), and she still hasn't done them. It's February 2021. If you have other sources, I would recommend using them over her if you could.

Professor Finger is one of the kindest professors I have met, she genuinely likes teaching and seeing her students succeed. However, the class just was not for me. I am a STEM major and the readings and group projects were not a fun time for me, but if you enjoy debating, discussions, and group projects then you would probably enjoy the class.

Discussion-based so make sure to show up and get credit. Weekly quizzes based on vocab. 2 group projects but not too bad. Do the readings and comment on the discussion board. Final exam was a short essay. She's responsive and understanding. Gives easy-to-follow instructions. Great class all around with engaging discussions.

Professor Finger is a caring professor who's intentional with the course. She's very nice and the lectures are worth going to. Weekly (ish) quizzes based on homework, not too difficult but it's easy to get one or two wrong and there are only 5 questions. Definitely a class that's applicable to our current world so it's very interesting.

Professor Finger is seriously one of the best professors I've had so far. She is so caring, and literally the nicest woman ever!! The class requires some reading, and group projects, but they are super manageable! Stress-free class, especially online, she makes it fun too!!

The professor was easy to access outside of class and she gave lots of feedback. However, the class was boring and fairly difficult. The reading was insane and rarely used in the other class work. The directions for all the projects were vague and the due dates on the syllabus rarely matched the ones in HuskyCT. It was easy for an honors though

Professor Finger is a very nice lady and you can tell she cares a lot about her class and her students. The class itself was pretty unorganized and without any sort of structure: dates on the syllabus rarely matched the due dates on HuskyCT and her grading criteria were never explained. I often found it difficult to keep up. Teacher good, class bad
Very easygoing class and teacher. There is weekly quizzes but as long as you read and know your stuff, you'll be fine.

She did not answer emails quickly, which was annoying since it was an online class. She assigned really long papers and a lot of readings. Way too much work for a 3-credit class. Also likes to assign group projects.

Professor Finger is one of my favorite professors at UConn! She is really sweet, helpful, and cares about her students. The class was really interesting and she takes attendance and factors it into your grade so you have to go to class. As long as you do the assigned readings, attend class, and do the blogs, you will do great in her class!

This class was random, but really interesting. I took it as an elective for my minor, so I guess I thought there was a bit too much reading for a course that many people take as an elective, but other than that, I can't complain. Exams are easy, discussion can be interesting, content is useful in real life. Prof. Finger stimulates student interest

This is a pretty easy class if you show up all the time (she takes attendance) and do the blogs after each class. If you do the work, you'll get an easy A, if you don't you'll struggle. The textbook is really wordy but it helps clarify some concepts. She shows a lot of movies. She is a great professor who really engages the class. Best professor!

She was a very nice person and the class was relatively interesting, however there was absolutely no structure to the class. We had no assignments and the lectures were random and useless. She made us buy 50 dollars worth of textbooks to tell us that we didn't need them. Do not take this honors core. All this class is is frustrating.

Truly one of the best professors I've had at UCon. Not only very nice and willing to help, as well as patient with her students, she motivates her students. She encourages them to not only improve their German, but other life skills, such as public speaking. Extremely smart lady, effective teacher, nice person...she's got it all!

This professor is absolutely amazing. Best professor I have ever had. I had no idea what this class was going to be like and it turned out to be my favorite class. She takes attendance which is the only downfall but the class is worth going too. Easy exams if you study. Teaches in a simple way you don't realize how much you have learned.

Very enthusiastic and energized during lectures. Is generally a funny and smart guy. Very harsh grader and has an intense final presentation. His teaching style is very informative and will learn alot however is a generally tough class.

Prof. Ghaddar is one of the best. He lectures well and keeps students engaged better than most. He uses great examples too. Assignments actually benefit learning, although I will say there is a lot of work. My friends in the online section are bored while I actually enjoy going to class, which says a lot (usually I get really bored). Take him!

Taking my business capstone course with Professor Ghaddar was a smart decision. He has a wealth of knowledge in strategy. What I particularly liked was his lecture style as he blended theory with practical advice and anecdotes from real-world business settings. If you want to challenge yourself and learn a ton, take MENT 4900 with Ghaddar!

Terrible course, take with another professor if possible. Assignment criteria for getting an A is never known and expects too much time dedicated to projects. Final presentation you get questioned heavily in front of class. Encourages participation but argues with students on whether or not they're right, which discourages paticipation. L professor

This was the best class I took at Uconn. Ive never seen a professor more passionate about the material and passionate about making lectures interesting, engaging, and relating the topics to real life. I loved everything about this class and wish I could take it again. This class is demanding, but I have learned more from it than any other here.
Very condescending and insane amounts of work.

The whole semester is just watching a power trip. Enjoys stressing students out by nitpicking presentations and cases, acts like his class is the biggest deal of all time and that he's the smartest guy in the world. VERY hard to get an A.

Above all else, DUDE IS A TOUGH GRADER! If you've been getting A's in most other courses, expect to get a B in this one. Only a few items are graded. Group projects are very time-consuming, so beware of procrastination. The final project will test your wits while presenting and your ability to defend your work. Overall, very difficult to get an A
Genuinely the most stressful class I've ever taken. I constantly feel like I'm not doing anything right. It is so hard to know what he's looking for in assignments.

He cares about his students a lot and his lectures are very engaging and interesting, he gives lots of examples to help you remember things. However, it is not an easy A. He's the type of teacher that only gives A if you go above and beyond, but an A is def achievable. He doesn't let you have laptops in class so bring a notebook for notes!

Arrogant. Exams have purposely tricky questions with confusing wording to make sure you get things wrong even if you studied for hours. His proud philosophy of "I rarely give out A's" is exhausting, and makes you feel like you shouldn't even bother trying if you know he won't like it anyway. I recommend any other professor for this course.

The amount of assignments in this class is UNREAL! Most amount of work I have EVER had in all of college but super ironic because he NEVER gets assignments graded in a timely manner. Majority of the time you have no idea what you are doing in the class. He cold calls on people so make sure you participate. He is really engaging but can be cocky.

His lectures are great & engaging, you will learn a lot. But it's a hard class and requires a lot of work. The 3 group projects (financial analysis, marketplace simulation, & final presentation) will be frustrating if you don't have good partners (senioritis beware). Midterm exam was MC and challenging. He also grades participation & 3 case papers.

Sami was my favorite professor I've had at UConn. His lectures are engaging and interesting, and he really cares about making sure students understand the material. Definitely need to put effort into this course, but it's very manageable! Highly recommend taking his class!

Although he can be a harsh grader, he really wants you to succeed. I have learned so much and have improved on certain skillsets that I was insecure about before. 1 midterm, 2 group projects, simulation, and 3 case studies. If you want an easy A, do not take him. If you want to learn and put in effort, definitely take him!

Professor Ghaddar is an amazing teacher. He's certainly a tough grader, but if you put in the effort to attend class and try your hardest it's very difficult to receive a bad grade. He cares about seeing his students learn and succeed, and certainly maintains a great attitude about everything he is teaching.

He is very engaging and seems to have a genuine interest in his students, my favorite prof at UConn. The class is very group-work heavy, I was lucky enough to get put in a great one. A good grade isn't difficult if you put considerable time into the few assignments that there are (I often spent multiple hrs/week w/ my group). He is a slow grader.

Sami is well-educated, experienced and provides engaging lectures that I always looked forward to. The assignments are difficult and he is not an easy grader. Although, he is very accessible and always willing to help students no matter what. Be sure to really understand concepts and read the book before the exam and start on assignments early.

Best prof I've had at UConn. Definitely not an easy A but genuinely will learn so much. Extremely accessible outside of class and actually cares about students. No laptops in class but you will never get distracted due to his high energy. Breaks concepts down and makes sure you actually understand them. If you put the work in you will gain a lot.

Sami was honestly my favorite professor all of college. His lectures were interesting and engaging, and I looked forward to going to class. You definitely have to put in some work to get an A, but if you put in the effort its not bad. Sami is all around a great guy, hard to find a professor that actually teaches and genuinely cares like he does.
Her exams were not like her practice which made studying for them difficult. SI instructor was extremely helpful and the only resort for the course.

This professor works at a very fast pace. There is not much time in between chapters to really understand the material. I recommend going to SI sessions 100%. Sometimes it can be difficult to understand her.

Very hard class, but you can do well if you try. There are 4 quizzes, 2 exams, and 1 curved final. 2 quizzes are dropped. SI helps a lot, so I recommend going. There are plenty of extra credit opportunities. Prepare to put a decent amount of time into studying if you want to do well in the course. Practice problems in the textbook are helpful.

Offers extra credit that helps with the difficulty, take advantage of it. 2 of your mini exams get dropped so try to study heavily on the first two because that material is much easier. 2 exams plus the final, final is usually curved because it is standardized which helps. Prepare to put a lot of time outside of class in and use SI and office hours

Doing well in chem1122 with Professor Aguirre is definitely achievable. It definitely requires a lot of outside studying. I definitely recommend going to SI to help understand concepts. I also recommend going over lecture notes after class and reading the book. Some concepts can be difficult to understand so you have to look them up on your own.

She's sweet but this class is excessively hard. Don't go in thinking it will be easy because it's a foundational course, there's lot of difficult information covered in a short period of time. Mini exams and exams are hard. There are a lot of extra credit opportunities though. The final exam is a standardized national exam. Take at a CC if you can.

She expects you to know everything already and treats lectures as a review even though she didn't teach any of it. The material is extremely difficult and you have to teach yourself. Everything you go over in discussion with TA is so different from what you went over in class and is also pretty useless for the mini exams and exams. SI is only help.

Dr Aguirre is a sweet lady but her class is tough. 75% of attendance counts towards your grade. Material is hard but discussion section does help. She offers lots of extra credit and flexible ways of grading that only benefit you. 2/4 of the quizzes are dropped. 2 other exams plus the final. Again, class is hard but she is genuinely so sweet

Her lectures are useless and I have never learned anything from them. She barely explains anything and expects you know everything already. Lost of content learned very quickly. She posts practice exams that are nothing like the actual exams so it makes it very hard to study for. If it wasn't for the SI instructor I would fail this class.
Practically expects you to know everything about chem. She breezes through lectures while everyone is confused. I almost learned everything through my discussion ta.

She has a very thick accent and it is hard to understand her lectures. There are 4 mini exams, 2 exams, and a final. She does not curve the exams, but will drop the lowest 2 (out of 4) mini exams. Attendance is mandatory she uses square cap to track it. Topics are explained more by TAs in discussion which helps.
Professor Aguirre is really caring and intelligent. She is easily accessible. The class was extremely difficult but she did her best. Her lectures are not the best but one-on-one she is helpful.

I love her! She is very caring and truly wants her students to do well. She offers a lot of extra credit and explains things very well both in class and in office hours. She uploads all notes in huskyct but attendance is mandatory for lectures. Chem can be hard but overall she made it pretty easy. Also her accent caused no difficulties.

I personally think she is a great Professor. She does have an accent and speaks a little low sometimes so I recommend sitting in the front. Besides that there are 4 mini exams and 2 tests and she drops the two lowest mini exams. She definitely wants her students to pass and as long as you show effort it is completely doable.

Aguirre was nice and her lectures were fine, nothing special. Only reason I went was because attendance is graded and even then I skipped half the time. It's a hard class and chem is def not my strong suit but the grading is pretty forgiving. Overall lecture and discussion are both useless and I taught myself most of the material lol.

her accent's not as bad as everyone says it is. make sure you do the extra credit, study, etc. it isn't an easy class, but she does explain everything in pretty good depth at least for me. it's not terribly hard, just a lot of information. it covers gen chem, orgo, and biochem, pretty basic stuff. take something else if u need CA3 though.

prof aguirre is a really sweet person, but it is very difficult to understand her lectures sometimes with her accent. tests can be hard but she does have office hours and tutoring available. there is an assignment due sunday each week which can be annoying but are not bad at all. you actually have to attend lecture (participation counts as grade)

Her accent is very thick and hard to understand at times. 8 am lectures had me falling asleep, but as long as you complete all the homework assignments (not bad or lengthy at all) you will do fine. TA's in discussion help to clarify concepts, the project is a big grade booster too. Really liked her grading.

Professor Aguirre is okay. There are 4 mini exams and 2 bigger exams, plus a final. Other than the homework questions, I never opened the book once. Aguirre is very kind though and is great about answering emails and being there when students need academic help. The lectures aren't too hard to follow along and btw she uses iclicker for attendance.

Easy A. All you need to do is attend lecture and discussion and complete the HW. I never opened the textbook besides for the HW questions. Professor Aguirre is easily accessible and is just hard to understand due to her accent. Very understanding and drops the lowest mini exam grade.

If you've taken Stuber's Undergraduate course, you know how this course will go: weekly coding assignments that are difficult. Despite that, Stuber teaches this graduate course much more relaxed and effectively than the Undergraduate. I really enjoyed this course and its very useful material. I would definitely recommend this course.

Exams are hard, but not impossible once you understand the overarching concepts. Start the HW ASAP (only need a 60% to receive credit) and GO TO OFFICE HOURS!!! Entire class is out of 20 points, participation is key. Hardest class in CHEG plan of study.10-12 hours of HW/studying a week minimum required. Read the textbook. Do practice problems!!

Stuber is extremely smart and made use of the entire 75 minute lectures. 4 exams total which made the class more digestible, less content on each. Start the HW ASAP, it takes a while. We got lucky this semester admittedly and had some great TA's. Surely you'll hear horror stories but its not bad. You basically need a 70 on everything to get an A.

This is a very difficult course, because it covers material you actually need to know if you want to be an engineer. Prof Stuber is passionate on the subject and teaches incredibly well. The grades are fair, and you only need 70%> to get an A on assignments, so if you can't hack it in this course, you wouldn't succeed with a different Prof anyway.

Professor Stuber is extremely smart, but half the class is graded on 10 homework assignments that take up >10 hours, per HW. Further, the tests are 4-5 questions and are very difficult. To his credit, you do get 1 sheet of notes for the test. Finally, form a study group and put yourself to work, you get out of the class what you put into the class.

Look, I think Stuber is a great guy, & I've heard he's a good research advisor, but this is just a bad class. It's insanely difficult, but I don't blame him entirely. Could he post his office hours notes for people that have class at that time? Yes. Could he make CHEG Analysis any easier? Besides curving, not really. Get rid of the class, not him

I think Professor Stuber gets a bad rap, but he really isn't that bad. Start the homework early and attend office hours as often as possible. You get what you put into this class. He didn't make it easy, but he forced us to learn the material

This was the hardest class I've taken so far at UConn. Stuber is a very intelligent and honest professor, but this class alone can make junior year fall semester for CHEG students an absolute miserable time. Although the office hours held every day of the week is a huge plus, the homework is insanely difficult. Form a study group, you'll need it.

Stuber is a very smart professor and is very thorough. The class is handled very professionally which deadlines and assignments clear. Despite this, the class is very hard. The coding problems are a little too difficult and you'll need to go to office hours and have a strong study group to succeed. Get old exams, they help a ton.

Stuber's a great guy, it's just the class he teaches makes me want to break my arms. He gives homework every week so be prepared to not know what you're doing. Learn how to code matlab if you can if that advice helps, & for this class, just take whatever Ls come your way & get the out of that class. Scam the homeworks, its your only way to pass

Dr Stuber is a nice guy and a decent teacher, but the class is extremely hard anyway. He has definitely improved his teaching skills from previous reviews in my opinion. Expect 10-15 hours of HW a week minimum. All you need to do is pass and you will never use anything from this class again, which makes it strange the class is a requirement.

Prof. Stuber's first attempt at undergraduate teaching was very rough. Attend class and do every homework, however, office hours are a must on the later homeworks as they only get tougher. A good background in MatLab and linear is helpful. The class will take 8-10 hours of work. Examples given in class were of poor quality. Smart man, poor teacher.

I'm halfway into my semester w/ Stuber, he began pop quizzes to determine who's attending and who isn't on a regular basis. He has office hours every single day of the week. You're going to want to go to all of them. I'm not kidding, move your schedule around, anything you have to do. Homework is very hard. Exams are fair and reflect the homework.

Online Class: System Optimization(basically numerical methods/analysis) Prof. Stuber is a really gifted instructor and you're going to learn things that are ACTUALLY relevant to the real world (companies pay so much for this stuff). PREP lecture+hmwk(3-4h), attend office hrs (1h), and make an 2nd attempt at hmwk (using his feedback). That's it.

This was an awful class. I put in over 12 hours a week working on the homework and doing all of the textbook problems, and still didn't do well. If you have minimal knowledge of matlab (from taking CSE1010), good luck to you. Nothing is explained to you in class, and you have to teach yourself, which is impossible from the textbook.

Smart guy! He's very good answering questions. Start the homework early and use the textbook, then it's not too hard to follow along in class. Take linear algebra beforehand if you can, but just be aware that his exams (and his grading) are almost unreasonably tough. This class requires a lot of time management on your end, but he's super chill.

If you don't already have anxiety from majoring in ChemE, you will after taking this class. Stuber uses a very unhelpful textbook to teach the course and then rewrites the textbook verbatim in lecture. He also writes in tiny handwriting on the board and uses dry erase board markers with barely any ink. You better know MATLAB to pass. Thumbs down :(

One of the worst professors I've ever had, never did a numerical example in class for the "numerical analysis" course. Simply just set up problems using arbitrary variables, every "example" ever done in class was straight from the textbook. He is clearly very passionate and intelligent, however he needs to refine his methods and slow down.

This class is hard, but it's supposed to be . Prof. Stuber definitely got better at teaching as the semester went on. Office hours are essential for completing the HW. Most of the MatLab code needed is given in the textbook - just need to apply it to the HW problems. Linear algebra would have been helpful, but not required to succeed.

Professor Stuber started teaching undergrad this semester, and it wasn't pretty at first. However, he has greatly improved over the semester and I would take his class again. Homework is hard, exams are reasonable. Should definitely take Linear Algebra before taking this course.

She's funny, endlessly kind, keeps classes full of fun activities, and always keeps her students engaged. When we struggled with concepts she was very flexible with dates and quizzes to make sure everyone was adequately prepared, I never would have passed without her kindness, she really wants students to succeed not just in ASL but also in life.

She is very nice but she expects you to know a lot of ASL going into the class and if you don't this class will be difficult. She is really nice when it comes to making up tests if you were sick and she cancels class every so often. It's mostly graded on tests which can be a little hard on your grade.

J-Funny (her ASL name) is really sweet and goofy in class. She really tries to make all students feel comfortable and there are many ways to redo assignments to improve your grades. You will have signing assignments but tests are based on understanding what she signs. I would definitely recommend this class, I really enjoyed it and it is an easy A.

JFunny was such a kind and caring professor. Truly all about introducing you to American Sign Language and having fun with it! I really only showed up to the first 2 online classes and turned everything in late, she gives ample time and opportunity for all assignments - even the quizzes! Highly recommend if you want to know a little more about ASL!

J-Funny was the kindest most caring Professor. Shes really all about introducing you to the language and having fun with it. If you dont do well on assignments or turn them in late she doesnt Mark you for it and gives you endless opportunities to try again. I didnt show up to 80% of our online classes and got an A. Shes very understanding :)

J-Funny is one of the best profs I have had so far at UConn. I had her for ASL 1 and 2 and I always loved going to her class. You need to show up to class to learn or you have to find ways outside of class to learn. She gives quite a few quizzes but she always does practice ones that are basically the same. Easy class with a great prof!!

Prof Hanna was literally the best for ASL, especially with COVID. She made lectures fun and engaging and I learned so much more than I expected to! She's so funny and always makes the material really interesting. Usually just an expressive video and a quiz due each week so it's really not that bad. I'll be taking her again in the spring!! :)

I literally loved this class. At first I was a little worried with it being online and all, but she does such a great job at teaching. With that being said, it's strongly recommended go to class, she reviews the material and allows practice time to really strengthen your skills. She's also super understanding, def recommend !

SUCH a good prof for intro to ASL. Took it not knowing the language at all and Funny taught us clearly. Over zoom it felt like we were in person with her learning. Quizzes every week or so, just go to class and watch, maybe look at textbook vids. Not hard if u practice. Love love love her shes so understanding. Currently have a 103 average :)

J-funny is very enthusiastic. Content comes from the textbook and if you don't practice outside of class it's easy to fall behind and not understand. Quizzes are every two weeks and homework is making short videos where you sign a story or sentences. Exams are easy and she gives partial credit. She lets students decide what to practice in class.

Amazing ASL professor. Fun class, you learn a great deal of the language due to the immersion aspect of the lectures (voices off, sign only). She's the kind of professor where you come to class not just because you need to but because you want to!
Joan was an amazing Asl teacher!!! She truly cares about her students and you will have soooo much fun in her class

Great person! She's hilarious, personable, and wants to be there. Grammar won't be taught, classes are kind of boring and repetitive. You can not show up, never do homework, and probably still pass. She'll make you buy the book but she goes over everything in class. Easy A though, it was a fun class, & she's understanding of other classes you have.
J-Funny is one of the best professors I've had. I genuinely looked forward to every single class. There's lots of activities and games. She makes it really fun.
She is amazing and everyone loves her

Her philosophy is unique. She believes that the best way to learn is to have a little fun and to enjoy the course by practicing our ASL. Her approach helps keeps us motivated and anxious to learn more. She helps us engage in conversation using ASL applying it to real world applications.

J-Funny is the best ASL professor, she makes her classes always a good time so you never feel like you're just sitting there learning material. She's very interactive and makes you feel super comfortable in the class, by far my favorite professor and class! As long as you show up for quizzes and keep up with the material, easy A

My favorite class this semester. A funny professor who engages you in her class. Need to study regularly if you are first being introduced to ASLN. Quizzes occur every chapter. Final and midterm are easy if you prepare for them (Receptive and expressive parts). Will be taking ASLN1102 with her as well. Really recommend her!!!

Joan Hanna (J Funny) has become one of my favorite Instructors at UConn! Right off the bat she makes you feel at ease and comfortable in the environment. As long as you go to class and pay attention you're sure to get a good grade. I learned a lot more than I expected to and am looking forward to moving on to the next level

Joan is so awesome. You learn sign language without even realizing it, that's how easy she makes it. Has weekly quizzes but they're very easy if you go to class and they all have extra credit point options. I got 100+ on all of them. She's the easiest ASL prof!

You just need to apply yourself to receive a good grade. She outlines her expectations of you and if you follow those expectations, you will have no problem. Go to class, pay attention, take notes, and work hard-- as you would in any University setting.
Terrible. It's not an understanding of the text but more how well you memorize her phrasing. You use a different word than she used and you get half credit. Just don't..

She tells you what to write about, how to interpret the text, etc., and I can understand why that might annoy some people. However, I enjoyed reading the assigned books and they were pretty easy reads. Memorize what she wants you to memorize for the quizzes. Short essays aren't too bad and I got A's/B's on those. Not a bad class.
Best professor I've ever had. I've spent most of my life going to school and this was the best experience ever. Keep up the good work.

Very discouraging teacher: she is right, you are wrong. Wouldn't call it a discussion class all she does is summarize the material, yet attendance is still mandatory and a huge portion of your grade. Rewards grammar over ideas. Don't take her if you enjoy being an English major.You'll an A if you are a 'favorite' of hers.
Just don't do it.

Not a good English teacher in that to do well, you HAVE to write about what she thinks is right. If you write a good paper about your own different opinion and support it, the highest you can get is a B. Somewhat rude... Suck up to her, pay attention to grammar and you'll do okay (A/B). Wish we could have had classroom discussions. Books are okay.

Horrible teacher, completely inconsistent grader. She crushes intellectual discussion should it ever come up in class and is very disorganized. Her "take home quizzes" are actually surprise essays with almost no notice. For the benefit of your sanity and GPA avoid her like the plague.

Orringer is not clear in the LEAST. She takes roll call and is a very inconsistent grader. She plays favorites, and assigns massive amounts of reading with excessively short notice. Grammar is everything, which is fair, but she gives notes on books and then marks our answers wrong on quizzes.
Apply yourself, you will do fine

She is one of the sweetest teachers I have ever had. She is extremely helpful and allows you to redo papers to average a grade together. Yes, she is strict with grammar but she is an english teacher. She is quick to email back to any questions you have and is always willing to help.
AVOID AT ALL COSTS

Ridiculously picky when it comes to answers on quizzes: make sure you write down what she says WORD FOR WORD in lecture and then regurgitate it back to her on the quiz. Watching movies outside of class was a pain. Be careful what you say in class -- if she doesn't agree with you 100% she'll shut you down. Not the worst prof, but far from best.

She is a horrible teacher! she thinks grammar is the most important thing in life and doesn't even read your papers she just looks for grammar not the ideas you have written. If you go to her for help she is completely useless and will not give you a straight answer. I would never take this class avoid it at all costs!
Stick to what she tells you- it is exactly what she wants to hear regurgitated back to her in the essays you write.

She quizzes and teaches her own interpretations and is a stickler for grammer like no other. All assignments are the same where you compare a novel to a movie interpretation you have to watch outside of class. I wouldn't really recomend the class.

A stickler for grammar in a freshman english course -- and doesn't believe in rough drafts! Her grading seemed subjective -- make sure you show up and speak out. Lecture is a bit boring, usually she just goes through the reading and points out significant ideas. Had us watch a lot of movies outside of class, which was inconvenient.
Boring! And I had to correct her way too many times. It might have been nice if she knew the material she was "teaching."
go to class because everything she says is what she wants to read in your essays. very easy class once you figure it out
I took two of her classes in the semester. She does page by page and tells you what is important, which just happens to end up on her quizes. Write and underline these things in your book!

Unless you specifically need to take this class to graduate, AVOID! Does not respond to students and dismisses questions during lectures. The material is moderately interesting, but she has no ability to communicate it. Dense material but doable. Big disconnect between lab and lecture. Pray you have a good TA. In general, worst professor I've had.

McBrearty, despite being accomplished in her field and department head was one of the worst professors I have ever had. Never responds to emails and unhelpful during office hours. Horrible lectures. Travis was an amazing TA. Quarter of your grade is determined by very easy discussions, and extra credit can raise it by almost 10%. Easy enough class.

Dr. McBrearty can come across as a bit cold/uncaring to her students, but she is very knowledgeable in her field of study. Lectures can be disorganized, but Travis is an amazing TA who does a good job of streamlining information in discussion before an exam. Exam questions are MC, T/F, and open-ended, so make sure you study. Book is unnecessary.

WORST professor I have taken at UConn! Avoid at all costs. The class was easy but insanely boring. She is rude to students and never starts or ends class on time, you can tell she doesn't care at all. The textbook (that she wrote, and costs about $100) is completely pointless. Tests aren't bad but do the extra credit which are super easy!!
Goes through lecture at an unreasonable pace and hates stopping to answer questions. The TA's do most of the teaching during lab time, without them passing this class would be very difficult

EXTREMELY disorganized in lecture. The slides are a jumble of information, and she rushes through them. Don't bother asking for clarification either because she will claim there's not enough time. She usually goes past the end of lecture, and then speeds through the material even faster while everyone is leaving. BAD CLASS

She is very knowledgeable about her subject, but an awful professor. Has no regard for ending class on time, and often gives most important information after class should have ended. Reviews don't cover half the material on the exams, lecture slides are lacking as well. She wastes class time talking about her own personal achievements. Do not take.

Prof. McBrearty is a very knowledgable professor. Her lectures can be a little dry even if you are interested in the subject, but I recommend attending. Discussion sections are very helpful for exams. The exams are difficult, they require you to study a great deal of info. If you study it is possible to get an A in the class. Not an easy class.

Tops in her field and the department head (busy). Lectures slides prepped by tas. Disconnect between lab and lecture. TAs grade differentially - your lab and extra credit grades depends on who you get. Want an A? Show up to lecture, form a study group and meet twice a week from wk 1.Answer the labs, but then listen to the TA to verify your answers.

She... was so... boring. The subject was really interesting, and she clearly knows her stuff, but she was completely monotone. She often appeared to forget what was on her slides, and seemed surprised whenever she'd flip to the next one. Tests had SO much material, but it's doable. She always runs over time. Discussions are helpful.

Yes, she would sometimes run over class time by a little bit, but in general, she did a fabulous job. She presented very interesting information and offered a lot of extra credit which helped me get an A. Overall, she did a pretty good job, well done!

This class is very difficult. Expects you to know an absurd amount of information for one exam. Does not want to see or help students outside of class. The discussions are the best part of the course. I'd advise staying away from this one.

Very interesting class, professor is okay at best. Goes through lecture slides very quickly, so laptop is a must. Frequently goes over by ~5 or more minutes. Doesn't want to see kids outside class. The class itself was really interesting, and McBrearty knows her stuff. Plenty of extra credit, fair tests. Put in the effort, and you'll get an A.

Like many say, the class is indeed difficult and you have to work for an A. Still, a B is very achievable. She does go through slides quickly, but in my case I found the material to be very interesting and so I was able to keep up and do well. If you're not good with memorizing then stay out of this one, but if you're interested this is a good one

Sally is a good woman. I enjoyed the class as an ECON major but i just had a general interest in the class. Talks about herself and where she has been,but i would too if i was a world renowned anthropologist. Exams are not tricky, usually overstudied. She gives so many chances for extra credit, you can raise letter grade by 10 points (ie 75 to 85)

She goes way too fast in lecture. I don't care if she puts the slides online I go to lecture to learn and hear a summary of info, not hundreds of details that are disorganized and given little attention.

Love this class! If you are into learning in depth about early hominin species via fossils and fossil sites then this is the class to take. She sometimes rushes through slides in class, but they are all online. Exams are general multiple choice, short answer, fill in the blank. Not an easy A you do have to put in the time and she gives extra credit

Exam reviews are 20+ pages long, with details not even looked at on the exam. She gives loads and loads of information expecting excretions of tiny increments. Overall depth of material and exam questions far too many for a gen-ed. Also, essay questions for a big lecture (150+ kids) really? No wonder your TA's are miserable and lousy.

Straightforward. Powerpoints online. No need to attend class and no need to read the texts. Discussions are helpful as there is a worksheet every week = grade booster. Exams pretty easy. They dont go into as much detail as the slides so I usually over studied. However its a mix of MC, short answer, and essay. Decent class

Worst professor ever. Spends more time talking about her finds and showing locations she's photographed than teaching. Huge tests containing essays and fill in the blank with no idea as to what to expect. This class is far too serious for a 2000 level class and the TA's are awful. Save yourself from a GPA killer.

Lack of criteria for projects, most of lecture was taught through pre recorded videos and lecture became useless. Class felt like an afterthought to the professor and grading was done late in the semester.
Very boring class. But fair grading

Favorite Professor so far at college. Thermo is difficult so you will need to go to class. If you do, you will not need any textbook. Office hours help for HW. Do it. He starts every problem from scratch and emphasizes understanding the concepts before problem solving. Even if you flunk one or two exams he grades considering your progress.

Class is heavily lecture based. Ugur focuses on teaching to make sure you actually learn, instead of memorizing stuff for tests. Weekly homework is 4 questions and can be difficult at times. Three midterms and a final make up 90% of the grade. Exams are basically easier versions of the homework. Although it was tough, I learned a ton from Ugur.

Ugur is a gem. His lectures were short but filled with a lot of information and great examples. You are only graded by three exams (20% each) a final (30%) and homework was (10%). Exams are similar to homework and are very fair. Just do the homework enough times that you are able to do them without help. Homework takes a while but is very helpful.
Only way to learn was to pay attention in lectures. He speaks the entire time and expects you to understand easily, no slides presentation or anything.
If you're taking a thermo class, take my mans. Best lectures and all the exams and hw are reasonable and they all go together.

3 midterms worth 20% each, final 30%, homework 10%. Homework 4 questions every week due Friday, usually pretty hard. Exams 5 short questions (if you study a lot, aren't that bad). Bonus exam replaces lowest exam score, all MC/TF no lockdown. Lectures are kind of hard to follow but gives a lot of examples and hints. Overall cool professor.

The class is very difficult, but it is taught very clearly. I have no experience with other professors who teach this class but I would absolutely recommend him and would take another class with him. There was 1 homework assignment each week and 3 midterms that were formatted similarly to homework problems. If you put the work in, you will do well.
Very clear and concise. Explains the content very well. Very knowledgeable in the subject and communicates effectively. Making thermo my favorite class this semester

Good prof, lectures are interesting, HW can be hard but the book will have example problems along with the examples he does in class. Exams make up 90% of your grade so make sure to study hard for them. Going into the book and doing example problems and doing all the HW's over again will guarantee you A's on the exam.

He may be confusing/might not always explain very well. However, he grades fairly. He provides an equation sheet and writes what each equation is called (which is helpful). There are 3 exams and a final. For each of the 3 exams, I only finished 2 out of 5 questions and got an 80. *always attempt each question (you will get some credit)*

I am shocked reading some of the other reviews as I found Ugur quite unbearable. His lectures for this class did not reflect the homework at all making homeworks quite difficult. I found his office hours to be less than helpful. I would highly advise against taking fuel cells with Ugur.

Pop quizzes in class so you should go, he posts the lectures online though which is nice. Exam problems are nothing like homework but old exams are good to study from as well as quiz questions. He knows his stuff so if you go and pay attention you should be good

Great professor. Pay attention, go to class, take good notes, do homework, study, and you will earn an A. Tests questions are very similar to quizzes, which are shortened homework problems. Dr. P makes the material easy to understand, and is more than willing to explain if you are confused. I'd take him again in any class he teaches in the future!

I thought Thermo2 was easy; nobody else did. Lectures were straightforward to the point of repetitive dullness. Pop Quizzes are deceptively easy, Exams are half pop quizzes, half stuff to make you think. FAT CURVE. Took him for Fuel Cells- not your typical engineering course. Much more conceptual and market-driven than doing math. P tough.

He is a generous grader on exams and gives a HUGE curve at the end of the class but he is not a great teacher if you're actually trying to learn the material. His lectures are pretty useless and he gives minimal information on what will be on the exams. Also, he didn't give any information about the final exam which was very difficult.

He is fairly easy grader and his curves are huge but his exams are not as easy as previous review claims to be. His homework are long. His exams are short but hard and he has tendency to put trick questions on it. Allows one side of page for formula sheet in midterm and two side in final. Does not give any hint as per what will be on exam.

Honestly the greatest professor I have ever had at UConn. Easily the best in the engineering department. If you want to have an easy A in thermo, take it with Ugur. He will guarantee you a great grade. Exams aren't hard, homework is a joke. Please take this professor.

Ugur is probably the best professor I've had. Very thorough and very fair. Teaches you everything and only tests you on things that are straight forward. If you keep up with the homeworks, quizzes and exams are nothing to worry about

Dr. Shapiro is sharp, and he was clearly born to teach given his dedication, organization skills, and incredible knack for paraphrasing difficult texts and arguments in a way that anybody can understand. He is committed to student success and is very kind. He is always available to help with issues or just chat about material.

Professor S. Is a very intelligent man. I feel as though he has great intentions, and an amazingly eccentric personality. The issue with his class and teaching style is that he lacks compassion in his grading, and is a bit unrealistic for people who do not have as much a philosophical niche as he does. If it isnt how he wants it, its wrong.

Prof. Shapiro is very knowledgeable and passionate about philosophy and manages to make dry topics more engaging. Quizzes are hard and some questions are a bit too tricky. Exams are scary but if u study a lot you'll do fine-- he's a pretty lenient grader & nice guy. Going to office hours helps and ATTEND CLASS (otherwise ur screwed w the reading)

This class made me change my minor; do not take it unless you're a philosophy major or something. Shapiro made no sense; he's not good at explaining complex topics. This is my least favorite class I've ever taken. Don't do it. You've been warned.

He is a lenient grader and if you just do the work you'll be fine. The worst part is reading. It is constant and there are short writing assignments due weekly. If you miss class good luck understanding the reading. There's two longer writing assignments plus a midterm and a final. This class is not easy. I never want to take philosophy again.

Very good and thoughtful professor. Really tries his best to help students succeed. Highly recommend if you are genuinely interested in Logic. Smart guy who genuinely views you as an equal and will try his best to help you. Very good at responding to emails (even at midnight). A true Harvard man.
Not very articulate, very poor job at explaining complex ideas resulting in most people being confused. Tests are largely based on very acute details that were hardly even glazed over in lectures.

Shapiro is the most articulate man I have ever encountered. He has taught me more than any other professor I have ever had. This class requires a substantial amount of reading and effort, but Shapiro is always there for you if you need him. He wants to challenge you, but more importantly wants you to succeed. This man changed my life. GO DESCARTES.

I have taken nearly every class my Philosophy class has had to offer, and this class is undoubtedly the hardest one. This class should be a 3000/4000 level class. Shapiro is a very, very,very articulate teacher. He wants his students to succeed and will always be there to help you. But he is very challenging. The man graduated from Harvard for math

Lionel is a very straightforward/clear teacher. He writes out all of the notes on the whiteboard which helps immensely in a philosophy course. He is very awkward but very clear. He gives exam review sheets which prepare you for exams. His exams are tough but he doesn't grade writing harshly. If you are interested in philosophy, take this class.

If you have the option- DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH SHAPIRO. His grading is EXTREMELY arbitrary and the tests are impossible. He gives a reading quiz every time which is a multiple choice quiz that's all trick questions. Worst class I've taken here.
While the material was certainly unclear and hard to understand, this professor does all he can to try and help explain it. He also does want to see his students succeed even if they are struggling.

I took PHIL1103 with him in spring2012, he is a really nice guy. The exams or materials might be hard to understand, but if you stop by in his office hour or send him an email, he'll answer it for you and make it as clear as he can.

Lionel Shapiro is *not* for the casual philosophy student. He requires a very high level of thought and thoroughness to succeed. I've read a few comments regarding his unrealistic grading, but it seems those writing that were simply regurgitating the text instead of adding anything original. He will bury you if you don't think critically.

Took this class for 17th and 18th century. I really enjoyed this class and this professor so I am not sure what others are saying about him. It isn't all that easy, but isn't all that hard as long as you carefully read the material,listen to the lectures, discuss in class. Professor Shapiro is more than reasonable when you have an issue.

Maybe it's because I took 1101 and it was an easy class for me, but it's philosophy. It's not gonna be an easy class without a good professor. Shapiro sure you're up to speed with the readings with simple Reading Analyses and detailed notes. Those combined with if you study the 5-6 hrs/week he recommends & see him during office hrs, you're golden.

terrible professor. beyond unreasonable when handling student situations. notes are sporadic and useless. studied for hours and made 15 page study guide and still got a C+ on first exam. so philosophical it becomes naive. this guy needs to be re evaluated. unlike any prof ive had at uconn
he grades so hard! I thought I understood everything until the quiz. I wrote down word for word what he said in my notes, but he wants you to say studd he hasnt taught
boring, talks in circles, doesn't really get to the point, very confusing
Horrible Professor...Materials were hard to understand and his explanations didn't make it any easier. Droned on in class and stimulation of interest was nonexistent.
Awesome professor! Is very knowledgable and really pushes her students to learn! If you need her help she is more than willing to give it to you. Would really recommend!
I really had a crush on her. I did well in the class but there was something about her that drew me to her.

She knows her stuff but would often ramble about irrelevant things and laugh at her jokes. She also treats her students like children which is really annoying. Pop quizzes too. okay class if you go and semi-read Shakespeare

When the class started, she said she realized there were a lot of non-English majors in the class. Despite this, she was rude, harsh in grading and just kept droning on in class.
