By far the worst professor I've ever had. Rude to students when asking for extra help. Unclear instructions on assignments and expects us to know MATLAB and Simulink when some of us have never used it before. By far one of the worst professors in the department. Nothing positive to say about him
I cant hear him talk. Man just whispers his life away. The topic is also mad confusing, he moves too quick

He grades very fair and is well prepared in lectures. Generous extra credit. Only issues are his ability to use blackboard, and some HW prob. he chooses from the book are much harder than those in lecture, still he does not grade HW very strict. The exams and projects are exactly the same as in class problems. No attempts to trick his students.

Very clear in his expectations and fair with grading. Accommodating with giving extra credit and extending deadlines to help students given the virtual format of the class. His lectures are very organized and he explains concepts relatively well.

Very clear, structured class. Derives equations used in class while emphasizing the end use of them and the physical interpretations in an intuitive way. Emphasizes the importance of not re-deriving solutions for every problem and instead just to apply them. Wants students to succeed.

Professor Smith has been my favorite professor at UConn so far! This was my second time having a class with her. She is super kind and caring. Her lectures are engaging and she is always open to getting feedback on her teaching. She has such good energy. She gives great feedback and makes sure to point out the positives and not just the negatives!

I LOVE Professor Smith! If I could take every English class with her, I would. We had a semester project that she broke up into sections and gave detailed feedback on each section so they all came together very nicely, and the project was meaningful to our future careers so I'll definitely be using it when I'm a teacher. The books were also great!

Professor Smith is very sweet and attentive to her students' needs. She's quite lenient as long as you do what she asks, and will give you multiple ways to complete a task. Participation is graded, but can be fulfilled in ways other than attendance; still, she told me that she really appreciates people showing up for class. A nice person overall.

She is one of the best professors at UConn, so well-spoken and caring for her students. Gives great feedback and class is mostly discussion based but she allows everyone to express themselves freely. Very self-aware of making students feel comfortable, 10/10 will take a course with her again.

Super simple assignments. Loves to hear from everyone about their take on the readings. No midterm or quizzes. Allows you to catch up on work you missed while out. Even had a slide dedicated to the beards of the Victorian Era lol

One of the best professors I have had! She is funny, caring, and kind. She made the online COVID transition so easy on us and was accomodating always. There was one large project throughout the semester but the checkpoints made it very do-able. She cared so much about us learning and it was obvious - an amazing professor!

She is such a kind person and so clearly cares about the wellbeing of her students. Amid the COVID pandemic, she was a professor that put a lot of effort into transitioning to online learning. She provides thoughtful feedback on every assignment and is very understanding to what is going on in students' lives outside of class. Absolutely recommend!

I absolutely loved this class and I have no idea how Professor Smith's rating is less than 4 or 5 stars. She gives amazing feedback, makes time to meet with you whenever you need to, and actually knows how to host decent class discussions. Her assignments are creative, and the readings she picks are pretty good. I'd recommend any of her courses.

Awesome professor - really deserves better ratings!! Super understanding & caring professor. If you like YA lit, you'll like the class. She's very intelligent & a bit awkward, but her lectures are great. Occasionally dull topics, but she takes feedback & values all opinions. Two papers, one midterm, and final. All easy if you read & come to class.

Victoria Smith is one of my favorite teachers at the University of Connecticut. Though reading heavy and participation heavy, those elements only serve to make the class more interesting. The class is mainly discussion, based on the articles and novels assigned. If you pay attention and participate, this is a fascinating and easy A.
Boring. Bad overall experience. Bad vibes.

This class was uninspired and monotonous. I would recommend taking it with a different professor or not at all. There were unrealistic participation expectations and unexpectedly harsh grading on easy material. The class was boring discouraging.

She's very sweet. Easy grader and is honestly just interested in hearing you express your own ideas. However, she has very high (slightly unrealistic) expectations for participation, and expects everyone to contribute multiple times per class. She also makes us carry around a gigantic book every class. Material could also be very dry.
Absolute best professor. Pretty easy to get an A. Class is very interesting and she gives amazing feedback. I have already taken two courses with her.

Weining is a great guy, awful class. You only ever see the grades of 2 assignments, so you never know where you stand. Material is confusing and you really do not need to go to class but he does assignments at the end that supposedly count towards your participation. He used to drastically curve in past semesters but he stopped doing that.

Weining is a great guy! The class is basically just teaching you how to do excel analysis. Exams and assignments are easy, the midterm is take-home, and everything gets a +30-point or more curve. Take notes during class to remember how to do certain problems bc exam problems are basically just reworded from in-class problems.

Can be fairly challenging to understand WB and what's going on in the course, but our TA was generous w/ grading, and Bao himself offers some crazy exam curves at semester's end. He's very, very kind- just be sure to go to class, pay attention, take notes, and email him if you're having trouble. Helps to find a study buddy or two. Only 2 HWs.

Awesome guy. Took him for MKTG 3661 and one of the sweetest professors I've ever had. Some of the concepts throughout the course might get difficult but he always is willing to help and is very accessible by email. Overall good class with a great professor, highly recommend.

One of my favorite professors that I have had since I've gone to UConn. He is the sweetest guy alive. He loves teaching this class and it shows in his demeanor no matter the day. He brings the same energy to each class which always makes you smile. He is not afraid to help you if you don't understand the concepts. Take his class! Strongly recommend

LOVE Professor Bao. He is a KING! He is the sweetest professor I have ever had. He truly wants all his students to succeed in his class. He is an angel. He loves what he does and it shows. Please answer him when he asks "How was everyone's weekend?" because he loves when students respond. :-)

Bao is incredible. The nicest professor I have had at UConn. Class was fully online. Had 40 minute "offline" portion so class is realistically only 30 minutes. Only 2 exams and 2 projects that are fully online. You have 3 days to complete the exams so they are not hard. Overall, fairly easy class with a top-tier professor. Highly recommend.

I'm not even done with this guy's class but he is honestly the most wholesome professor I have ever had. Super short lectures where you can do the work before on your own time and very simple in-class activities. It's a very laid back class so I can actually focus on learning the concepts instead of just remembering material.

Super caring professor & very helpful in lectures! I learned a lot about Excel and marketing analytics concepts. The only negative thing I have to say is that all the lectures involve working in Excel on your laptop, but the exams are no-notes on paper which made it DIFFICULT. But he's seriously such a nice professor & I recommend this class.

Hands down my favorite professor I've had at UConn. Took this last semester & got a B+ which I'm not happy about, but that's on me not Professor Bao. He is so willing to help and gives very good feedback with his grading. He's also always in a happy/good mood. The structure of the class is also very straightforward. Take the class with Bao
It was a pretty easy class, but I felt that I did not learn a lot. The exams seemed to be much harder than expected. Meh. Don't really recommend.

Professor Bao was one of my most accomodating professors this semester with online learning. Lectures were super short, like 30 minutes max, and a few short lectures that we had to watch before class. No cameras or mics on, and participation is just answering polls and submitting mini group projects that are super easy.

Absolutely love this man. He has a heavy accent but is very nice and funny. No quizzes, just the 2 exams, which are lengthy but you have a week to complete them (totally open note). Most of the work is through Excel. 2 assignments which arent too hard if you follow his video tutorials, where he even provides written captions. My favorite professor

His class was the first money worth class in my 4 years of college life. He always asks (do the poll) students if we are on right track or not. He goes over all the questions that students have, and always willing to help students. Best professor ever. Highly recommended.
This was the worst class I have ever taken and pretty much ruined my whole grade!

His notes are on a white sheet of paper and are very hard to follow. He picks the hardest example problems to do and rarely goes over problems we will actually see on the exam. The only reason why I passed this class is because I started using David's (the honors professor) notes halfway through the course. The average for the final was a 65.
Avoid him if you can

Horrible. His notes are just blank pieces of paper that he fills out during the lectures, so it is very difficult to follow along. Everything I learned was through YouTube. The WebAssign homeworks would too often have little relevance to anything we would see on a quiz or exam, especially because this class is no calculator.

If math doesn't click for you then don't take calc 2 with Alberts. He is an audiobook of the horrible text of this class. You can get 100s on all the quizzes and homeworks but if you do poorly on any of his 3 exams, you're gonna get a poor grade. If you wanna do good in his class get ready to work HARD. He is a good guy and means well, but he's DRY

I don't have him but I'm studying with my friend that does and she's lost bc there's so much my professor taught me that Alberts either just like straight up didn't teach them or just got too lazy to finish teaching all the steps and now they're all confused at the p-set answers. Ik ppl teach different but I dont consider withholding info a style.

Avoid! New to teaching and IT SHOWS. Runs his course very by the books with no curves or chances to make up. Doesn't post online notes so you're at the mercy of what you write down in class. Grade is 85% test and 15% homework so mess up on one and your grade is screwed. He doesn't seem to understand students have other classes. Otherwise, nice guy

Brandon was a great professor this semester. He takes up the whole lecture but he is really thorough and takes the time to make sure you understand the material. Sometimes the lecture can be dry but overall really engaging! Use of the textbook is not required but really useful for weekly quizzes and the exams. Exams are not that hard if you study.

He's a nice guy but the material he goes over is the hardest examples of every topic. Sometimes the stuff that is on the quizzes aren't even gone over in lecture and we would never know the answer if the TA never went over them in class. He is good at answering questions but he should do more examples that are more related to what we need to know.

He made few mistakes for his 1st and 2nd exam which spend students over 20 mins to solve a wrong question. After exam he corrected this question and said this question doesn't count. This happened in 2 of his exam which was 15 % for your grades.

Your grade in the class is based only on exams with 15% of your grade relying on homework. Each exam gets harder and harder and the final was one of the hardest exams Ive ever taken. There was minimal to no curve in the class on any exams at all, despite the class failing the exam.

Brandon himself is a great teacher. He teaches the concepts very well. Despite this, his class insanely hard. You have three exams and homework to determine your grade, each exam is more difficult than the last. He grades very tough, and is noticeably hesitate to curve. I took this class with thermodynamics and orgo and it was my hardest class.

His exams were extremely hard and he was not very helpful during his office hours. Your grade is only based off of two exams and then a cumulative final, all MUCH harder than the webassign. Also, his curve at the end of his class was extremely small compared to other classes. You will only do well in this class if you are naturally intelligent.

Brandon Alberts is a very good professor for differential equations. His class is more test heavy than most other diffe professors, but his tests are very fair and easy to do well on. He does a very good job going over problems and they're very similar to homework and test problems

Dr. Goldhamer is a gem! His class is extremely difficult, but he genuinely cares about student learning. Go to office hours and he will sit with you for as long as you need to understand the concepts. Study early for this class because it can take a while for the concepts to digest, and you need to be able to connect them to do well on his exams.

Dr. Goldhamer is a nice guy and very passionate about what he teaches. However, his exams are VERY tough. No matter how much you study and know the material, he always puts questions on the exams that require such deep analytical thinking, making it almost impossible to pass. I would not recommend taking this class to anyone.

I agree with others saying his attitude towards students could use some readjustment. I am severely asthmatic + at-risk and found it discouraging that he seemed intent on invalidating the participation of those who didn't attend in-person, despite the classroom not having COVID safe seating or ventilation and the positive rate now nearing 10%.

Decent lecturer. BAD attitude; posts lectures online while insulting students who choose to watch them--even if covid weren't going on it's ableist + classist + just generally rude to criticize students who choose to learn virtually. needs to stow his ego and empathize; there is no wrong way to learn. I have a 92 and I watch online bc of autism :|

Your grade was only based on three exams, all non-cumulative and MC. The questions test your knowledge really specifically, so it's difficult to do well. He doesn't offer extra credit, so you really have to put your all into this class to do well. The lectures were interesting, but I think he would've been a better instructor in person.

The tests are very challenging and questions can be obscure. To do well in this class you must only focus on this class and be interested in pursuing a PhD in developmental biology. Don't think this class is focused on regenerative biology because that is only the last lecture and the other parts of the semester are embryology.

Very well respected professor for good reason. He is very intelligent but makes everything extremely clear in lectures. Instead of memorizing a bunch of things, he makes you learn how they were discovered and get to know the process of science very well. Interesting class and one of my favorites

This was one of the best classes that I took, and one of the most difficult. Goldhamer is a fantastic teacher, and his class will absolutely help you to think like a scientist. I think it is a testament to his teaching ability that I can say that this was one of my favorite classes, even though I received a B- that I worked quite hard for.

He's a great teacher, but the class and exams are really hard. Take it if you want to learn, but aren't too hung up on getting A's on every exam, because you probably won't unless you make this class your only priority. Definitely the class I learned the most in

This class was a pleasure: well structure and decently paced. In class review session were helpful before the exams. The exams themselves are challenging and require one know the material very well but they are fair. Great class if you are willing to work hard and learn alot.

Great professor, keeps you awake with funny asides. It's not uncommon that a personal slide will "somehow" find its way into his ppt presentations. The topics great, if you want to learn to think more like a scientist, take the class.
good guy, brutal grader, unclear exams, but at the end i was supposed to get a D in the class and he gave me a C overal...
No Comments
Brutal grader.
Bro was chill. Helped when I had questions and recorded his lectures in 121. I would take him again if I could. Bro is AMAZING!
He helps you inside and outside the class. He is awesome

Every assignment was on Aleks and was taught through material on the McGraw Hill textbook. When it came time for the final, there was never a review, never a study guide, and pretty much no guidance. This man gave us an exam with material completely unfamiliar to us and nothing like any homework problem, quiz problem, or exam problem given to us.

Dr. Xu is a very nice person. The homework assignments are easy because you have unlimited attempts, and he allows you to use excel to solve every problem. I usually feel unprepared for the tests, but he allowed us to retake our test to receive a higher grade. The content can be tricky, so make sure to really try on the assignments.
Very good professor

Absolutely the worst prof I've ever had. Extremely unaccommodating and doesn't know how to teach stat without using R or excel. I used to be great in math and he makes me feel stupid. Barely teaches and the tests are impossible and graded so hard, even if you get 100s on the homeworks and think you did good on the test you still will do bad.
lectures the whole class and barely explains the problems by skipping multiple steps. gives book homework almost always and your final grade in the class is based off of 2 exams and the final.

Justin is a fantastic professor. He puts a LOT of emphasis on the "Financial Meaning" of what he's teaching. This will help you understand the more complicated equations as well as the real-life importance of what you're learning. The homework isn't graded, but you will suffer on exams if you don't do it. He loves answering questions so ask away!

Justin is a solid professor, especially for FM which is a really hard course. His lectures are very helpful and he gives very clear explanations. He also gives you a lot of opportunities to get extra credit here and there.
Clear lectures, great professor, care about u actually learn things. Take his class.
BEST Math prof I have ever had!!!! He gives amazing lectures and explain things super clear! You give efforts and you will be fine!

Took this class in fall 2017 and I have to be honest with you, this is the hardest class I've ever taken, and, this professor is the best math teacher I've had. He is amazingly good at explaining things, otherwise this class would become much harder. You can still have your social life, since the homework is not mandatory.

Math 2620 is hard. Of course it is, what do you expect from a SOA exam prep class otherwise. The good news is that Professor Xu gives amazing lecture that makes problem solving process clear and simple. Pay attention to the class, do the homework, and you'll do well.

Incredibly difficult class with high expectations and lots of homework. The amount of work will destroy your social life. The professor warns you in the beginning that all you will do is study. Not worth taking the class if your major isn't finance.

She is so lovely. This class is extremely easy. You write one thing every 2 weeks, usually about 1 page long (2 of the assignments are just poems). There is no final really, just a portfolio compiling the work you did that semester. Class can drag on a bit, but she cares a lot and as long as you show effort, easy A.

Truly enjoyed her class. Prof. Pelizzon made me love writing again. She gives incredibly helpful feedback and shows true passion for what she teaches. 250 word discussion posts 1x a week and 6x total 5-page papers throughout the course (3 papers, 2 drafts). Content is really engaging and she is very caring. Best W course I could have taken.

She is such a caring professor who is truly passionate about what she teaches, and it shows. She makes class interesting and keeps everyone engaged. You do have to go to class every week, but the work is very reasonable for a W and the readings were actually pretty interesting and fun. I highly recommend taking a class with her!

For a W, it's not crazy. 200 word Discussion board posts and 200 word replies every week on poems from an author, 3 papers but u submit first drafts each time so technically 6 throughout the semester? Other than that you just need to go to class. I would recommend

Such an easy W course. She was such an easy grader, and we only had 3 papers. The reading was mostly light, usually poems and one book that we read over a month. Her lectures can be dry, and participation matters so you have to go to class, but overall this was such an easy course.

For a class that wasn't a W, there was a lot more writing than was expected. However, the prompts she gave were very thought-provoking and interesting/easy to write about. Before this class, I didn't consider myself a fan of poetry or nonfiction, but I can now say that has changed.

The class is easy. She is very passionate about poetry and hopes that students will be too. Several writing assignments and two recitations of poems in front of the class. But overall an easy class if you study and take the time to learn the material. And trust me, there is not a lot of material. I don't spend much time doing work for this class.

Penelope seems sweet on the outside but she is a sour plum. She expects everyone to be as passionate about poetry as she is going into the class. Her midterm was fine but the final was cumulative with about 45 poems to interpret and identify as well as 33 terms to define. Unwilling to listen to reason when discussing alternatives. don't take class

Penelope Pelizzon is a consistently good professor. She is a strong speaker and introduces a variety of poetic styles. She encourages (requires) students to memorize and recite poems to the class. For those with stage-fright, I must emphasize that she will encourage the more shy students. Overall, if you enjoy poetry, I would highly recommend her.

I often struggle with writing, despite being very passionate about it, simply because I have a hard time finding inspiration and turning it into something palpable. Professor Pelizzon has a unique talent for bringing out the best in me. She helps students to make each other better, and you just don't see that every day.

Personally, I found 4600W to be far more writing than necessary for a W class and I don't shy away from writing in general. Class constantly runs late and I waited for 30 minutes outside her office despite having an appointment. I find her irritating and condescending and personally would never recommend taking a W class with her.

I feel so inspired in Professor Pelizzon's class. I think some of my best written work was done for her assignments. She knows what she's taking about, and her insight to poetry and prose is fascinating. You can't help but feel inspired. Don't graduate without taking a class with Professor Pelizzon.

Professor Pelizzon is an amazing poetry teacher. She has studied these poems well and is able to identify the important aspects and themes of the poems. The workload is very light and yet full -- as in, you learn so, so much with a very light homework load. Whether you're a poetry lover or hater, you want to take this class with Professor Pelizzon.

I was very hesitant about this course as I had heard many negative things. However, I personally found that this class is NOT as hard as everyone makes it out to be. All you have to do is study for the exams, know the material well, and you will do fine. All the material from the exams are directly from the slides he posts.

Dameon is kind, and he will go back and explain things if you ask him. Despite this, his class is ridiculously difficult to comprehend. The class average for his exams have been in the 50-60s, so don't take if you are self conscious about your grades. Don't be fooled by people in the class who seem to understand things, they are likely retaking it.

Dameon is well meaning, but lectures are extremely dry. Quizzes are difficult, but taken online and are directly from the textbook. His TA does offer "Math Camps" which I would highly encourage you to attend as content is covered in a very different and applicable way to exams/problem sets. He offers extra credit for math camps/study participation.

In all honesty, this may be the toughest SLHS course that you'll have to take at UConn so it doesn't even matter who teaches this course. Dameon is a good professor and he really tries to help his students learn. You just have to put in a ton of effort and more to pass the class. Visit office hours before it's too late!
Very, very tough

I think this class gets a bad reputation but in reality their are many opportunities to do well and learn a ton. Damien gives up to 5 points of extra credit on the final grade. It is important to remember this is a Q class, so you do have to put the work in and read the book, but overall this class is comparable to any other core science class.

dameon is a really nice person (always available to help you) but in class he just isn't a good teacher. he goes fast through the material and does not engage the class (hard to pay attention). can't use calculators and the math is really complex (solving logs by hand). no extra credit unless you attend the math camps. try to take with diff prof.!!

This class is difficult no matter who is teaching it. A lot of people criticize Dameon because they are unhappy with their grades, but it is not his fault. The exams are extremely difficult, but not impossible. GO TO MATH CAMP AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE. Dameon is also very helpful at office hours. He just doesn't realize when people are confused!

I wish Dameon had a higher grade on here! He's super smart and always willing to help if you just ask, in office hours or right after class. Definitely take notes in the class and do the problem sets multiple times till you get 100%. Make sure you do the readings & buy the textbook. The class sucks i.e. no calculator but Dameon is a great guy.

Took for science of speech and hearing (Q) as a requirement for slhs major. Not once did he mention the word "speech" or "hearing" the entire time, so the class completely lost its meaning. Doesn't allow you calculators and makes you remember all the formulas yourself. Weekly online quizzes and tons of textbook reading Dont take.

Dameon is an extremely intelligent guy no doubt, but does not know how to effectively teach. I worked my ass off in the class and got Cs on the first two exams with a curve that he added. However, I ended up with an A- in the class cause he does curve/the online quizzes/attending math camp does help your grade. This class is the worst, good luck!

Hardest class I've ever taken hands down. Dameon was extremely intelligent but absolutely did not know how to teach. He did not have any time for this class which was unfair because it is one of the most difficult classes of the major. So much math, no calculator. No tutor, just a TA that doesn't have time either.

this class was impossible. SO hard. the readings were long and very dense. He is very smart but does not know how to teach AT ALL. study guides were 0 help, most of the things on them were not on the test. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITHOUT FIRST TAKING PHYSICS. it is a TON of math with no calculator. GOOD LUCK
Just no. Don't do this to yourself. Wait for another instructor to teach this.
Prof. Luzzatto is a loose cannon. He has the teaching style of a petty and childish bully. Unprofessional, sensitive primadonna who thinks he's a hot shot. Take the other historian's craft option.

The worst professor I have ever had. Puts work up on the board in class and critiques it in front everyone. Gives false information knowingly on his syllabus. No clear grading structure. Says things like "Are you always this poor a writer or does this come as a surprise?" in front of others. Avoid at all costs. Shouldn't be in the classroom

everything about this man is inconsistent, he regularly calls out students, will drop your grade to a zero your assignment is even 10 minutes late. his grading is completely arbitrary and he bases it off "how he feels". he also refused to offer any feedback or answer questions on my rough draft, and told me to rewrite the whole thing

I took this class in the Spring of 2021 online. He was extremely arbitrary in everything he does and isn't understanding. He does not take criticism well and is unprofessional. The way he graded was unclear, his assignments were unclear, and to make it worse he had a thick accent which made everything more confusing.

Professor Luzzatto is a great person but not a great professor. He doesn't give clear guidelines, never can tell what he wants, and doesn't give good feedback on papers. He also isn't around for office hours or after class. Again, great person, not a great prof.
His grading is pretty much vibe based so if you put in effort and talk in discussion you can get a good grade. Don't take this class if you like pineapple on pizza or any structure what so ever.
We rockin with Sergio 9 days out of the week. This man draws more dimes than the US Mint. We love Sergio.

Not a good professor. Lectures are poor, actively refuses to give individualized feedback, and grading criteria are unclear. If you can avoid taking this course with Luzzatto, you should. I understand it is required but other porfs teach it just take it with one of them because chances are it will be more educational and not quite as unpleasant

I was going about my semester when I remembered I had forgotten to leave this review. Professor Luzzatto is extremely contradicting and confusing. He preaches that he wants more class participation, but will lecture for 20 minutes as students have their hands raised waiting to talk. No clear guidelines on any assignment, and a tough grader.
Sergio is an awesome professor. He's so funny too. He roasted me a few times but it comes from a good place.
Tough class, but fair: if you put in the work and you work consistently, you'll be okay and will learn a lot.

Be ready for a lot of writing and reading, but also for his very tough grading techniques. Most students who talked in class at least once a week would get 'sporadic participation' grades and he takes attendance EVERY class. He starts every class with a 20-minute rant Fluent in English, but won't understand some American writing wording in essays

Syllabus was incredibly unclear, grading is arbitrary. No one in the class really understood what he wanted and he'd regularly start class by just ranting for 20-30 minutes. The work isn't even hard per se its just seemed impossible to know what he wanted for 2/3rds of the semester. The notes and lectures were useless, I had to self teach a lot.

expectations are extremely unclear, and doesn't tell you until midterms what your grade is, despite the syllabus saying he will provide weekly feedback/grades. isn't willing to work with you if you aren't doing well. wants people to have an open dialogue, yet proceeds to go on long-winded rants all class.
Great guy strict teacher "wants you to lear:. But honestly he iss to serious.
I enjoyed the class a lot! I felt that even though it was pretty easy, I still learned a fair bit and the class is very unique. TA's taught most of the class.
I loved this class. Easy A and Sanford brought in many speakers that were informative to help guide students into the medical field. One compliant is TAs did take a while to grade.

so boring bc lectures were done solely by undergrad TAs yet we're paying tuition for him to teach.. guest speakers were good. could have been a lot more meaningful of a class, but its easy if you need the credit.

Dr. Sanford is a GEM! This class is so meaningful and applicable for the medical/allied health field. Class is patient-centered focus with medical interviews/histories, book reports, guest medical lectures, and other relevant assignments. We need more professors and classes such as this one. I would take if on any pre-health track. Doable class!!!!

TAs taught the whole class. final is an interview w/ keat using the patient interview skills learned throughout the semester. hw is usually writing a patient interview or a reflection, and there is 1 book report- lots of busy work but very easy assignments. some guest speakers that are interesting to hear from. overall easy class. good for premeds

Class is taught entirely by undergraduates (super boring). Very few guest speakers but the one's who did come were fantastic. This class is an easy A but unfortunately costs hours of busy work and dreadfully boring lectures. If you are in it for the content, look elsewhere.

Truly the best. But if ur looking for an easy 1 credit course, this isnt it. He is so passionate about medicine and is a great professor, but the class is definitely more work than just 1 credit. Even then, its not a ton of work either, just reading and an assignment each week, plus the final at the end. Great class atmosphere and TAs were great
The class was really interesting. Wasn't a heavy workload. Grading was fair and clear. Dr. Sanford and the TAs were really nice.
I love Dr. Sanford. Really passionately about the material and all the guest lecturers were fun.

I loved Dr. Sanford. He is very kind and clearly knows a lot about medicine and is very eager to share his knowledge and help students learn. I did enjoy this class because it was very thought-provoking and it helped me as a stem major. The only thing is that it is a bit work heavy for a 1 credit course.

Dr. Sanford is so sweet and knows a lot about the field. However, this is definitely a work-heavy UNIV class to take (feels like much more than 1 credit). His discussions are led well but you should be prepared to share and have the work done.

I thought that my UNIV class would be easy and fun. I was wrong- Sanford teaches probably the most work-intensive UNIVs. I spend more time on this class than I do any other because he simply piles on the homework, sometimes assigning it only 2 days before class. If that's not enough, he will come to class and ask US to remind him what he assigned.

We did a lot of group projects however they were pretty straight forward where you simply had to read a part of the text book and create a power point covering what you read. Even for the final. The only thing is that it got quite boring since most class days consisted of listening to your classmates present.

I got a lot out of this class and overall enjoyed it, however do not take this class if you are looking for an easy UNIV. This is probably one of the most work-heavy UNIVs offered by UConn. However if you are looking for a thought provoking 50 minutes a week this is the class for you.

Overall she is super sweet and offers extra credit, and revisions on exams. Her exams are very difficult because her answer options are very tricky, so study a lot and know your stuff!! If there is another professor teaching this class take it with them instead, trust me. Shes a great teacher but i would not take again, her exams are just too hard.

Dr. Garr-Schultz is a very strong lecturer and clearly knows what she is talking about. I enjoyed her lectures and regret not putting in as much work as I should have for this class. There were extra credit opportunities after the exams but I can't speak for her other classes that will be. Very test heavy so study study study!

I was scared of all the bad reviews, but I loved this class. Really fun lectures if you like psych. Always show up to lecture bc not everything is written on the slides, you should be fine without the textbook, and some stuff on the exams are specific so take good notes. Offers exam revisions if needed.

She's a great lecturer, always kept me engaged and gave lots of examples to help me remember the material. Grade is based on three exams and SONA participation. If you review your slides and pay attention in lecture, the exams aren't too bad. Lots of chances for extra credit!

She honestly was not a bad teacher, but the exams could be really difficult and there aren't much assignments to help build up your grade. She does give extra credit and mini assignments at times, but it really isn't worth a lot so you just have to make sure you study a lot for the exams, or else you won't do good in the class.

This class was great! I have no idea where the negative reviews come from. If you are expecting an easy A with zero effort, don't take this class - but this is college, and for this class you should go to class and study a little bit. There are three exams and she gives some small assignments and other activities. I really enjoyed this class!!

I was nervous about her because I saw the previous reviews, but she was one of the best instructors I've had. Only main assignments were the three exams (no final) but she provided optional extra credit and revision assignments. I never used the book, but go to lecture if you can because the slides are posted, but not all the information is on it.

Professor Garr-Schultz covered a lot of material in class and on exams, but offered many ways to make up for them. She offered extra credit for each exam and revisions. Although she could be sassy, she seemed to care about her students and really wanted us to understand the material.
Absolutely Nightmare about the exam

Do not take this course with Garr-Shultz. My roommate took the same exact course and had an easy A. Tests were ridiculously specific about lecture material and videos shown, and everyone bombed the tests, so on the first she allowed test corrections but decided that it was too much work for her for the other 2. Good luck.

If I didn't take 1103 instead of 1101, I probably would've finished with a D-. Her exams are hard asf and the curves are weak. People literally had to ask her to add like 2 or 3 small assignments to try to up their grade. She never updates the grade book so you could never know what the actual grade is unless you emailed her.

This class was easy and manageable. Did not take up too much time at all. Very frustrating that she never updated the grade book and I never knew what I had the entire semester. The grade book showed an inaccurate grade and you had to email her for your actual grade.

Dr. Garr-Schultz is super sweet, very engaging, and her lectures are really interesting. I found that class passed by very fast because it was really interesting. She gives extra credit opportunities and is very fair when grading exams. You do have to study the textbook but there's virtually 0 homework otherwise.

Dr. Garr-Schultz is the best psych professor I've had so far. I've taken 4 psych courses and she is the only professor who manages to keep everyone interested, even those of us who aren't psych majors. She's caring and always makes accommodations wherever necessary. The only thing I'd critique is that she can go a bit fast during lectures.

An amazing professor who puts in as much time as you do. Ask for help and he'll help you. Even if you're not a photographer or don't want to be a professional, he'll help you improve no matter your skill. The course will be a lot, but it will be worth it if you want a challenge and want to be better.
Not a good class.

It's not even the rigor of the course but the lack of respect for students and other activities that they may be doing outside of that class. If you don't want to be the next AP or New York Times photographer do not waste your time in this class. If you enjoy photography, great. But take the photo class that is in the college of Arts
Not available.
Just no
No comment
Only take this class if you want all confidence in your ability to be a killed. He grades on what he would do instead of the pictures we submit, and changes assignment details last minute
I would avoid this class like the plague.
Never hated a class at UNL more than this one. Worst teacher, worst experience. Would avoid at all costs

Shoun Hill is a great professor. As an award-winning photographer he knows what he is talking about when it comes to photography. He is a tough grader however, it is because he wants you to become better. Its a big time commitment but students have become better photographers because of him. His office is always open and he gives good critiques.
Provides a lot of professional photojournalist experience!
I had Hill for JOMC132, he was laid back but can be a hard grader on some assignments.

The assignments were so much work and extremely time consuming every single weekend and he graded very hard. this is by no means an entry level or general journalism class like the name of the class suggests. would definitely never recommended it to anyone and everyone in my class wouldve agreed.
Gives photo assignments that are needlessly time consuming, gives random assignments after class that are due within a few hours, randomly calls on people in class - I recommend avoiding this class.

Professor Miller is an incredible professor who cares about his students immensely. He is always available to meet with students, however, make sure to text him rather than email him (he prefers text and responds faster). If you are struggling in Accounting Professor Miller is the ideal professor because he really cares about helping students!

Professor Miller is a nice guy but a mediocre professor. His lectures were just him reading off slides, very dry. He makes you feel bad for not understanding things ("you guys aren't dumb, you should know this"), and is hard to contact (never replied to several of my emails). The homework made me want to cry several times- takes at least 3 hours.

Basically you just buy the Pearson textbook access and learn the class from that. He just reads off the powerpoint slides from the textbook. I liked taking his class online because we didn't have synchronous lectures so I could get my work done at my pace. Overall he's a nice guy and very accessible to answer questions

Professor Miller is awesome! He really wants his students to do well and makes himself available whenever you have any questions. He also tries to incorporate real world experience into his lectures to make the course content more meaningful.

Group projects were fairly graded. He was boring to listen to. Would try to do problems in his head and clueless most of the time. His homeworks took forever. His exams became more easier at the end of the semester bc he finally used the practice problems as his exam problems. Didn't like too much

Overall, professor Miller did a great job at engaging with the class and using his professional experiences to help students understand certain topics. He was always willing to help students with projects given, and there was never a time I did not feel prepared for the exams. He is extremely easy to talk to, and a really funny guy as well.

Practice exams and class handouts are identical to the exams, study those and you'll be golden. He's an easy grader when it comes to the group projects. There's def a lot of homework but it's a good grade booster. He's a really great guy when you get to know him and he really goes out of his way to help his students, if you put in effort so will he

Miller is the man. He actually cares about teaching. He hands out practice exams that are just like the real exam. If you score an 89.5% in the class, then you are exempt from the final. Online homework and quizzes are a pain. As long as you read the chapters and pay attention in class, then you should pass no problem. Some group projects.
He had no idea what he was doing half the time. He thinks UCONN students are above everyone which isn't true. He doesn't reply to emails or help those in need. Exams were tough.
Great Professor. Goes above and beyond for his students. Practice exams and review sessions were extremely helpful for the exams. He is very funny and caring, wish I could take him again.

Best accounting professor I've had. Practice exams are just like the homework, they're fairly easy too- all multiple choice. He's a pretty easy grader for the group projects too. The only downside to the class are that the homework and quizzes (via Pearson) are incredibly tedious and time consuming, but it does help you retain the material.

This was his first semester at UCONN. Very knowledgeable and not afraid to tell it like it is. Online homeworks and quizzes were tough and time consuming, but doing them made tests easier. A few group projects, but nothing too difficult. Very accessible and flexible.

Miller was a great guy & professor. He is among the few at UConn who actually care about their students and are more than understanding of arising conflicts, as long as you speak up. He gives practice exams that are actually useful and similar to the real exams. The homework and online quizzes are the hardest part of the class but also manageable

Dulli does not teach you how to do problems, just teaches the concepts. The tests are incredibly difficult and require studying at least a week in advance. If you want to do well in his class, buy a Chegg account to learn how to do all the HW problems and memorize the PowerPoint slides.

Worst year of my life with him in 1401 and 1402. Slaved away doing the homework problems both for their due dates and to review for the exam. Impossible to do without chegg since lectures are theoretically simple but have no correlation with the homework. avoid this professor at all costs

Many people here have hated on Dulli, but he is a unique professor. If you ACTUALLY pay attention, and at least pretend to be interested, he will revere you and respect you as a student. The class is hard and does require much more work than other Q courses but he is passionate about the class and wants you to suceed+hes hilarious and inspiratnl

Just taking lecture notes is not nearly enough in order to do well. The online hw problems are usually very difficult, but if you take the time to really work them out and understand whats happening, you'll do alright. If not, don't be surprised when you get a 30 on an exam. Dulli will help you though if he see's that you put in effort.

Lectures won't help you understand the material. Barely any resources to study from. Tests extremely hard and include much much more than he goes into in class. Avoid at all means necessary. Way too much work and no benefit

If you actually put in the effort this class deserves and read the book, his lectures actually make sense and you don't need to "Chegg" the homework assignments. This class was full of pretentious premeds who felt entitled to the A, but if you're not willing to put in the effort, Dulli won't help you get it, and frankly you don't deserve it.

Luckily, PHYS1230 (along with 1530) is meant as a "review" of sorts. That being said, a lot of the material we covered I already had a basic knowledge of. I can see how if it were to be a new topic to me that his teaching style would cause problems. He often speaks in metaphors and uses confusing language. He is giving us a huge curve.

Hani Dulli is alright at best. When a student asks a question his answer can be hard to follow. This class was focused on problem solving for people who had taken physics before, so it wasn't very difficult.

This was his first semester. It was an absolute disaster. Chegg account is mandatory for hw, I learned more from it than him. Halfway through the semester he's doing serious damage control for how unfair he was so that's not too bad. Class is super volatile but with the 5% total course curve I'm probably going to end up with an A so there's that

Professor Dulli assumes that all students have a strong background in physics and does not explain the concepts well. The online homework was difficult to complete solely using his notes because he did not explain the concepts in terms of how to use them to solve problems. Lectures were not useful. Avoid this professor if you want to do well.
Prof. Dulli is well meaning, but a poor teacher. His explanations are often difficult to follow, exam questions are poorly worded, and he doesn't always show respect for students.

Hani Dulli is the worst professor I have ever had. His lectures are completely irrelevant to the material on the homework and exams, and he never does examples with actual numbers. I study for over a week for the exams and still fail, and I am a good student. He is condescending to students and rude. Avoid him at al costs.

If you're not familiar with physics from high school you will NOT pass. The lectures are all concepts, never gives examples with numbers. If you try to visit him in his office hours he blatantly calls you stupid. Exams are multiple choice and he doesn't give you any room to work out the problems. Can't do homework without googling everything.

Took her for both Elementary I and II and really enjoyed her. I mean, the Chinese language, in general, is hard, so you do have to put in the work to succeed. She is really chill about due dates, and if you turn things in late, she'll understand. Also, is great at responding to emails quickly, highly recommend.

Not recommend for non native Chinese speaker, hard to get involved on discussion. The professor graded on attendance heavily and don't accept excuse( illness with prove), if miss more than 5 class, it lower your grade from A to B, syllabus is unclear and to be honest, lecture don't worth going at all, she don't add attendance till the last min

Half of the class is asynchronous, but the discussions are mandatory. Meng laoshi is chill, a little confusing with the extra credit. Her emails can be confusing sometimes, but all in all, she's not a bad professor. Also, both the textbooks can be found online pretty easily for the weekly quizzes.

Attendance required because she checks attendance. Lectures boring, but straightforward. Easy class with not many assignments. Only big one is the group presentation due at end of semester, but she gives you the whole semester to work on it. All quizzes and exams open book. Easy and gets you acquainted with international students.
Prof Meng is great :) awesome class

Professor Meng is super chill. 70% of our grade is participation so if you show up to class you already pass. She understands Chinese is difficult and grades us lightly. HW, quizzes, and exams are straight forward and she tells us exactly what to expect. She even gave us 2 attempts on our final! Great and easy class.

Extremely easy course. Professor Meng allows open note exams and does not grade tough at all. She understand that Chinese is a difficult language and works with all her students. You learn a lot in this class but it is not overwhelming at all. Highly recommend!
I think it is too easy to be a professor. the quetions that was in the quiz are controversial. she did not give any feedback to your low grade assignments.
Prof. Meng made the class interesting. Open book online tests.
Easy tests
Took her last year, she would expected you to know everything and would want you to say it correctly even if you struggle.

Professor Meng is a very sweet woman. She was very understanding and easy to work with. If you have a conflict with any due dates, she will work to accomodate you. You'll 100% need the textbooks if you want to pass her class. She frequently gives small quizzes during class, but lets you know well beforehand. Get ready to work, languages are hard.

AMAZING. very organized with grading and structure of online class, clear grader, easy to talk to, and compromise with. lots of reading but very easy; quiz Q's come straight from reading; no tricks. DEFINATLY a easy class to take over the summer, barely lifted a finger. Group project was SUPER easy and so was the final paper. would take again!

A nice professor, who cares about the class and the material. He'll give demonstrations and show videos to explain concepts and will always try to make sure you understand the material in your own words. Gives plenty of time for homeworks, tests were online and open book, final exam was take-home but tough. Make sure you use the right equations!!!

Really nice guy, likes to make jokes every now and then to lighten the mood. Gives you quiz answers to study from the class before, changes up numbers to solidify concepts, "All or nothing" style quizzes. Homeworks are difficult, but manageable. Willing to help you, but not give you the answers. Really wants the class to do well.

This man planned out the final at the beginning of the course. Throughout the semester, he would give us an example problem then pause and mysteriously say "this is a good exam q". I starred all these times. Question for question what he said throughout the semester was on the exam. Go to lecture. Star these questions. Don't study anything else

Really a good guy, expects you to learn the material if you want to but his lectures are not worth going to. He ends them early, he starts them late and wings it. He gives you the quiz questions before each quiz and the final is very easy, open book/open laptop. You will get at least a B in this class without even trying/learning anything.
Nice guy, can't teach and very unorganized. He breezed through couple of chapters and gave a completely irrelevant question on the final exam even when he said he would not do that.

He's very funny and provides everything you need to succeed in the class. Final was open notes, open book, open internet, and some questions came directly from HW assignments. Class can be a bit boring, but it's hard for a professor to make circuits exciting. Just keep up with the course (and textbook) and you'll get a good grade.
You will literally be lost in the class. Make sure you do all the homework problems in the back of the book otherwise you will derp on the final exam.

Final was like jumping into the abyss. Did perfectly on the all of the homeworks, quizzes and labs. Ended up with a B because his final was complete madness. You also won't learn much because he only gives few homework assignments and the class is very unorganized.
Easiest Electrical Engineering Prof. at UConn. Final is difficult only because it's the only one that has questions that aren't direct copies from homework/class examples.
Good Professor, knowledgeable, easy in terms of tests/quizes basically tells you exactly whats gonna be on them and sometimes awards extra points

He was the lab instructor for EE 209W one summer session (This was when UConn had separate lecture and lab sections). The lab was fun and during summer it was a small section, so pretty much one-on-one instruction. A good lab partner is a plus. Hands-on lab EE is the "fun" part of it. Bode plots and Fourier transforms, on the other hand...

Extremely helpful, fun class. Makes it easy while teaching you everything you need to know. Makes students feel at ease about subject matter, and gives a pretty decent background on all of the components taught. Also tells jokes once in a while. He knows his stuff.

Simmons is ra Refused to give me above a B+ on anything for some reason...really nice guy though, helpful when you ask him questions or to look over your essay before you turn it in. Take notes and you'll be more than fine.

Professor Simmons was a pretty good teacher. Though at times he seemed to be a pretty difficult teacher who had high expectations because this was an honors class. Cheat sheet on exams was helpful but obviously he expects a lot of details. We could also earn up to 3 pts of extra credit on our final grade which helped me get an A.
Straight forward made his expectations clear. Allowed you to bring a double sided paper with notes.One of the Best teacher I had so far at UCONN.Made class interesting, which made time go by fast.

He's a mellow, cool guy that made history tolerable. still a young dude, so he understands our struggle. he permits a cheat sheet for the exams, which is a huge help. There's a short paper also. I highly recommend him if you need to take a gen-ed req.
Very fair professor. Allows a one pages (front and back) cheat sheet for midterm and final. Four (short) papers the whole semester. Nice guy and very knowledgable.
Super easy, can use notes on quizzes and a a cheat sheet on the exams which are really easy. He's really nice take his class!

Hist 1502 is a great class. Extremely easy, very little work, and still pretty interesting, even for someone who's not interested in history. Professor is a nice guy who answers any questions and is very straightforward about expectations and assignments.

SO EASY, he gives you study guides and allows you to have a cheat sheet for midterm/final. not alot of work but well worth it. he's a young guy and understands what college kids think/go through. easy A even if you don't like history.
Very straight forward, no surprises, not a ton of work, but if you do it you're golden

Definitely fair when it comes to exams, just do the cheat sheet and you'll be fine. He also really knows a lot about history. I just wish he had been clearer about what was expected in the essays. Overall, not a bad class.

He is an overall great guy. His exams are no surprises, he gives you a guide ahead of time and you get a sheet to bring in. Textbook readings are not necessary, however the document ones are helpful as he quizzes on those. Makes lectures interesting, guy really knows his stuff even as a PhD student.

Really good teacher, easy exams, easy quizzes, easy papers, must take this if you have to choose a history class but you're not good in history. There is also 3 points of extra credit, meaning to raise a grade. The professor is a nice guy too. Really recommanded.
TOO CUTE!
Extremely disorganized. Often late. No structure to the course at all. "Poetry" more like analyzing Yeats for a month. You can go for a good laugh or possibly cringe.

He is so unorganized and completely confusing. Don't ever expect an A without kissing up or reading everything word for word! His tests are all IDs and quotations from plays; he expects you to know every little thing! He's also an unfair grader; he will give kids that don't do the work the same grades/similar grades as those who do. crazy!

He provides a good laugh every class and is willing to help you if you ask. BUT DO NOT I repeat DO NOT get him as a professor! He is most inconsistent grader! You never know exactly what he wants when he assigns a paper or gives you a test. Luckily he allows rewrites on most things but still! Disorganized, loses stuff, doesnt show up to class!DONT.

He's ok. I started off hating him and once I got into the swing of how he teaches, it became easier for me. He also liked me because I was one of the few that came to class every single day of the year. Get on his good side and he'll be willing to help you. You need to continue to ask questions to clarify things because he's not organized at all.

Sticking with this class was the worst decision I made all semester. He's completely disorganized, and the papers he doesn't lose get handed back soaked in last night's gin. Grading is arbitrary, he'll tell you to rewrite papers that haven't been marked except for a grade on the front, and the handwritten study guide for the exam was illegible.

this guy knows all about shakespeare because he probably knew him. Extremely unorganized. changes dates for tests and papers and forgets to tell the class. all you will do is read shakespeare and basically memorize quotes. I learned nothing and i am a theatre Major. awful grader too. I've never been more frustrated by a teacher.

Very unorganized and a flaky grader. He will lose assignments often and ask for you turn in another one. Then he will find the previous assignment and give you back both assignments with 2 totally different grades. He grades/teaches on his mood. But if you go to class, office hours, participate, and make your name known to him you will do fine :)
He works REALLY hard to make literature enjoyable- I enjoyed his class. Genuinely cares about student success.

This man is sweet and knowledgeable. That being said, he will teach you NOTHING and expect you to know exactly what he didn't teach. He grades unpredictably and is the most disorganized professor I've had. He reads aloud whatever is assigned, and barely says anything insightful. The most frustrating professor I've ever had.

I had him for poetry....I love this man but he is very boring and he curves a lot. Open book quiz and midterm but he's a little scary and dirty.... other than that he tries real hard to make you laugh :) yay but forgetful and the material can be pretty boring it's all old
Richard Peterson is a wonderful, brilliant man who challenges and entertains. He is very giving of his time and his expertise and is someone I will always remember with great fondness.

You will get nothing out of this class. He reads aloud each class and expects you to copy down his interpritations to the readings. There is no thinking whatsoever. He is a sweet old man, but forgets things easily and his quizzes are just agrivating.
we only had one book of poetry for this class, brit lit..... all we did was analyze poems, and take open book quizzes. he's also very helpful, but also very forgetful.

John is a smart guy and actually learns the names of his students. He's a fast talker, so you have to pay attention to keep up with him. That said, he is very open to questions, and presents the material as intuitively as possible. His exams are hard, but the great thing about his class is that your grade is equivalent to the effort you put in.

No nonsense, but in my estimation - should ONLY teach upper level math, engineering or scientific courses. Doesn't possess the ability to manage or motivate struggling students. At least he acts personable.
Linear algebra; He talks fast, but conveys information well. If you do the optional homework assignments and keep up with the vocabulary, you will do quite well.

Very smart. But he doesn't understand students don't have such an indepth understanding of math as he does. He leaves the door to his office wide open and cares about his students but he talks way too fast and makes it hard to follow. Along with the fact that he has a hard time conveying the material to us at our level. I left class more confused
Not bad, speaks very fast and clearly knows his stuff. Do the practice exams and you can do alright.

John is a very bright and energetic teacher. Unfortunately, there are times when he overestimates the capabilities of the class in regards to their current level of comprehension. In the past, this has caused lots of problems (especially for quizzes), but I believe he has improved a little over time. Still, it's a challenge sometimes to follow him.

John Haga is too hard of a professor. He teaches as if the students are all pHD students and expects them to know a bunch.His quizzes are so bad. and its not from the homework or lectures. Gud luck if you take his class
John is a smart man but a horrible teacher. "Educated Guessing" was a strategy to solving his problems. Avoid John if possible.
John knows math really really well.. he talks very fast in class, but I enjoyed lectures a lot. He's very interesting. Don't expect the class to be easy.
Do not select john haga as your professor

He really really understands the material, and explains it well. He also sometimes adds little side-notes about math that you've always wanted to know. He's american, so he has no accent, which is obviously great. The class is tough, but that's not his fault, that's the course instructor's. He prepares you well, if you're willing to put the time in
John is a great guy and definetly willing to help during his office hours. He speaks really, really fast in class, but otherwise he is very good at conveying the material to his students.
USELESS
He received his tenure status in exchange for false testimony while a witness in Connecticut Superior Court.

Bob was the best. He was deeply concerned about his students and their understanding of the course material. His talent for guiding young egos to a better understanding of themselves was impressive. We use to venture down to Chuck's Steak House and enjoy an evening of local music. You couldn't find a better teacher or friend.

I studied with Dr. Luyster in the late 60s. I will always remember the unique and interesting experiences he provided his students. I worked with him again in the 70s when I was director of the Inner College at UConn. At that time he proved himself to be an outstanding professor who genuinely cared about the intellectual growth of the students.

How is this guy a professor of philosophy? Way in over his head. He has no concept of the subjects he teaches and their subtlties run circles around him. Utterly useless. As a person he is only mediocre. As dim-witted as he is old. AVOID
No Comments

I took 3 classes & an ind. study with Bob. He's challenging. I love that his classes are mostly discussion. I never found him to be biased against girls as some people have said. Also, he's certainly not anti-Christ, since he encouraged me to become a minister. Rather, he won't take pat religious answers--he wants you to think for yourself.

Don't take this class. He plays guessing games and doesn't care about his students. His grading is erratic and you're penalized if you don't agree with him. Oh, and as the icing on the cake, very pro-Antichrist.

I took him for three classes because I was a philosophy major and by the last one, I was soooo sick of his sledgehammer rhetoric. He plays with a limited set and recycles the same themes over and again. I would not recommend his classes for serious philosophy students. Best for young inflamatory males. (But he's not listening back.)

I have no idea what in the world everyone else is talking about that he picks on girls. He picks on the students that don't take his class seriously. If you take his course seriously, then he won't pick on you. He is extremely informative and one of the best teachers in UConn.
He was a great teacher that opened my eyes to many things. I never encountered him being unfair to females as someone else said, myself being a female.

umm, The other reviews of luyster were obviously written by guys. Umm, The discussions he holds are basically "try to guess what 'I' think about Sartre!" and he calls on women like he is waving a bug from his face. He obviously feels that female students are unformed thinkers..!
Awesome guy, every class was interesting and fun to attend. He hardly lectures at all, the entire class is just class discussion
Best techer in the world..he can open you're eyes to the important stuff in life

If you're at all interested in women's issues or violence against women take this class. The topics are difficult so make sure you're comfortable with the syllabus. It's much more applicable than I thought it would be plus Olsen is very sweet and approachable. As long as you participate in discussions and submit writing on time, you'll be fine.
Awesome professor! Really gets you thinking about contemporary women's issues all over the world related to violence. Lots of work, but you get a lot out of it.

At first I thought she would be a dry and boring professor, but soon enough I realized that she is actually pretty cool and engaging. Weekly papers, 2 analytical papers and participation made up our grade. It was a lot of work, but the content was some of the best of any class I've ever taken. Take Kristine/Women, Gender, and Violence!

She is a very nice professor but you HAVE to go to her class because she takes attendance every lecture. The class is SO MUCH WRITING and she is a pretty tough grader. Material was interesting and she posted all of the readings so you don't have to buy a textbook

Women's Movements was a cool class with her. I learned a lot and she cares about hearing different opinions and perspectives. Few complaints, just that her attendance policy is kind of strict but it's more based in participation, so definitely speak up. She's also not super free outside of class but she has a life too so that's understandable.

Three readings + one reading response each week, and four 5-6 pages long analytical papers . Classes are mainly discussion bases, so participation really matters. Both the amount of work and the content that Dr. Olsen has covered are tough, but this course is really inspirational and it completely changed my attitudes toward many things.

So it's an easy A class (weekly reading responses and three longer papers which she is super lenient about grading) BUT she is a horrible professor. She lectures at you about pretty heavy topics with little to no emotion, is not accessible outside of class, and posts readings three days before papers are due- SO. FRUSTRATING!!!!!!

Kristine is extremely caring about her students. There are reading response essays due every week, but they only have to be 2 pages and are based on your own opinions of the reading. She is generous with grading. Participation really does matter and she takes attendance every class so if you skip you will not do well.

I found this class to hit many heavy topics that are very central to the issues on campus. The course content allowed us all to think through many social issues through our papers and engaging conversations. Overall her teaching ability and style makes the class become more about exciting and educational conversations.

I really enjoyed taking this course as well as her WGSS/HRTS 2263 course. These courses have allowed me to grow more as an activist and obtain a professionalism in essays that have allowed me to be a successful student. This professor will genuinely care about you and help you develop complex concepts and ideas into strong thesis.

I have Professor Olsen for Women's Movements and she is an AMAZING professor. The class is discussion based and the topics spark some great conversations. Also, there are just 4 papers assigned and no exams, which is really nice. Easy grader of essays as long as you get your point across and have a strong thesis.
Teaches opinions and doesn't return papers back quickly even though it is a writing course.
very easy, discussion based class. weekly readings, two essays and participation make up most of the grade.

Prof Burke is so passionate about literature which makes going to her class so enjoyable! Accessible outside of class and sooo helpful with essays. She took the time to help me research sources for my paper. If you have the chance take a class with her!!!

Lots of reading but its an English class so I guess it's expected. I like that she made an effort to include authors of color. It wasnt too hard of a class, i took this fall 21 so my memory might be foggy but there wasn't many assignments. Largely discussion based and also not too big. Professor Burke was really understanding and super friendly.

Professor Burke is really sweet, and the class itself (homework and participation wise) is very easy. However, your grade is made up of only participation (25%), a midterm essay, (25%), and a final essay (50%); therefore, if you mess one up, it is hard to boost your grade back to where you want it. As a person though, she's very kind and easygoing.

Mary Burke is very knowledgable and gives outstanding lectures. However, she doesn't ask for too much thinking outside of the box. Discussion questions are typically already answered in the previous class by something she said in lecture. Repeat her opinion and you'll be golden. Essay feedback was not too helpful. Most readings were dry.

She loves her subject matter and is a lovely person to listen to. There's a ton of reading in Irish Lit but as long as you can manage that you'll be fine. She's very clear about what she wants from her students and doesn't make assignments overly difficult.

Prof Burke understands this isnt our only class. Shed rather us learn something than do things just to get a good grade. Discussion once a week are helpful b/c the Qs are what she uses for the final. Only a midterm paper (you choose/create the topic) and the final exam (2 questions. You're allowed to bring textbook and 2 pages of notes).
Wonderful lady. Very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about Wilde and Irish Lit. Interesting in lectures and easy on grading.

Friendly and helpful professor. Class was split into lecture one day and discussion the next, and questions for discussion were always emailed the day before. Final was cumulative but everything came from the discussion questions and you were allowed a cheat sheet.

She is a fabulous teacher. Very passionate and very well versed in her subject matters. Interested in students and seems to care deeply that students become interested and involved in their work. Discussion is mandatory, one paper, one final and two film screenings. Overall, a very laid back curriculum if you do the reading and show up!
Really enjoyed her class. She is extremely nice and a very easy grader. I would like to take her again before I graduate and would definitely recommend her.
Amazing teacher. She is really interesting to listen to and very interested in the subject she teaches.
She was easy as hell. If you do all her assignments you should get a A. She barely gives assignments anyway. She is very nice too. If you need a class to get a A in, you should take her.
No Comments
Laptops banned in class.

Impossible amount of reading. Regular busy work. Mandatory attendance. Poor grading criteria. Inconsistent and vague expectations. Overly-legalistic syllabus. Excessively difficult compared to similar courses.

This class is discussion based instead of lecture based which is really awesome considering the subject. Dr. Willen wants students to be engaging with the material so make sure to put your all into the portfolios/readings. The readings are a lot but add a lot to the course. The group project is also a lot but was super rewarding. Loved this class!

Our grade was based on discussion questions, participation, 4 assignments and a group project/presentation. The weekly reading for discussion questions can be long, but overall the workload is manageable. Dr. Willen is super sweet but also a little bit scary because she is a tough grader, but if you put in the work you will get a good grade.

This class was ridiculously work-heavy for no reason. You just get thrown powerpoints with notes as "lecture" and genuinely never see the professor. There are weekly discussion posts with 400-word minimums and 250-word responses that are just busywork. Three exams and weekly quizzes. It's not difficult but just full of painfully pointless work.

Willen means well and seems to genuinely care about the subject she is teaching but class is unproductive. She assigns a LOT of reading considering that we would only discuss a fraction of it. My biggest issue however was that she is an incredibly harsh grader despite not giving clear instructions for the severe level of specificity she requires.

Dr. Willen is quite passionate about the subject, but she really assumes that we are all anthropology majors "as anthropologists we need to...". Class is good, but they should add a W to the course since there was more reading than my English class. She grades quite harshly and gives no grading criteria for the projects/assignments (i.e. no rubric)

Dr. Willen is very passionate about anthropology and it shows. It's a very lecture heavy class, there are only powerpoints shown during lecture which can be a little tiresome but it's an effective way to learn the material.

I LOVE WILLEN! Attendance is mandatory because you have to turn something in every lecture class and at discussions. Weekly review quiz due every friday but they're super easy because they're online and open notes/book. She is so enthusiastic about all of thed topics we cover and it makes lectures enjoyable to sit through.
This woman gets ridiculously excited about her subject! She obviously loves to teach, and it is infectious. Her tests are very easy and she is very easy to follow. I loved this class.

She is a great professor and a wonderful person on top of that. She clearly loves the topics she teaches and makes the material comprehensible. She cares about her students and wants them all to succeed. Must go to class to get the information. Her tests are very detailed oriented and readings are 40+ so you need to have time to take her class

really good teacher, and very organized. If you love reading 100 pages for every class meeting this is your class. Quizzes and pop quizzes tend to have questions on the smallest non relevant parts of 100 + page readings. The extra credit is a joke, its pointless, she doesn't put a value on it. I liked the class at first, it quickly became brutal

Very passionate professor-fun in class.Your participation is a large part of your grade so be sure to read articles assigned! Tendency to give "surprise" quizzes on readings.She never posts power points so going to class for notes is crucial cause it's a large part of exams.Quizzes and exams are relatively simple. :)
Gang when u slide to the lectures he just has his own fun doing math and everyone has to watch and suffer. You gotta teach urself everything outside of class if u wanna succeed

I've never written one of these but had to now. Worst professor I've had. He blames his students for collectively doing poorly on exams when it is a result of the way he teaches. Reaching out for help doesn't help because he will just respond with major attitude and won't help. Gives attitude when asked questions in class. Take a different section.
Terrible professor. Please stay away from him, his lectures are useless. I never write these reviews, but I had to for this guy. He blames us for doing poorly on exams, even though he can't teach.

3 weeks in it was clear that going to class wasn't worth it. He read slides that were theoretical without teaching concepts and then fly through examples. The average on exam 1 was a 60, after blaming the low average on us, he said he would give the exam problems ahead of time on other exams. First year teaching, but thats no excuse for him sucking

I was one of the many students who didn't attend class because we were better off learning on our own. Everyone did so poorly on the first exam that he gave us the exam questions for the next 3 exams with a cheat sheet. It was a test where you just copied things down.
